    Colchicine Alkaloids and Synthetic Analogues: Current Progress and Perspectives

    • Iuliia A. Gracheva
      Iuliia A. Gracheva
      Department of Chemistry, Lobachevsky State University of Nizhny Novgorod, Nizhny Novgorod 603950, Russian Federation
      More by Iuliia A. Gracheva

    Abstract

    Colchicine, the main alkaloid of Colchicum autumnale, is one of the most famous natural molecules. Although colchicine belongs to the oldest drugs (in use since 1500 BC), its pharmacological potential as a lead structure is not yet fully exploited. This review is devoted to the synthesis and structure–activity relationships (SAR) of colchicine alkaloids and their analogues with modified A, B, and C rings, as well as hybrid compounds derived from colchicinoids including prodrugs, conjugates, and delivery systems. The systematization of a vast amount of information presented to date will create a paradigm for future studies of colchicinoids for neoplastic and various other diseases.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Natural products have historically been an invaluable source of lead structures for therapeutic agents.(1) Among the drugs approved by the FDA within the first 15 years of the 21st century, more than one-third are compounds of natural origin.(2) Colchicine (1), an alkaloid extracted from plants of the genera Colchicum, Merendera, and Gloriosa, is one of the most prominent and historically significant substances (Figure 1).(3−7) Having been used from the dawn of medicine as a joint pain remedy, colchicine finds application in modern clinical practice in the treatment of acute gout, Behçet’s disease, familial Mediterranean fever, chondrocalcinosis, systemic scleroderma, and amyloidosis.(8) Numerous studies have demonstrated the efficacy of colchicine also in autoimmune, chronic infectious, cardiovascular, allergic, and neurodegenerative diseases (Figure 2).(8−12) With the discovery of the strong antimitotic properties of colchicine, numerous attempts have been made to chemically modify the molecule in order to reduce its inherent toxic side effects. This Perspective highlights the chemical synthesis and biological activities of colchicine alkaloids and their analogues with modified A, B, and C rings, as well as hybrid compounds derived from colchicinoids, including prodrugs, conjugates, and delivery systems.

    The Cellular Protein Tubulin and Tubulin-Binding Agents: Advantages of Compounds Addressing the Colchicine-Binding Site

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    By forming the cytoskeleton, microtubules are essential structural components of eukaryotic cells. They are assembled from α–β heterodimers of the protein tubulin.(13) In humans, eight α-tubulin and seven β-tubulin isoforms were detected.(14) Microtubules are hollow cylindrical structures characterized by a complex dynamic equilibrium of tubulin polymerization/depolymerization. The control of this equilibrium is essential for the regulation of numerous cellular functions.(15) Proliferating cells form a complex dynamic array of microtubules, i.e., the mitotic spindle, which is responsible for the correct segregation of chromosomes, their divergence to the cell poles and release at the end of the mitosis process.(16,17) In nondividing cells, microtubules ensure the correct arrangement of organelles,(18) maintain the shape of compartments, participate in the processes of cell growth,(19) migration,(20,21) and intracellular transport.(22) The role of microtubules in intercellular synaptic interactions of special types has also been established.(23) Therefore, tubulin represents an important target in the treatment of cancer and a wide range of other diseases.(24)
    A large number of compounds affecting the dynamic equilibrium of the processes of self-assembly and disintegration of microtubules have been identified. Substances that stabilize microtubules and prevent their disintegration include paclitaxel, docetaxel, and their derivatives, epothilone, cyclostreptin, peloruside, and other compounds. Destabilizing compounds that interfere with the tubulin nucleation/polymerization process include Vinca-alkaloids (vincristine, vinblastine, vinorelbine), combretastatin A-1 (CA-1), and combretastatin A4 (CA-4) including their phosphate prodrugs (CA-1P and CA-4P, respectively), estramustine, podophyllotoxin, curacin A, 2-methoxyestradiol, colchicine, and other compounds(25−27) (Figure 3). All antimitotic agents, albeit in varying degrees, have a negative effect on the nervous system and the hematopoietic function of the bone marrow, cause gastrointestinal tract dysfunction, exhibit cardiotoxicity, and, in some cases, may cause aneuploidy.(24,26,28)
    The emergence of medical and pharmaceutical chemistry has allowed the launch of several antimitotic agents as drugs. Most of them bind to the Taxane or Vinca sites of tubulin: vincristine (approved for the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, lymphoma, and various solid tumors), vinblastine, vindestine (lung cancer), paclitaxel and docetaxel (nonsmall-cell lung carcinomas; breast, prostate and stomach cancer), and ixabepilone (approved for the treatment of breast cancer). For more information about the microtubule-binding agents that have undergone clinical trials, see ref (26).
    In recent decades, many studies have been conducted aiming at the development of ligands for the colchicine-binding site of tubulin. Among them are allocolchicinoids (Figure 4), in which the tropolone ring C has been changed to a benzene ring, namely, natural (−)-allocolchicine(29) (2), synthetic (−)-N-acetylcolchinol (3), and its methyl ether (NCME, 4). The water-soluble phosphate prodrug ZD6126(30−32) (5) has even reached phase II clinical trials; however, the trials had to be stopped due to cardiotoxicity at therapeutic doses. Despite some serious limitations of the established colchicine-derived compounds, such as systemic toxicity, low water solubility, and a resulting poor bioavailability, there is a continuing high interest in such compounds. This may be due to the fact that members of this class of tubulin-binding agents may also have several advantages over the Taxanes and Vinca alkaloids widely used in clinical practice.
    One such advantage is the ability of colchicine-binding site ligands to also exert an antiangiogenic effect. In recent years, a variety of colchicine-binding site compounds (such as combretastatins) have been identified as small-molecule vascular disrupting agents (VDAs).(33−36) By threatening the blood supply of tumors such compounds suppress the formation of new vessels and destroy already formed capillaries.(37) In addition, colchicine-binding site ligands are little susceptible to multidrug resistance (MDR),(37) which is one of the main factors limiting the usage of antimitotic agents in clinical practice. The development of MDR is often associated with the alteration of tubulin isoforms, namely, an increased expression of the βIII isoform, which indicates a developing resistance against Taxanes or Vinca alkaloids. Actually, the efficiency of colchicine and 2-methoxyestradiol appears to be independent of the isomorphic composition of β-tubulin.(38,39) Despite these advantages of colchicine-binding site ligands, only a few compounds of this class have found entry into clinical trials(35,40) (such as combretastatins) or have been withdrawn from testing due to low efficacy or side effects.(41)

    Colchicine Structure: A Pharmacophore Model of the Colchicine-Binding Site and Options for Modification

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Colchicine is an unusual natural product in several aspects. The molecule displays a 6–7–7 tricyclic ring system containing a tropolone ring and a stereocenter at C-7, which induces an aR-configuration of the chiral axis defined by the bond joining rings A and C(43,44) (Figure 5). Even nowadays, this seemingly structurally simple molecule (in comparison to Taxanes or Vinca alkaloids) poses a challenge to synthetic chemists.(45,46) The first total synthesis (22 steps, 0.00006% overall yield) of racemic colchicine was performed by A. Eschenmoser and co-workers in 1959, starting from readily available purpurogallin.(47) In 2017, using a [5+2]-cycloaddition strategy, C.-C. Li and co-workers reported a most efficient (9 steps, 9% overall yield) total synthesis of enantiomerically pure colchicine starting from 2,3,4-trimethoxybenzaldehyde.(48,49)
    Research on the interaction of colchicine and its derivatives with tubulin started long ago.(50) The first SAR study was carried out in 1998,(13) but the data necessary for mapping the topography of the colchicine-binding site were obtained later. A precise characterization of the colchicine-binding site was finally achieved in 2004.(51) In this study, a crystal structure of stathmin-stabilized tubulin in complex with N-acetyl-N-(2-mercaptoacetyl)colchicine (as a very close colchicine analogue) revealed subtle insights into the mode of colchicine binding and the conformational response of the protein (Figure 6).
    By integrating the binding data for 15 structurally different colchicine-related antimitotic agents, a pharmacophore model was developed.(52) This includes seven reference pharmacophore points located on two planes at an angle of 45°. The elements of this model are three acceptors of hydrogen bonds A1, A2, and A3, which form contacts with the amino-acid residues Valβ181, Cysβ241, Alaβ250, Aspβ251, and Leuβ252; the hydrogen bond donor D1 interacting with Thrβ179 and two hydrophobic centers H1 and H2, as well as the planar group R1 (Figure 6a). It was found that for effective binding, the compound should possess at least two hydrophobic centers, one hydrogen acceptor, and a planar group.(53,54) Almost any modification of ring A causes a complete loss of binding, while modifications of both B and C rings are tolerated to a certain degree (Figure 6b). The methoxy groups of rings A and C are essential for cytotoxicity of the compound but do not affect the interaction with P-glycoprotein (P-gp), the protein responsible for MDR. The presence of a nitrogen (either as an amine or an amide unit) at C-7 was established to be essential for the recognition of a colchicinoid by P-gp. Accordingly, colchicinoids lacking a nitrogen in this position are not substrates for P-glycoprotein anymore.(55) Thus, many studies have focused on the modification of the substituent at C-7 in the search for colchicine analogues with improved activity, lower toxicity, or a reduced tendency toward drug resistance.

    Ring A Modifications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The three methoxy groups at ring A of colchicine (1) are crucial for tubulin binding, and changes often result in a loss of activity. Accordingly, only a few colchicine derivatives with a modified ring A structure, including both naturally occurring and synthetic compounds, have been investigated. Demethylation of one or more methoxy groups results in a decrease of antimitotic activity by several orders of magnitude.(56) A similar trend is observed for thiocolchicine (6), which is easily obtained from 1 by nucleophilic replacement of the OMe group at C-10 by an SMe group (Scheme 1). Interestingly, 1,2,3-demethylthiocolchicine (7) shows an increased topoisomerase II inhibition activity and proved to be more potent than commercial etoposide in this respect.(57)
    A natural analogue of colchicine (1) in which the methoxy groups at positions 2 and 3 are replaced by a methylenedioxy bridge (forming a dioxol ring) is the alkaloid cornigerine (8) isolated from Colchicum cornigerum(58) (Figure 7).
    Cornigerine (8) possesses very similar biological characteristics as colchicine, including inhibition of tubulin polymerization and the prevention of the growth and division of L1210 leukemia cells in the metaphase.(59)
    The sulfuric acid-mediated regioselective C-2-O-demethylation of colchicine (1) was exploited in the preparation of derivatives with improved water solubility and bioavailability, however, at the price of a significantly decreased cytotoxicity and tubulin inhibition (Scheme 2).(60)
    Compounds 9 and 10 exhibited cytotoxicity in the range of 0.08–1.42 μM to cells of pulmonary A549, ovarian 1A9, and epidermal KB carcinomas. In comparison, unmodified colchicine (1) displayed a much higher activity (IC50 = 0.002–0.003 μM) against the same cell lines.(60)
    Also, glycoside analogues of colchicine have been described, such as colchicoside (11) and thiocolchicoside (12),(61,62) in which the methoxy group at C-3 is replaced by an O-glycoside residue (Scheme 3). Colchicoside, a natural alkaloid isolated from the Gloriosa superba, served as a starting compound for the preparation of thiocolchicoside (12). The latter is used as a muscle relaxant in the treatment of rheumatological disorders due to its analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects. Compounds 11 and 12 were found to possess not only an increased solubility in water but also the ability to inhibit signaling cascades and pathways involving the transcription factor NF-kB.
    A number of functionalized thiocolchicoside derivatives were found to exhibit affinity toward the GABA- and strychnine-sensitive glycine receptors localized in the brain and spinal cord.(63,64) Their synthesis started from 3-demethylthiocolchicine,(65) (13) which was reacted with acetylated glycosyl fluorides 14 in the presence of tetramethylguanidine (TMG) and BF3–Et2O in acetonitrile to give a number of thiocolchicine-grafted glycosides 15. After removal of the protective groups, these compounds 16 were modified at position 6 of the carbohydrate fragment (Scheme 3).
    Replacement of the C-1 methoxy group of colchicine by other alkyloxy or acyloxy groups(66−68) did not lead to significant changes in the cytotoxicity of the compounds; however, bulky substituents led to reduced activity (Scheme 4). The same held true for a C-1-modified thiocolchicine.(69)
    In 2008, Kitajima et al. reported the isolation of gloriosamine A (20) from Gloriosa rothschildiana as the first example of a natural colchicinoid bearing a substituent at the C-4 position(70) (Figure 8). Biological evaluations showed gloriosamine A (20) to exhibit significant cytotoxicity against A549 human lung adenocarcinoma cells and thus inspired researchers to investigate 4-substituted colchicinoids. In 2011, Yasobu et al. published results of their studies on colchicine derivatives with different C-4 substituents(71) (Figure 8). By evaluating the cell-growth inhibitory activity using mice transplanted with the HCT116 human colorectal carcinoma cell line, it was found that 4-fluorocolchicine 21 and 4-chlorocolchicine 22 exhibited a lower toxicity and a more potent cell-growth inhibitory activity than colchicine (1). Later, Majcher et al. investigated the activity and selectivity of colchicine derivatives modified both at C-4 and C-10 position(72) (29–32, Figure 8). They showed that 4-bromothiocolchicine 31 and 4-iodothiocolchicine 32 are active against three of the investigated cancer cell lines (A549, MCF-7, LoVo) with potency at nanomolar concentrations and an improved relative affinity toward tumor cells over normal cells.
    Electrophilic alkylation of colchicine (1) with paraformaldehyde or a mixture of an aldehyde and an amine in H2SO4 resulted in the formation of 4-substituted derivatives 33–35(73) (Figure 9). However, the products proved to be much less cytotoxic by at least 2 orders of magnitude.
    To summarize, the nature of the substituents at ring A of colchicine (1) plays an important role. Some of the ring A derivatives showed almost 100% inhibition of tubulin polymerization in the low micromolar concentration range in all cases not exceeding the value for colchicine. However, as a rule, changes at ring A generally lead to a decrease in biological activity and do not result in the suppression of side effects of colchicine.

    Ring B Modifications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Ring B, along with ring A, plays an important role in the binding of colchicinoids to tubulin,(74) although changes of this structural fragment are possible without disturbing the biological activity. In particular, a variation of the C-7 substituent can be implemented maintaining high cytotoxicity.(75)

    Skeletal Modifications of Ring B

    Known skeletal modifications of ring B include ring contraction and expansion, heteroatom insertion, and annulation of an additional (heterocyclic) ring. As the size and the nature of ring B influences the dihedral angle along the (chiral) axis linking rings A and C, the study of synthetic ring B-modified colchicine analogues has opened insights into the dependency of biological activity (tubulin polymerization inhibition) on the torsional twist and the size of ring B.
    In 1993, Sun et al. published the synthesis of a series of thiocolchicinoids with a six-membered ring B(76) (Scheme 5). Following established protocols, deacetylthiocolchicine (36) was prepared from 1, and a subsequent Demjanov rearrangement afforded the B-nor-colchicinoid 37 bearing a hydroxymethyl group. Acylation of the alcohol function 37 with various acyl chlorides then yielded derivatives of type 38, while dehydration with tosyl chloride and DBU led to alkene 39.
    These new colchicinoids, as well as colchicine (1) and thiocolchicine (6), were tested in KB (nasopharyngeal cancer), A549 (lung carcinoma), HCT-8 (colon cancer), P388 (leukemia strain), RPMI-7951 (melanoma), and TE671 (brain cancer) cell lines to establish their inhibitory effect on tubulin polymerization and cell growth. Among the synthesized compounds, the carbonate 38 (with R = OEt) exhibited the highest cytotoxicity, which was comparable to that of thiocolchicine (6).
    The alkene 39, as well as ester derivatives with small substituents, showed the strongest inhibition of tubulin polymerization. The high activity of 39 indicates that a preorganized S-configuration of the chiral axis is not necessary for tubulin binding. This is also confirmed by a comparison of alkene 39 (2.4 μM) and alcohol 37 (3.6 μM) with respect to their inhibitory ability as well as their binding affinity toward tubulin, the latter being determined in a competition assay using labeled colchicine. A similar pattern is also observed for compounds 40–42 without a stereocenter in ring B(77−80) (Figure 10), which exhibit strong tubulin inhibition activity.
    More recently, Schmalz and co-workers prepared colchicinoids with a six-membered ring B through Demjanov rearrangement of deacetylcolchicine 43(81) and subsequent derivatization of the alcohol 44(82) (Scheme 6).
    Interestingly, colchicinoid 46 with an exo-methylene group at ring B proved to be the most promising compound in this series. It is active in the nanomolar concentration range and possesses a pronounced apoptosis-inducing activity. Moreover, compound 46, in combination with vincristine, showed a pronounced synergistic effect against vincristine-resistant cells.
    A Beckmann rearrangement was applied to obtain the first thiocolchicine derivative with an expanded, eight-membered B-ring.(83) A series of allocolchicinoids with a nitrogen-containing B ring were synthesized as shown in Scheme 7. The deacetylated allocolchicine analogue 48,(84) prepared from colchicine (1), was transformed into the ketone 49 using the Rappoport reagent.(85) The reaction of 49 with hydroxylamine hydrochloride gave the oxime 50, which underwent Beckmann rearrangement to afford a mixture of lactams 51 and 52. The predominantly formed isomer 52 was reduced to the unstable amine 53, which was stabilized by N-acetylation using pentafluorophenyl acetate.
    N-Acetylcolchinol methyl ester (NCME, 4), which inhibits tubulin polymerization somewhat more effectively than colchicine itself, was selected as a standard for in vitro biological tests.(86) Among the synthesized compounds, ketone 49 and oxime 50 were shown to be most effective with a cytotoxicity comparable to that of NCME (4) (Scheme 7). Among the colchicinoids with an expanded ring B, the acetylated compound 54 was most active, while lactams 51 and 52 proved to be almost inactive. X-ray crystal structure analysis of 50 revealed a twist angle of 53°, which corresponds to that of the most active compounds in the colchicine series.(87)
    In addition to derivatives 49–54 described above, the authors also synthesized the allocolchicinoids 56 and 57 containing a heterocycle condensed to ring B(84) (Scheme 7). Compounds 56 and 57 showed significant cytotoxicity to MCF-7 cells, comparable to the highly active parent compounds such as colchicine (1) and NCME (4). As a related compound, the tetracyclic colchicinoid 59 was synthesized in 2003 by the group of Danieli by treatment of deacetylthiocolchicine (36) with tert-butyl nitrite in the presence of catalytic amounts of acetic acid.(88) The reaction presumably proceeds via a diazo intermediate 58 from which the tetracyclic product is formed under the elimination of tert-butanol (Scheme 8). The authors noted that compound 59 is cytotoxic against a broad range of cell lines, being, in some cases, as active as paclitaxel.
    It should be noted that the treatment of 36 with nitrous acid instead of tert-butyl nitrite led to the formation of the ring-contracted product 37, as described earlier (see Scheme 5). In this case, the diazonium salt 60 is formed as an intermediate prone to undergo Demjanov rearrangement.
    In addition to colchicinoids with a nitrogen-containing B ring, colchicinoids containing an oxygen atom in the B ring were synthesized by Schmalz and co-workers(89) (Scheme 9). After enantioselective reduction of the ketone 61 using the Corey–Bakshi–Shibata protocol, the alcohol 62 was O-propargylated to give 63. Substitution of iodine by a succinyl side chain was achieved by iodine–magnesium exchange, transmetalation using CuCN·2LiCl, and acylation of the resulting cuprate with methyl 4-chloro-4-oxobutanoate. The obtained acid 64 was converted into the diazoketone 65, from which the tetracyclic key intermediate 66 was obtained in a Rh-catalyzed process involving an intramolecular [5+2]-cycloaddition. Treatment of 66 with Et2AlCl yielded the dihydrotropolone 67. While attempts to convert the reduced intermediate 66 via 68 into a tropolone 70 were unsuccessful, the epoxide 69 was isolated as the only major product instead.
    Employing BJAB and Nalm-6 cell lines resistant to doxorubicin, the apoptosis-inducing activity of colchicinoids 66 and 67 was assessed. While both compounds exhibit only moderate activity by themselves, they were shown to strongly enhance (recover) the cytostatic effect of doxorubicin against the resistant Nalm-6 cells (synergistic effect of 400% at a concentration of 1 nM of doxorubicin and 10 μM of 66).
    In 2012, Nicolaou et al.(90) reported the diversity-oriented synthesis of tetracyclic allocolchicine-related compounds of types 71–78 with different constitutional arrangements of ring B (Figure 11). Starting from common key precursors related to autumnaline, a library of compounds was prepared. Some compounds were found to exhibit significant cytotoxic activity against HT-29 colorectal carcinoma cells, thus indicating the potential of such structures for further development.
    Summing up the findings from this section, we can observe that there are many examples of preserving or increasing the cytotoxicity of derivatives with a narrowing of cycle B and the inclusion of heterocycles. Moreover, the extension of cycle B negatively affects the cytotoxicity and inhibition of tubulin due to a change in the angle between rings A and C.

    Side-Chain Modifications at Ring B

    To increase the bioavailability of colchicine, water-soluble glycosylated derivatives of type 79 were prepared by reaction of methoxamine intermediate 80 with a number of reducing sugars(91) (Scheme 10).
    The activated ester 81 was treated with deacetylcolchicine (43)(81) to yield the methoxyamine-substituted colchicine 80 after Boc deprotection. By reacting this compound with various monosaccharides, a library of 58 glycosylated derivatives of type 79 was prepared (14–78% yields). These compounds were found to possess a less pronounced cytotoxic activity (0.3–1 μM) compared to colchicine (0.025–0.035 μM) against SKOV-3, ADR-Res, SF-268, and HCT-116 cell lines. As the most interesting result, it was shown that two glycosides containing deoxypentose residues exhibited activity as microtubule stabilizers, i.e., the opposite of the usual (expected) effect of colchicinoids as inhibitors of tubulin polymerization. Thus, this study has demonstrated for the first time that “normal” colchicinoids can be converted into microtubule-stabilizing agents by seemingly minor structural modification.
    The interaction of colchicinoids with cell membranes significantly influences their biological properties as the drug may not reach its tubulin target if it cannot properly pass the lipid membrane. To investigate such effects, a number of water-soluble (82–85) and lipophilic (86–88) colchicine derivatives were synthesized (Figure 12) by Lebeau et al.(92) These authors also demonstrated in vivo that colchicine initially mainly localizes in the cell membrane, while only a few molecules succeed to directly interact with tubulin. Only in a second stage of the drug delivery process, the drug is slowly released into the cytosol where it is almost irreversibly grasped by tubulin. Thus, the cell membranes serve as a depot for colchicine, as a passive regulator of the intracellular admission of the alkaloid.
    The lipophilic SIB-conjugated PEGylated colchicine 89 labeled with 131I was used to investigate its biodistribution in tumor-bearing mice.(93) It was found that the drug cleared from normal organs rapidly and did not undergo deiodination in vivo. However, a poor tumor localization excluded it from being further investigated as a tumor-targeting radiopharmaceutical.
    To prepare a library of C-7-modified colchicinoids of type 94 (including lipophilic derivatives), a “click”-conjugation approach employing the colchicine-derived azide 93 was elaborated(94) (Scheme 11). The azide 93 was prepared from colchicine (1) after deacetylation and treatment with trifluoromethylsulfonylazide (TfN3). The Cu-catalyzed 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of 93 with alkynes (including propargyl esters of palmitic and oleic acid, respectively) proceeded under microwave irradiation to afford triazoles of type 94. In a similar fashion, derivatives of allocolchicine 96(94) and N-acetylcolchinol 92(95) were also prepared.
    Using this approach, a wide range of C-7-modified colchicine derivatives (97–105) containing an alkyl, aryl, heteroaryl, hydroxyl, amine, and ester group, as well as fragments of carbohydrates, steroids, and organometallic complexes were obtained(94−97) (Figure 13).
    A publication from 2018(98) is devoted to the preparation of urea derivatives of colchicine 106 (Figure 14). The investigation of the cytotoxic activity of these urea derivatives against HT-29, MCF-7, HeLa, and HEK-293 cell lines revealed that almost all compounds were active in the nanomolar or even subnanomolar concentration range. Interestingly, a chlorine atom in the o-position of the N-phenyl ring was found to increase the activity. In addition, the ability of these compounds to reduce the expression of proto-oncogenes associated with telomerase activation and the VEGF/VEGFR-2 autocrine process (such as c-MYC, hTERT) was observed at concentrations close to the IC50 and below. The inhibitory ability of 106a and 106b is comparable to sunitinib, a well-known protein kinase inhibitor approved by the FDA in 2006 for the treatment of kidney cancer, resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and progressive well-differentiated locally advanced or metastatic pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
    The related thiourea derivatives of type 109(99,100) (prepared as shown in Scheme 12) were also found to exhibit cytotoxic activity against A549, HT-29, and HCT116 cell lines, with IC50 values in the low nanomolar range (0.3–5 nM) for the most active compounds. Noteworthy, in vivo experiments using a compound of type 109 (with R1 = ethyl and R2 = p-N,N-dimethylaminophenyl) confirmed a significant antitumor activity, while the test animals showed no changes in behavior, weight loss, and lethality.
    In 2007, Lee et al. reported the synthesis of a new colchicine derivative, CT20126 (110), possessing an immunosuppressive activity(101) (Figure 15).
    Remarkably, compound 110 inhibits the proliferation of lymphocytes without showing cytotoxic effects and additionally inhibits the expression of pro-inflammatory genes, such as iNOS, TNF-α, and IL-1β, in macrophages. This compound induces apoptosis by halting the cell cycle in the G2/M phase and activating caspase-3, which is nondistinctive for colchicine and its analogues. Compound 110 was initially developed as an inhibitor of tubulin polymerization. However, unlike colchicine, it not only causes rapid destruction of microtubules but also promotes the polymerization of tubulin dimers to short filaments, which then do not function properly.(102)
    Recently, new carbamate derivatives of colchicine (111a/b) also possessing immunosuppressive effects were synthesized(103) (Figure 16). These compounds interfere with the proliferation of CD8+ T cells as well as CD4+ T cells by inducing apoptosis through inhibition of tubulin polymerization, cell cycle arrest in the G2 phase, and reduced mitochondrial polymerization. These compounds also suppress T-cell activation by inhibiting IL-2R activation and the STAT3 signaling pathway. Therefore, compounds 111a/b were suggested to be used in organ transplantation in conjunction with reduced doses of cyclosporine A. This might allow the suppression of side effects and improve efficacy by promoting the survival of transplanted organs and cells.
    In addition to colchicine derivatives bearing an amide, carbamate, or urea side chain at C-7, the corresponding ester analogues of thiocolchicine have also been investigated. To install the required hydroxyl group at the C-7 position, deacetylthiocolchicine (36) was first treated with 4-formyl-1-methylpyridinium benzenesulfonate (FMB) according to the Rapoport method, and the resulting ketone 113 was subsequently reduced with sodium borohydride. The racemic mixture of alcohols (rac-114) was effectively resolved via chromatographic separation of the diastereomeric esters obtained with camphanoyl chloride(104) (Scheme 13).
    The enantiomerically pure alcohols 114 were then converted into esters derived from aliphatic, aromatic, and heteroaromatic acids. It was shown that 7R isomers are significantly less active than the 7S enantiomers in the inhibition of tubulin polymerization. In addition, esters derived in a similar fashion from allothiocolchicine were investigated(105) and found to inhibit tubulin polymerization more effectively as compared to colchicine and thiocolchicine under the same conditions.
    Recently, a group that previously synthesized double-modified derivatives of colchicine reported the synthesis and biological investigation of triple-modified colchicine analogues, i.e., 4-chlorothiocolchicine derivatives with a carbamate 116–123,(106) amide 124–139, and urea 130(107) side chain at C-7 (Scheme 14). The majority of these compounds exhibited a significantly higher cytotoxicity than colchicine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin against the cancer cell lines tested. In addition, four compounds (118–121) showed a strongly improved selectivity toward cancer cells as compared to normal cells.
    To summarize, the side chain of cycle B is tolerant of various types of functionalization. As will be shown further, the C-7 position can be effectively utilized to create prodrugs and hybrid drugs and for the attachment to polymer carriers.

    Ring C Modifications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As already mentioned, the tropolone ring plays a significant role in the interaction of colchicine (1) with tubulin.(108,109) However, compared with ring A, this fragment of the molecule is more tolerant to structural changes, and many C ring-modified colchicinoids with high or even improved biological activity are known (including compounds with a contracted, six-membered ring C). The ease of the synthetic modification of ring C is an important factor in the development of prodrug forms of colchicinoids.
    One of the prominent colchicine analogues with a six-membered ring C is N-acetylcolchinol (3), along with its water-soluble form ZD6126(30) (5), and its methyl ether (NCME, 4) (see Figure 4). To date, several protocols for the preparation of these compounds have been developed.
    The common synthesis of N-acetylcolchinol (3) starts from natural colchicine (1), which is first converted into colchiceine(110) (131) by acidic hydrolysis of the tropolone methyl ether. This compound is then oxidatively degraded to iodocolchinol (90), according to Windaus.(94) Deiodination of 90 with an excess of zinc in acetic acid leads to 3 in a high yield (Scheme 15).
    Another method for the synthesis of N-acetylcolchinol from colchicine (1) is based on the facile transformation of colchicine (1) into allocolchicine(111,112) (2) in the presence of sodium methylate. After ester hydrolysis, allocolchicinic acid (134) is degraded to the corresponding aniline (135) by Schmidt rearrangement. Diazotization of 135, followed by hydrolysis, gives rise to N-acetylcolchinol (3). Noteworthy, the reaction of allocolchicine (2) with methyl lithium and subsequently with H2O2 affords the hydroperoxide 136, which readily further reacts to N-acetylcolchinol (3) in a fashion related to the Hock phenol synthesis from cumene (Scheme 15).
    In addition to the semisynthetic preparation of N-acetylcolchinol (3) from natural colchicine (1), several strategies have been developed for the total synthesis of allocolchicinoids.(113) One of the key steps in almost all syntheses is a biaryl-coupling step performed under oxidative,(114−116) reductive,(117) or Pd-catalyzed Suzuki(118) cross-coupling conditions. For the oxidative biaryl coupling step, hypervalent iodine reagents, as well as (toxic) thallium salts,(115) have found stoichiometric application. The control of the stereocenter configuration was realized through the asymmetric reduction of a carbonyl group(119) or hydrogenation of enamides(120) (Scheme 16).
    For the synthesis of N-acetylcolchinol derivative NCME (4), several interesting approaches were proposed (Scheme 17). The key steps of the DeShong and co-workers(121) synthesis were Friedel–Crafts acylation and Favorskii-related rearrangement of 146 to expand ring B to a seven-membered ring. Green et al.(122) exploited an intramolecular Nicholas reaction to synthesize 4 in an enantiomerically enriched form.(123) The required dicobalt octacarbonyl complex 147 was prepared from aldehyde 148 obtained on the previous biaryl coupling step. Later, a shorter synthesis of NCME (4) via Lewis acid-catalyzed cyclization of the biphenyl-propenone 149 was published by the same scientific group.(124) An unusual method for the synthesis of NCME (4) was disclosed in 2017 by C.-C. Li and co-workers.(48) It is based on the photoinduced conversion of colchicine into β-lumicolchicine (150), followed by photochemical decarbonylation and electrocyclic opening of the Dewar benzene intermediate.
    Several strategies have also been developed for the total synthesis of allocolchicine (2), which represents another biologically important colchicinoid (Scheme 18). As key steps, the Diels–Alder reaction,(125,126) ene-yne metathesis,(126) as well as transition-metal-catalyzed arylation(127) and cycloaddition(128,129) reactions were exploited.
    The semisynthetic preparation of allocolchicine (2) from natural colchicine (1) exploits a methoxide-induced rearrangement (see Scheme 15).(111) After the nucleophilic attack of the methoxide anion on the carbonyl group of the tropolone ring of colchicine, the cycloheptatriene intermediate 132 undergoes an electrocyclic reaction to form the norcaradiene 133, from which allocolchicine (2) is formed under fragmentation of the cyclopropane ring and elimination of methoxide. Hydrolysis of the methyl ester leads to allocolchicinic acid (allocolchiceine, 134), which can be used for the synthesis of N-acetylcolchinol (3).
    As an interesting (albeit less efficient) alternative, the conversion of colchicine (1) into allocolchicine (2) can also be achieved by photochemical oxidation (endoperoxide formation) followed by reduction/decarboxylation(84) (Scheme 18).
    Like colchicine (1), allocolchicine (2), N-acetylcolchinol (3), and its methyl ester NCME (4) possess high affinity to tubulin and exhibit a strong cytotoxicity against many types of tumor cells. However, all these compounds show significant side effects that limit their use in clinical practice. Accordingly, the search for structurally related compounds with a more favorable pharmacological profile continues to be an attractive scientific playground. It is important to note here that unlike colchicine (1), existing as a single axial (aR,7S)-isomer, allocolchicinoids exist in solution at room temperature as mixtures of aR and aS isomers.(113) Since the biological activity of each configuration has never been reported so far, the question of which of the two (or both?) possible conformers can bind to tubulin remains open.
    A somewhat unusual compound is (S)-3,8,9,10-tetramethoxyallocolchicine named “Green 1” (161), an isomer of NCME, in which the three methoxy substituents at ring A are shifted by one position (Figure 17). Unlike colchicine, Green 1 exerts no effect on tubulin polymerization, indicating a different target. However, it induces pro-death autophagy in pancreatic cancer cells and E6 leukemia cells but not in normal human fibroblasts, in contrast to NCME (4), which acts nonselectively in both cancer and normal cells. Green 1 also caused increased production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in mitochondria isolated from pancreatic cancer cells. Furthermore, in vivo studies showed that Green 1 is tolerated well in mice.(130)
    The substitution of one of the oxygen functional groups of biologically active colchinoids by a fluorine atom may lead to new drug candidates with enhanced metabolic stability and lipophilicity or other novel features.(131) In 2016, Akai et al. synthesized a number of allocolchicine analogues via the spirocyclic key intermediate 163 through domino deoxyfluorination/rearrangement or acid-promoted dienone-phenol rearrangement(132) (Scheme 19). The investigation of the cytotoxicity of compounds 166a/b against DU145 (prostatic) and Panc1 (pancreatic) cancer cells revealed the fluorinated derivatives to exhibit strong cell-growth inhibition, comparable to N-acetylcolchinol (3) and NCME (4). Furthermore, these compounds proved to be less toxic to a noncancerous cell line than the known compounds.
    Another type of colchicine analogues is those containing a heterocyclic substructure instead of ring C. The conversion of the tropolone ring of colchicine (1) by the Diels–Alder reaction with 2-nitrosopyridines was described by the Miller group in 2010(133) (Scheme 20). The resulting bridged polycyclic products (168) were formed as mixtures of two regioisomers; however, useful regioselectivities were obtained using 2-nitrosopyridines with a substituent at position 6.
    The cytotoxic activity of colchicinoids of type 168 with respect to PC-3 (prostate carcinoma) and MCF-7 (human breast duct adenocarcinoma) cell lines was examined. Most new derivatives were found to exhibit a cytotoxicity (10–28 nM) comparable to colchicine. Interestingly, some of the compounds enhanced tubulin polymerization rather than disturbing the self-assembly process. Apparently, the introduction of a heterocycle at the C-8,12 position of ring-C of colchicine changes the structural conformation and affects the colchicine–tubulin interaction.
    Baudoin and co-workers(134) demonstrated that substituted dibenzo[c,e]oxepine, i.e., 6-oxa-allocolchicinoids, may display potent biological activities. Taking into account that the C-7 substituent at the B ring of colchicine may be varied and that various functional groups are being tolerated well in this position maintaining bioactivity, several reports on the synthesis of 6-oxa-allocolchicinoids of types 169–173 were published(135−139) (Figure 18).
    Among the compounds shown in Figure 18, phenol 172 showed promising biological activity: 172 inhibits tubulin assembly to the same extent as combretastatin A-4 (CA-4). The authors speculated that in the absence of bulky substituents in B and C cycle, the molecule is free to adopt the aR configuration required for binding to tubulin despite the chemical difference from CA-4 and colchicine (1).(137)
    In 2012, the first allocolchicinoids with a heterocyclic ring (D) condensed to ring C were reported by N. Sitnikov et al.(140) Starting from 3,4,5-trimethoxyphenylpropionic acid (176), these authors developed a total synthesis of the pyrrolo-allocolchicinoids 178 and 179 and also of the related structures 183 and 184 with a reversed orientation of the N-methyl-indole fragment(140−143) (Scheme 21).
    The key steps in the synthesis of compounds 178 and 179 are a Suzuki–Miyaura biaryl coupling and Friedel–Crafts cyclization of acyl chlorides generated in situ by means of the Ghosez reagent (Scheme 21A). Pyrrolo-allocolchicinoids 183 and 184 were synthesized by direct intramolecular C–H arylation of aryl iodides 181 and 182, respectively (Scheme 21B). While the 2-substituted indole derivative 181 was prepared through Weinreb ketone synthesis, the isomeric intermediate 182 could be obtained by direct Friedel–Crafts acylation of 1-methyl-1H-indole (180).(141) Further transformations of the C-7 keto functionality in the primary tetracyclic products 178, 179, 183, and 184 allowed the preparation of various derivatives (ketones, alcohols, azides, amines, and acetamides). Chiral derivatives were only prepared in the racemic series.
    As a remarkable outcome of this study, alcohols and ketones of type 178 and 179 were found to exhibit strong antiproliferative and apoptosis-inducing activity against Burkitt’s lymphoma cells (BJAB)(140,142) in the nano- and subnanomolar concentration range, while showing only a relatively low nonspecific cytotoxicity.
    Later, semisynthetic approaches toward nonracemic pyrrole-derived allocolchicines were developed as well (Scheme 22).(144−146) Starting from allocolchicinic acid (134) prepared from natural colchicine (1) (see Scheme 15), pyrrolo-allocolchicinoids of type 186 were obtained in 6 steps using the Fisher method to introduce the pyrrole cycle.(146) In the case of 187, the pyrrole ring was installed by a Pd-catalyzed tandem Sonogashira coupling/5-endo-dig (Larock-type) cyclization.(144) In comparison with colchicine and the N-H congeners 186 and 187a, the N-methyl substituted compound 187b demonstrated the most pronounced anticancer activity (IC50 < 1 nM, cell cycle arrest in the G2/M phase, 25% apoptosis induction) as well as a lower short-time toxicity against the human colon cell line HT-29.
    Also, starting from colchicine (1), syntheses of various nonracemic furano-allocolchicinoids were elaborated by Fedorov and co-workers(147−151) (Scheme 23). Compound 188 was prepared in only three steps by first transforming 1 into iodocolchinol (90)(95) and subsequent Larock-type Pd-catalyzed annulation of the furan ring employing terminal alkynes(147) (Scheme 23).
    Among the prepared molecules, colchicinoid 188 (R = CH2OH, Scheme 23) containing a hydroxyl group in the pseudobenzylic position was found to exhibit high cytotoxic activity. In vivo testing of this most potent furano-allocolchicinoid using C57BL/6 mice inoculated with Wnt-1 tumor cells indicated significant inhibition of tumor growth without weight loss, neurological symptoms, and lethality of the experimental animals.(147) This may result from the ability of this pharmacophore fragment to readily form covalent bonds with tubulin by connecting with flexible S–H cysteine residues. The possibility of covalent attachment of such furano-allocolchicines with thiols was demonstrated by the reaction of 188 with various sulfur-containing compounds leading to the ex vivo formation of sulfides of furano-allocolchicines 189 with full conversion in an acidic medium(148) (Scheme 23).
    Furano-allocolchicinoids containing hydroxyl groups at both the benzylic and the pseudobenzylic positions (190, R = CH2OH) exhibit cytotoxicity toward epithelial cell lines in the nanomolar concentration range and induce a panel of cellular effects such as overexpression of tubulin and F-actin, as well as hyperpolarization of mitochondrial and lysosomal membranes.(149) In addition, the authors made an interesting observation concerning the influence of “charge” on the cytotoxicity. More specifically, the presence of a primary amine at C-7 in 191 (R = H) causes substantial reduction of the antiproliferative activity in comparison with the corresponding alcohol (190), and compounds with a carboxyl group (or zwitterionic compounds carrying both an amino and a carboxyl group) also show reduced activity, albeit to a lesser extent.(150,151) This suggests that compounds with functional groups, which are protonated (amino) or deprotonated (carboxyl) under physiological conditions, are less active because cells restrict charged molecules to specific organelles, such as lysosomes or mitochondria. This demonstrates that the physicochemical and cytotoxicity profile of physiologically active compounds can be modified by simple variation of functional groups.

    Miscellaneous Modification of Rings A, B, and C: Organometallic Complexes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The simplest option to modify the substitution pattern of colchicine ring C is the replacement of the tropolone methoxy group by reaction with a sulfur nucleophile, as in the synthesis of thiocolchicine (6).(152) The conversion of 1 into isocolchicine (192)(153) involves a swap of the two oxygen functionalities (Scheme 24).
    It is interesting to note that thiocolchicine (6) possesses significant antiproliferative activity, resulting from the inhibition of tubulin polymerization by binding to the colchicine binding site.(76) In a concentration range of 0.02–70 nM, it stops cell growth and division of KB, A549, HCT, P388, RPMI-7951, and TE671 cell lines. While various (mainly C-7-modified) derivatives of thiocolchicine (6) were found to exhibit significant biological activity,(154) isocolchicine (192) does not possess affinity toward tubulin and is noncytotoxic.(155,156)
    Another simple analogue of colchicine is colchicide(157) (193), in which the C-10 methoxy group is replaced by a hydrogen atom. This compound (193) is accessible from thiocolchicine (6) by reaction with Raney nickel in acetone (Scheme 24). For a long time, the methoxy group at the colchicine ring C had been considered necessary for tubulin affinity. However, colchicide (193) was found to exhibit an in vitro activity comparable to colchicine, with 87% protein binding at a concentration of 25 μM (90% for colchicine under the same conditions).(158) Moreover, compared to colchicine (1), colchicide (193) proved to be at least 30 times less toxic after a single intramuscular injection.
    A large number of studies concern the biological activity of colchicinoids containing an amino substituent instead of the C-10 methoxy group at ring C (compounds 194, Scheme 25). As a rule, the advantage of such aza-colchicines results from the fact that the biological activity is maintained, while the compounds are less exposed to P-glycoprotein (P-gp), causing the development of multidrug resistance.(159) The known members of this compound family are derived either from ammonia (with a free NH2 group),(160) mono- or disubstituted alkylamines,(161,162) allyl or propargylamine,(163) aromatic amines,(161,164) amino acids,(165) ethanolamine,(166) morpholine, or piperazine.(161)
    Azacolchicinoids of type 194 with small amino substituents X, such as NHMe (194k) or NHEt (194l), display a strong cytotoxicity based on inhibition of tubulin polymerization. Compounds derived from isopropylamine (194n) show an activity profile similar to colchicine.(167) Derivatives with bulky amino substituents (194d,i,j,r) display a decreased antitumoral activity.(167,168) Noteworthy, substitution of the C-10 methoxy group of colchicine (1) by NH2 leads to an increase of the biological activity and simultaneously to a decreased general toxicity at the same therapeutic dose.(169) As mentioned before, the introduction of an amino group at C-10 reduces the efflux of colchicinoids by P-gp, probably due to an altered interaction mechanism.(161) A similar behavior, i.e., a reduced P-gp response upon drug administration, while maintaining the antiproliferative activity, was also recorded for compound 194u with a halogenated arylamino group at C-10.(164)
    As another subtype of C-10 nitrogen-substituted colchicine derivatives, the nitrate conjugates 196 and 197 were synthesized as shown in Scheme 26.(170) After nucleophilic substitution of the methoxy group by the reaction of 1 with ethanolamine, the product was reacted with succinic anhydride to give the acid 195. O-Alkylation of the carboxylate either with 4-hydroxybenzyl bromide or a 1,ω-dibromoalkane then allowed the preparation of the nitrates 196 and 197, respectively. These compounds were then shown to exhibit cytotoxic activity in a concentration range of 0.02–0.3 μM toward A2780, A549, BEL7402, and MCF7 cell lines. The nitro derivatives were originally expected to display a special biological activity due to the release of nitrogen monoxide; however, the authors did not report any results of biological experiments.
    Organometallic derivatives of colchicine can be synthesized not only through the click methodology (see Figure 14), employing metallocene-derived alkynes, but also by creating chelate complexes. An example of such a colchicine derivative is the rhenium tricarbonyl complex 198(171) prepared according to Scheme 27. Deacetylcolchiceine (199), synthesized from colchicine (1), was reacted with bromoacetic acid to give the tridentate ligand (200), which upon treatment with 188Re(H2O)3(CO)3 afforded the metal-containing colchicinoid 198.
    The rhenium-188 complex 198 can be used for combined chemo and radiotherapy of tumors. This compound does not undergo transchelation when incubated with histidine and cysteine for 48 h and possesses a sufficient lifetime for usage in clinical practice. Biodistribution experiments demonstrated high tumor uptake and a significantly increased tumor-to-muscle ratio of the drug. At the same time, the accumulation of this drug in the liver does not change during the day, which is possibly associated with the increased lipophilicity of this derivative. In addition to the colchicine-derived rhenium complex, several other conjugates of colchicine with gadolinium,(172,173) technetium,(174−176) and cobalt(81) complexes have also been described.
    In 2020, Kurek et al. designed and tested biological activity of colchicine complexes with lithium, sodium, potassium, magnesium, and zinc nitrates(177) (201, Figure 19). Antimitotic activity on ovarian cancer cells SK-OV-3 showed two complexes with Na and Mg to be quite active: the one with K possessed moderate activity. Complexes with Zn and Li demonstrated less activity than others what was explained by the different bond angles between carbon atoms 1–1a–12a–12 from that for colchicine (1). In colchicine, the two aromatic rings are twisted, making a dihedral angle of ∼54°. This inherent aR configuration of the chiral axis (Figure 19) is crucial for its binding to tubulin,(45) and any deviation leads to a decrease in activity for complexes of such type.

    Hybrids, Conjugates, and Prodrugs of Colchicinoids: Colchicinoid Delivery Systems

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The creation of hybrid drugs, prodrugs, and nanoscale delivery systems represents a rapidly developing area of modern medical chemistry. Hybrid drugs are aimed at exploiting more than one mechanism to affect a pathological process. Concerning cancer, it is possible to influence cellular signaling pathways, the functioning of DNA, the regulation of the cell cycle, apoptosis, and/or angiogenesis.(178) The generation of a prodrug by changing the structure of an active compound allows for the modification of the ADMET characteristics.(179) As an example, modern nanostructured materials allow the delivery of drugs to specific target sites with a reduced dosage frequency in a controlled manner to suppress side effects experienced with traditional therapies. In particular, this approach can resolve some main critical problems encountered with conventional pharmaceutical treatments, such as nonspecific distribution, rapid clearance, uncontrollable release, and a low bioavailability of the drug.(180) Accordingly, a variety of colchicine prodrugs, codrugs, hybrid drugs, conjugates, and nanoformulations have been developed as summarized in by Ghawanmeh in a review from 2017.(181) Herein, we thus only highlight the recent progress in this field.
    An example of a hybrid molecule with a bidirectional biological effect is colchifulvin(182) (202), a hybrid of colchicine (1), and the antifungal antibiotic griseofulvin (203) (Figure 20).
    Despite the fact that the synthesized hybrid is structurally derived from two biologically active molecules,(183) colchifulvin does not interact with tubulin and possesses only a low cytotoxic activity (≥100 μM).
    A number of colchicine–adamantane conjugates of type 204(184−188) with ester linkers of varying length were synthesized using EEDQ (N-ethoxycarbonyl-2-ethoxy-1,2-dihydroquinoline) as a reagent (Scheme 28). These compounds were shown to exhibit cytotoxic activity at low nanomolar concentrations. The most active derivatives included a linker with five or six CH2 units, and compounds with shorter or longer linkers showed a significantly decreased cytotoxic activity (by 2–3 orders of magnitude). It was also found that a decrease in activity is observed when polar groups are introduced into the adamantyl fragment. The presence of bulky hydrophobic fragments, on the contrary, leads to an increase in cytotoxicity of the conjugate. This indicates the adamantyl fragment to address a large hydrophobic pocket, located mainly in the tubulin α-subunit, and also may explain the ability of these derivatives to cause clustering of protein heterodimers.
    In order to increase the bioavailability, two novel colchicinoid-containing phospholipid prodrugs (205 and 206) encapsulated into phosphatidylcholine-based enzyme-responsive liposomes were prepared (Scheme 29). The idea of the delivery system of such type is based on the increased levels of enzymes in pathological tissues. The prodrugs synthesized induce minimal distortions of lipid packing, and the corresponding liposomes were found to be stable in human serum. At the same time, being exposed to elevated levels of phospholipases A2, especially in the case of an sPLA2 analogue, the liposomes release colchicinoid-containing fatty acids. The latter undergo further hydrolysis by nonspecific esterases to release the active colchicinoid species. Noteworthy, the colchicinoid agents exhibited outstanding antiproliferative activity in the low nanomolar concentration range.(189)
    Recent studies indicate that tubulin can act as a host factor for vector-borne flaviviruses, like dengue (DENV) and Zika (ZIKV), and inhibitors of tubulin polymerization such as colchicine were demonstrated to decrease virus replication. With this in mind, a group of derivatives (compounds 212–218) with a hCE1-sensitive (human carboxylesterase-1) structural motif were prepared (Scheme 30). All of these prodrugs containing a leucine ester were hydrolyzed by the esterase in vitro. The prodrugs 212 and 215 were shown to exhibit antiviral activity against DENV and ZIKV (Scheme 30) in cell culture at low micromolar and submicromolar concentrations, while being much less toxic than the parent colchicinoids. In addition, the authors found that tubulin binding is not the only mechanism of antiviral activity of the new derivatives and that the hCE1 selective motif does not influence the toxicity.(190)
    As new furano-allocolchicine, the chitosan conjugate (221) was synthesized by fusing the succinic acid-modified furano-allocolchicine 188 with biodegradable and nontoxic polysaccharide chitosan of medium molecular weight(191) (Figure 21). Both compounds, 188 and the chitosan conjugate 221, induced in vitro tubulin reorganization, cell cycle arrest, and inhibition of cell proliferation in 2D and 3D cell cultures. Studies carried out employing Wnt-1 breast tumor-bearing mice showed that the conjugate 221 demonstrated a significantly stronger tumor growth inhibition than 188, possibly as a result of a better accumulation in the tumor due to an “enhanced permeability and retention effect”.
    Antibody–drug conjugates represent a powerful class of therapeutic agents in oncology. These agents generally bind to a specific cell surface receptor before the cytotoxic payload is released to cause cell death. The possibility of triggering the cytotoxicity of an antibody by coadministration with an endosome-disruptive peptide of low toxicity was demonstrated by Peterson et al.(192) This approach was realized by conjugation of NCME (4) to lysine residues of the HER2-targeting antibody trastuzumab (Herceptin) via a disulfide bond. Upon binding of the resulting antibody–colchicine conjugate 222 to HER2 on SKBR3 breast cancer cells, endocytosis occurs, the membrane-impermeable cytotoxin is released but trapped in endosomes, resulting in relatively low cytotoxicity (IC50 > 1 μM). However, coadministration with the nontoxic cholesterol-linked endosome-disruptive peptide Chol-EDP (223) promoted the release of this small molecule into the cytoplasm, conferring subnanomolar cytotoxic potency (IC50 = 0.11 ± 0.07 nM) (Figure 22).
    Recently, Darwis et al. reported colchicine-loaded transethosomes incorporated into the Carbopol 940 gel base for transdermal delivery of colchicine to overcome its poor bioavailability and the severe gastrointestinal side effects encountered upon oral administration.(193) All of the formulated gels exhibited non-Newtonian plastic flow without thixotropy. Colchicine-loaded transethosomal gels were able to significantly enhance the skin permeation parameters of the drug in comparison to the nonethosomal gel.
    Another gel-based delivery system of colchicine was proposed by Chen et al. as the vehicle for myocardial repair after infarction while minimizing its systemic toxicity.(194) After intramyocardial injection, the thermosensitive poly(lactide-co-glycolide)-poly(ethylene glycol)-poly(lactide-co-glycolide) (PLGA–PEG-PLGA) polymer hydrogel ([email protected]) released colchicine in a sustained manner over an 8-day period. In contrast with the intraperitoneal injection of colchicine solution, this drug effectively alleviated cardiac inflammation, inhibited myocardial apoptosis and fibrosis, improved cardiac function and structure, and increased mouse survival with negligible systemic side effects, what makes it a potential drug for promoting tissue repair after myocardial infarction.
    Considering borneol (BO) as an excellent penetration enhancer in Chinese medicine, which can promote the entry of drugs into the skin, Zhang et al. prepared the borneol-physically modified colchicine ethosome (COL-bpES) and used the prepared borneol-dioleoyl phosphoethanloamine (BO–DOPE) to obtain borneol-chemically modified colchicine ethosome (COL-bcES).(195) Compared to the free colchicine aqueous solution (free COL) and normal colchicine ethosome (COL-ES), the borneol-modified colchicine ethosome (COL-bES) exhibited a better drug penetration effect, while the particle size of the COL-bcES was smaller than that of the COL-bpES. Toxicity, in vitro diffusion, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics were superior to those of COL-bpES, providing a better delivery system for the treatment of small-molecule inflammatory drugs.
    A treatment approach for glioblastoma multiforme with theranostic nanoparticles (TNPs) in mouse models developed and validated in 2010 by Gill and coauthors(196) now evolved to a new strategy of combining TNPs with radiotherapy.(197) TNPs are composed of FDA-approved cross-linked iron oxide nanoparticles and the highly effective vascular disrupting agent azademethylcolchicine (ICT2552). Nanoparticles and ICT2552 are linked through a Matrix metalloproteinase 14 (MMP-14) cleavable linker to afford ICT2588 (224, Figure 23), the MMP-14 activatable theranostic drug. Intravenous treatment with theranostic nanoparticles enhanced the efficacy of ionizing radiation for the treatment of glioblastoma in mouse models, with limited toxicity to the normal brain or visceral organs and simultaneously enabled in vivo drug tracking with MRI. Considering the urgent need for new therapies against glioblastoma, this new combination therapy provides a promising option for the treatment of this deadliest neoplasm. Further studies to enable the clinical translation of the drug are underway.
    To address problems arising from prodrug hydrophobicity and nontarget-specific delivery to cancer cell organelles, AbouAitah et al. investigated readily available nanoformulations consisting of amine-functionalized mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) conjugated with folic acid.(198) MSNs were used as vehicles to transport the prodrugs, including colchicine, into HepG2 cancer cells. In comparison to nonconjugated MSNs, the resulting systems displayed a higher free radical scavenging activity, improved cellular uptake, sustained intracellular release, and higher cytotoxicity effects. Further investigations have led to the MSNs, functionalized with phosphonate groups and coated with the folic acid chitosan-glycine complex.(199) The resulting nanoformulation, loaded with colchicine (MSNsPCOL/CG-FA), was tested against cancer and normal cell lines. The anticancer effect was highly enhanced for MSNsPCOL/CG-FA, compared to colchicine in the case of HCT116 (colon cancer), HepG2 (liver cancer), and PC3 (prostate cancer); meanwhile, cytotoxicity was much lower in BJ1 normal cells (4% compared to ∼60% for colchicine). The mechanism of action was primarily apoptosis caused by mitotic spindle disruption. Furthermore, a contribution of genetic regulation (metastasis-associated lung adenocarcinoma transcript 1 and microRNA) and immunotherapy effects (angiopoietin-2) and programmed cell death protein 1 was found. Therefore, this study showed a novel method of developing cancer immunotherapy using an old-known natural product.

    Summary and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Colchicine is a prominent and fascinating natural product, which, due to its ready availability and its powerful biological properties, continues to receive much attention as a drug and a promising drug lead. Besides being clinically used in the treatment of gout and certain types of inflammation, colchicine and structural analogues were also identified as effective agents against several other diseases including dermatological and cardiovascular disorders.
    Due to its strong antimitotic (tubulin-binding) properties, colchicinoids also represent potential anticancer drugs, especially against drug-resistant cancers because their effectiveness was found to be independent of the isomorphic composition of β-tubulin. However, the application of colchicine itself as a chemotherapeutic anticancer drug is hampered by its high nonspecific toxicity at the required high doses. Among the other effects of colchicine on tumor tissues are inhibition of cancer cell migration and decreasing their metastatic potential,(200) disruption of Rho/Rho effector kinase (ROCK)/myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) pathway,(201) inhibition of angiogenesis,(202) inhibition of ATP consumption by mitochondria,(203) as well as the release of caspases and cytochrome C, leading to apoptosis of malignant cells.(204) Therefore, the effect of new colchicinoids on malignant tumors can potentially be mediated by a number of ways, independent of the interaction with tubulin, which may be devoid of nonspecific side effects of colchicine itself.
    Many new derivatives and analogues of colchicine have been synthesized and tested against different cancer cell lines; many of them showing promising results. Scientists still continue to design and synthesize new colchicinoids in their search for improved anticancer agents to be used in traditional chemotherapy. A still open question is how the particularly strong binding of colchicine toward tubulin and possibly other target proteins can be explained. It appears that a subtle combination of conformational preferences (associated with the axial chirality) with other structural features (pharmacophoric groups, size of the molecule, etc.) defines the activity of colchicinoids. Therefore, the investigation of conformational dynamics and the correlation of these characteristics with biological properties deserves further attention. A deeper understanding of the mechanism of action could open options for new therapeutic applications of colchicinoids in the future.
    In the age of targeted therapy, new techniques have been utilized to improve the pharmaceutical properties of colchicinoids, such as solubility or bioavailability. Noteworthy are attempts to extend the therapeutic potential of the drugs by selective tumor targeting, i.e., by conjugating them with macromolecules (antibodies, polysaccharides, serum proteins, peptides, growth factors, and synthetic polymers), or by incorporation into micelles or liposomes. Exploiting specific characteristics of cancer cells, new effective delivery systems are currently explored to achieve selective inhibition of cancer cells without harming other cells. Besides the use of selective delivery systems to develop colchicinoids with a reduced general toxicity, the future of colchicinoids may also arise from their combination with immunotherapy as several studies suggest that agents interfering with microtubule assembly can enhance the body’s immune response.(34,199) Beside the interactions with microtubules, colchicine influences the neutrophil chemotaxis, adhesion and mobilization, superoxide production in addition to inhibition of NACHT-LRRPYD-containing protein 3 (NALP3) inflammasomes, and interleukins processing and release. A mechanistic understanding of how specific colchicinoids enhance immunotherapeutic agents in different tumor environments will eventually allow the development of effective cancer therapies in individual patients (personalized medicine).
    This Perspective aims at providing the reader an overview of the various and powerful options for the chemical synthesis of colchicinoids developed in recent years. Moreover, the biological activity of the synthetic colchicinoids is discussed, with a special focus on the suppression of undesirable side effects and the improvement of pharmacological and pharmacokinetic characteristics of the compounds. Having made an attempt to do a comprehensive overview, we apologize to colleagues whose research could not be included in this Perspective due to space limitations. Taking a look at the road traveled in the history of colchicine derivatives, it can be concluded that investigation of the majority of the compounds discovered or synthesized was stopped at the stage of basic antimitotic activity tests. Comprehensive in vitro and in vivo preclinical studies, and in several cases, a transition to clinical studies are needed to make progress for the official use of colchicine derivatives in medicine. Also, considering recent advances in assay technology and the monitoring of patients, there is a real chance that new colchicine-derived drugs will find their way to the market in the future. We hope that the present Perspective will stimulate further investigations in this area.

    1. 1
      Koehn, F. E.; Carter, G. T. The Evolving Role of Natural Products in Drug Discovery. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2005, 4, 206– 220,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd1657
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      The evolving role of natural products in drug discovery
      Koehn, Frank E.; Carter, Guy T.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2005), 4 (3), 206-220CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Natural products and their derivs. have historically been invaluable as a source of therapeutic agents. However, in the past decade, research into natural products in the pharmaceutical industry has declined, owing to issues such as the lack of compatibility of traditional natural-product ext. libraries with high-throughput screening. However, as discussed in this review, recent technol. advances that help to address these issues, coupled with unrealized expectations from current lead-generation strategies, have led to a renewed interest in natural products in drug discovery.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhslSnsrg%253D&md5=ce80052abaa76430220ee5981138053e
    2. 2
      Newman, D. J.; Cragg, G. M. Natural Products as Sources of New Drugs over the Nearly Four Decades from 01/1981 to 09/2019. J. Nat. Prod. 2020, 83, 770– 803,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jnatprod.9b01285
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Natural Products as Sources of New Drugs over the Nearly Four Decades from 01/1981 to 09/2019
      Newman, David J.; Cragg, Gordon M.
      Journal of Natural Products (2020), 83 (3), 770-803CODEN: JNPRDF; ISSN:0163-3864. (American Chemical Society-American Society of Pharmacognosy)
      This review is an updated and expanded version of the five prior reviews that were published in this journal in 1997, 2003, 2007, 2012, and 2016. For all approved therapeutic agents, the time frame has been extended to cover the almost 39 years from the first of Jan. 1981 to the 30th of Sept. 2019 for all diseases worldwide and from ∼1946 (earliest so far identified) to the 30th of Sept. 2019 for all approved antitumor drugs worldwide. As in earlier reviews, only the first approval of any drug is counted, irresp. of how many "biosimilars" or added approvals were subsequently identified. As in the 2012 and 2016 reviews, we have continued to utilize our secondary subdivision of a "natural product mimic", or "NM", to join the original primary divisions, and the designation "natural product botanical", or "NB", to cover those botanical "defined mixts." now recognized as drug entities by the FDA (and similar organizations). From the data presented in this review, the utilization of natural products and/or synthetic variations using their novel structures, in order to discover and develop the final drug entity, is still alive and well. For example, in the area of cancer, over the time frame from 1946 to 1980, of the 75 small mols., 40, or 53.3%, are N or ND. In the 1981 to date time frame the equiv. figures for the N* compds. of the 185 small mols. are 62, or 33.5%, though to these can be added the 58 S* and S*/NMs, bringing the figure to 64.9%. In other areas, the influence of natural product structures is quite marked with, as expected from prior information, the anti-infective area being dependent on natural products and their structures, though as can be seen in the review there are still disease areas (shown in Table 2) for which there are no drugs derived from natural products. Although combinatorial chem. techniques have succeeded as methods of optimizing structures and have been used very successfully in the optimization of many recently approved agents, we are still able to identify only two de novo combinatorial compds. (one of which is a little speculative) approved as drugs in this 39-yr time frame, though there is also one drug that was developed using the "fragment-binding methodol." and approved in 2012. We have also added a discussion of candidate drug entities currently in clin. trials as "warheads" and some very interesting preliminary reports on sources of novel antibiotics from Nature due to the abs. requirement for new agents to combat plasmid-borne resistance genes now in the general populace. We continue to draw the attention of readers to the recognition that a significant no. of natural product drugs/leads are actually produced by microbes and/or microbial interactions with the "host from whence it was isolated"; thus we consider that this area of natural product research should be expanded significantly.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXks1Cmsrw%253D&md5=2c10c2aef98042d8bd772b6280b51d2b

    7. 7
      Borisy, G. G.; Taylor, E. W. The Mechanism of Action of Colchicine. J. Cell Biol. 1967, 34, 535– 548,  DOI: 10.1083/jcb.34.2.535
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      The mechanism of action of colchicine. Colchicine binding to sea urchin eggs and the mitotic apparatus
      Borisy, G. G.; Taylor, Edwin William
      Journal of Cell Biology (1967), 34 (2), 535-48CODEN: JCLBA3; ISSN:0021-9525.
      Colchicine forms a complex in vivo with a protein present in fertilized or unfertilized sea urchin eggs; similar binding was obtained in vitro with the sol. fraction from egg homogenates. Kinetic parameters and binding equilibrium const. were essentially the same in vivo and in vitro. The binding site protein was shown to have a sedimentation const. of 6S by zone centrifugation. The protein was present in exts. of the isolated mitotic apparatus at a concn. which was several times higher than in whole-egg homogenates. It was extd. from the mitotic apparatus at low ionic strength under conditions which lead to the disappearance of microtubules. No binding could be detected to the 27S protein, which is a major protein component of the isolated mitotic apparatus. The properties of the colchicine-binding protein, (binding const., sedimentation const., Sephadex elution vol.) are similar to those obtained with the protein from mammalian cells, sea urchin sperm tails, and brain tissue, and thus support the conclusion that the protein is a subunit of microtubules. 23 references.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF2sXks1Wqsb8%253D&md5=b411e7424152d1e710bdaa1b05186dae
    8. 8
      Slobodnick, A.; Shah, B.; Krasnokutsky, S.; Pillinger, M. H. Update on Colchicine, 2017. Rheumatology 2018, 57, i4– i11,  DOI: 10.1093/rheumatology/kex453
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Update on colchicine, 2017
      Slobodnick, Anastasia; Shah, Binita; Krasnokutsky, Svetlana; Pillinger, Michael H.
      Rheumatology (Oxford, United Kingdom) (2018), 57 (suppl_1), i4-i11CODEN: RUMAFK; ISSN:1462-0332. (Oxford University Press)
      A review. Colchicine is an ancient medication that is currently approved for the treatment of gout and FMF. However, colchicine has a wide range of anti-inflammatory activities, and studies indicate that it may be beneficial in a variety of other conditions. This paper reviews the evidence for the well-established use of colchicine in gout, as well as several other rheumatic diseases. In addn., we highlight the potential benefit of colchicine in cardiac disease, including coronary artery disease in patients both with and without gout.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXpslyisrg%253D&md5=ead96d22a63f294ca657b2f18ecbb81d
    9. 9
      Mandhare, A.; Banerjee, P. Therapeutic Use of Colchicine and Its Derivatives: A Patent Review. Expert Opin. Ther. Pat. 2016, 26, 1157– 1174,  DOI: 10.1080/13543776.2016.1214268
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Therapeutic use of colchicine and its derivatives: a patent review
      Mandhare, Anita; Banerjee, Paromita
      Expert Opinion on Therapeutic Patents (2016), 26 (10), 1157-1174CODEN: EOTPEG; ISSN:1354-3776. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
      Colchicine, the major alkaloid extd. from the meadow saffron (Colchicum autumnale) is one of the most prominent natural products belonging to the class of org. compds. known as tropones. Colchicine's medicinal properties have been long-known, but it has been attracting renewed attention due to its action as an antimitotic agent. This review presents an update and anal. of the patents claiming therapeutic activity of colchicine and its derivs. published in the last five years (2010-2015). Other patents claiming the application of colchicine in the areas of biotechnol., veterinary, and agriculture are therefore excluded from this review. Rapid increase in the no. of publications and patent filings in recent years for the significant therapeutic potential of colchicine, for several conditions beyond gout, clearly indicates the growing interest of research on this mol. Although the mol. structure of colchicine fulfils the four Lipinski's requisites for high oral bioavailability, the toxic side effects resulting from its fast metab. need to be assessed. Further efforts are therefore required to explore the appropriate dosage and possible administration techniques of colchicine for practical use.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xht1Gltr%252FE&md5=80aa4fa2846ebf59843a572ac95659a6
    10. 10
      Slobodnick, A.; Shah, B.; Pillinger, M. H.; Krasnokutsky, S. Colchicine: Old and New. Am. J. Med. 2015, 128, 461– 470,  DOI: 10.1016/j.amjmed.2014.12.010
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Colchicine: Old and New
      Slobodnick, Anastasia; Shah, Binita; Pillinger, Michael H.; Krasnokutsky, Svetlana
      American Journal of Medicine (2015), 128 (5), 461-470CODEN: AJMEAZ; ISSN:0002-9343. (Elsevier)
      Although colchicine has been a focus of research, debate, and controversy for thousands of years, the US Food and Drug Administration just approved it in 2009. Over the past decade, advances in the knowledge of colchicine pharmacol., drug safety, and mechanisms of action have led to changes in colchicine dosing and to potential new uses for this very old drug. In this review, we discuss the pharmacol. properties of colchicine and summarize what is currently known about its mechanisms of action. We then discuss and update the use of colchicine in a variety of illnesses, including rheumatic and, most recently, cardiovascular diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXktVChtLc%253D&md5=085cb6dcbfa84a9663b80da1428f0f3a
