      Reuter, S.; Prasad, S.; Phromnoi, K.; Ravindran, J.; Sung, B.; Yadav, V. R.; Kannappan, R.; Chaturvedi, M. M.; Aggarwal, B. B. Thiocolchicoside Exhibits Anticancer Effects through Downregulation of NF-κB Pathway and Its Regulated Gene Products Linked to Inflammation and Cancer. Cancer Prev. Res. 2010, 3, 1462– 1472,  DOI: 10.1158/1940-6207.CAPR-10-0037
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      61
      Thiocolchicoside exhibits anticancer effects through downregulation of NF-κB pathway and its regulated gene products linked to inflammation and cancer
      Reuter, Simone; Prasad, Sahdeo; Phromnoi, Kanokkam; Ravindran, Jayaraj; Sung, Bokyung; Yadav, Vivek R.; Kannappan, Ramaswamy; Chaturvedi, Madan M.; Aggarwal, Bharat B.
      Cancer Prevention Research (2010), 3 (11), 1462-1472CODEN: CPRACC; ISSN:1940-6207. (American Association of Cancer Research)
      The discovery of new uses for older, clin. approved drugs is one way to expedite drug development for cancer. Thiocolchicoside, a semisynthetic colchicoside from the plant Gloriosa superba, is a muscle relaxant and used to treat rheumatol. and orthopedic disorders because of its analgesic and anti-inflammatory mechanisms. Given that activation of the transcription factor NF-κB plays a major role in inflammation and tumorigenesis, we postulated that thiocolchicoside would inhibit NF-κB and exhibit anticancer effects through the modulation of NF-κB-regulated proteins. We show that thiocolchicoside inhibited proliferation of leukemia, myeloma, squamous cell carcinoma, breast, colon, and kidney cancer cells. Formation of tumor colonies was also suppressed by thiocolchicoside. The colchicoside induced apoptosis, as indicated by caspase-3 and poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase cleavage, and suppressed the expression of cell survival [e.g., Bd-2, X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis (XIAP), MCL-1, bcl-xL, cIAP-1, cIAP-2, and cFLIP] proteins. Cell proliferation biomarkers such as c-MYC and phosphorylation of phosphoinositide 3-kinase and glycogen synthase kinase 3β were also blocked by thiocolchicoside. Because most cell survival and proliferation gene products are regulated by NF-κB, we studied the effect of thiocolchicoside on this transcription factor and found that thiocolchicoside inhibited NF-κB activation, degrdn. of inhibitory κBα (IκBα), IκBα ubiquitination, and phosphorylation, abolished the activation of IκBα kinase, and suppressed p65 nuclear translocation. This effect of thiocolchicoside on the NF-κB pathway led to inhibition of NF-κB reporter activity and cyclooxygenase-2 promoter activity. Our results indicate that thiocolchicoside exhibits anticancer activity through inhibition of NF-κB and NF-κB-regulated gene products, which provides novel insight into a half-century old drug.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhs1Wrsr7K&md5=37c37d2770ba1f1c30424cd712036655
    62. 62
      Biziere, K.; Huguet, F.; Narcisse, G.; Breteau, M. Affinity of Thiocolchicoside and Thiocolchicoside Analogues for the Postsynaptic GABA Receptor Site. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1981, 75, 167– 168,  DOI: 10.1016/0014-2999(81)90080-7

      62
      Affinity of thiocolchicoside and thiocolchicoside analogs for the postsynaptic GABA receptor site
      Biziere, Kathleen; Huguet, Francois; Narcisse, Guy; Breteau, Michel
      European Journal of Pharmacology (1981), 75 (2-3), 167-8CODEN: EJPHAZ; ISSN:0014-2999.
      thiocolchicoside (I) [602-41-5] inhibited the binding of GABA [56-12-2] to its receptors on rat cortical membranes and antagonized picrotoxin-induced seizures in mice, suggesting that I acts as a postsynaptic GABA agonist. The structural analogs colchicoside [477-29-2] and colchicine [64-86-8] were without either biol. activity, although portions of the A and B rings of all 3 compds. resembled the GABA structure. The presence of a Me sulfide group at one end of this structural sequence may be important for the GABAergic properties of I, since this was replaced by a methoxy group in the inactive colchicoside and colchicine.

      Huzil, J. T.; Mane, J.; Tuszynski, J. A. Computer Assisted Design of Second-Generation Colchicine Derivatives. Interdiscip. Sci.: Comput. Life Sci. 2010, 2, 169– 174,  DOI: 10.1007/s12539-010-0076-z
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      66
      Computer assisted design of second-generation colchicine derivatives
      Huzil, J. Torin; Mane, Jonathan; Tuszynski, Jack A.
      Interdisciplinary Sciences: Computational Life Sciences (2010), 2 (2), 169-174CODEN: ISCLAL; ISSN:1913-2751. (Springer)
      Cytoskeletal proteins, such as tubulin, are a primary target for many successful anti-cancer drugs. The expression of several β-tubulin isotypes in normal and cancerous cells provides a platform upon which to construct chemotherapeutic agents capable of differentiating between them. To test this hypothesis, we have previously designed several colchicine derivs. and computationally probed them for affinity to the β-tubulin isotypes. Subsequent synthesis and cytotoxicity assays produced a small set of promising compds. exhibiting IC50 values approx. 30 fold lower than values previously reported for colchicine. Here we describe the creation and testing of these first-generation colchicine derivs. and discuss the subsequent design and preliminary computational screening of a novel set of second-generation derivs. using the most promising first-generation derivs. as scaffolds.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXlsFagtbk%253D&md5=dc30746a299b63d0a3d3abc51692ec85

      Computational design and biological testing of highly cytotoxic colchicine ring a modifications
      Huzil, John Torin; Winter, Philip; Johnson, Lorelei; Weis, Alexander L.; Bakos, Tamas; Banerjee, Asok; Luduena, Richard F.; Damaraju, Sambasivarao; Tuszynski, Jack A.
      Chemical Biology & Drug Design (2010), 75 (6), 541-550CODEN: CBDDAL; ISSN:1747-0277. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      Microtubules are the primary target for many anti-cancer drugs, the majority of which bind specifically to β-tubulin. The existence of several β-tubulin isotypes, coupled with their varied expression in normal and cancerous cells provides a platform upon which to construct selective chemotherapeutic agents. We have examd. five prevalent human β-tubulin isotypes and identified the colchicine-binding site as the most promising for drug design based on specificity. Using this binding site as a template, we have designed several colchicine derivs. and computationally probed them for affinity to the β-tubulin isotypes. These compds. were synthesized and subjected to cytotoxicity assays to det. their effectiveness against several cancerous cell lines. We obsd. a correlation between computational-binding predictions and exptl. detd. IC50 values, demonstrating the utility of computational screening in the design of more effective colchicine derivs. The most promising deriv. exhibited an IC50 approx. threefold lower than values previously reported for either colchicine or paclitaxel, demonstrating the utility of computational design and assessment of binding to tubulin.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Synthesis and antiproliferative screening of novel analogs of regioselectively demethylated colchicine and thiocolchicine
      Czerwonka, Dominika; Sobczak, Szymon; Maj, Ewa; Wietrzyk, Joanna; Katrusiak, Andrzej; Huczynski, Adam
      Molecules (2020), 25 (5), 1180CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
      Colchicine, a pseudoalkaloid isolated from Colchicum autumnale was identified as a potent anticancer agent because of its strong antimitotic activity. It was showed that colchicine modifications by regioselective demethylation affected its biol. properties. For demethylated colchicine analogs, 10-demethylcolchicine and 1-demethylthiocolchicine a series of 12 colchicine derivs. I and II [R = Me, Et, i-Pr, etc] including 5 novel esters and 4 carbonates I [R = Et, i-Pr, OMe, OEt] and II [R = Et, Ph, OMe, OEt] were synthesized. The antiproliferative activity assay together with in-silico evaluation of physicochem. properties, confirmed attractive biol. profiles for all obtained compds I and II. The substitutions of H-donor and H-acceptor sites at C1 in thiocolchicine position provide an efficient control of the hydration affinity and soly., as demonstrated for anhydrate, hemihydrate and monohydrate.

      Majcher, U.; Klejborowska, G.; Moshari, M.; Maj, E.; Wietrzyk, J.; Bartl, F.; Tuszynski, J. A.; Huczyński, A. Antiproliferative Activity and Molecular Docking of Novel Double-Modified Colchicine Derivatives. Cells 2018, 7, 192– 208,  DOI: 10.3390/cells7110192

      72
      Antiproliferative activity and molecular docking of novel double-modified colchicine derivatives
      Majcher, Urszula; Klejborowska, Greta; Moshari, Mahshad; Maj, Ewa; Wietrzyk, Joanna; Bartl, Franz; Tuszynski, Jack A.; Huczynski, Adam
      Cells (2018), 7 (11), 192CODEN: CELLC6; ISSN:2073-4409. (MDPI AG)
      Microtubules are tubulin polymer structures, which are indispensable for cell growth and division. Its constituent protein β-tubulin has been a common drug target for various diseases including cancer. Colchicine has been used to treat gout, but it has also been an investigational anticancer agent with a known antimitotic effect on cells. However, the use of colchicine as well as many of its derivs. in long-term treatment is hampered by their high toxicity. To create more potent anticancer agents, three novel double-modified colchicine derivs. have been obtained by structural modifications in C-4 and C-10 positions. The binding affinities of these derivs. of colchicine with respect to eight different isotypes of human β-tubulin have been calcd. using docking methods. In vitro cytotoxicity has been evaluated against four human tumor cell lines (A549, MCF-7, LoVo and LoVo/DX). Computer simulations predicted the binding modes of these compds. and hence the key residues involved in the interactions between tubulin and the colchicine derivs. Two of the obtained derivs., 4-bromothiocolchicine and 4-iodothiocolchicine, were shown to be active against three of the investigated cancer cell lines (A549, MCF-7, LoVo) with potency at nanomolar concns. and a higher relative affinity to tumor cells over normal cells.

      Pyles, E. A.; Hastie, S. B. Effect of the B Ring and the C-7 Substituent on the Kinetics of Colchicinoid-Tubulin Associations. Biochemistry 1993, 32, 2329– 2336,  DOI: 10.1021/bi00060a026
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      74
      Effect of the B ring and the C-7 substituent on the kinetics of colchicinoid-tubulin associations
      Pyles, Erica A.; Hastie, Susan Bane
      Biochemistry (1993), 32 (9), 2329-36CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960.
      The kinetics of four B-ring derivs. of colchicine binding to tubulin has been examd. quant. The binding of deacetoamidocolchicine, deacetylcolchicine, demecolcine, and N-methyldemecolcine to tubulin were biphasic processes. The assocn. rate consts. were detd. as a function of temp., and the thermodn. parameters for the transition states of the fast phase were calcd. The kinetic parameters for the formation of the deacetylcolchicine-tubulin, demecolcine-tubulin, and N-methyldemecolcine-tubulin complexes were very similar to each other, but different from the parameters for the colchicine-tubulin assocn. In particular, the global activation enthalpies for the formation of the three aminocolchicinoid-tubulin complexes were 3-5 kcal/mol greater than the global activation enthalpy of colchicine binding to tubulin. These results indicate that electronic rather than steric properties of the B-ring substituent are of greater importance in the activation enthalpy of colchicinoids binding to tubulin. In contrast, the global activation enthalpy for deacetamidocolchicine, which lacks a substituent on the C-7 carbon, binding to tubulin was virtually identical to the global activation enthalpy previously found for the colchicine analog that lacks the B ring, 2-methoxy-5-(2,3,4-trimethoxyphenyl)tropone, binding to tubulin (Bane et al., 1984). This result demonstrates that the carbons of the B ring are not involved in the transition state for the formation of colchicinoid-tubulin complexes. The first-order dissocn. rate consts. of the colchicinoid-tubulin complexes were detd. at 37°. The dissocn. profiles of the colchicinoid-tubulin complexes also consisted of two phases. The equil. consts. for the two kinetic phases were detd. from the rate consts. for each ligand at 37°. The equil. consts. for each kinetic phase of the aminocolchicinoid-tubulin complexes were indistinguishable within exptl. error. The equil. consts. for two kinetic phases of the deacetamidocolchicine-tubulin complex differed by up to a factor or 4 and were in reasonably good agreement with the equil. const. previously found for the assocn. by equil. methods (Choudhury et al., 1983). It is concluded that tubulin heterogeneity with respect to colchicinoid binding may be detected by kinetic means but is unlikely to be obsd. in unfractionated tubulin using equil. methods.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXhs1Smtrk%253D&md5=3a8e7f1a373b1d71d0ac0a8a1673c8ee
    75. 75
      Kumar, A.; Sharma, P. R.; Mondhe, D. M. Potential Anticancer Role of Colchicine-Based Derivatives. Anti-Cancer Drugs 2017, 28, 250– 262,  DOI: 10.1097/CAD.0000000000000464
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      75
      Potential anticancer role of colchicine-based derivatives: an overview
      Kumar, Ashok; Sharma, Parduman R.; Mondhe, Dilip M.
      Anti-Cancer Drugs (2017), 28 (3), 250-262CODEN: ANTDEV; ISSN:0959-4973. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      Colchicine, the main alkaloid of the poisonous plant meadow saffron (Colchicum autumnale L.), is a classical drug used for the treatment of gout and familial Mediterranean fever. Although colchicine is not clin. used to treat cancer because of toxicity, it exerts antiproliferative effects through the inhibition of microtubule formation by blocking the cell cycle at the G2/M phase and triggering apoptosis. Colchicine can still be used as a lead compd. for the generation of potential anticancer drugs. Thus, numerous analogs of colchicine have been synthesized in the hope of developing novel, useful drugs with more favorable pharmacol. profiles. Several colchicine semisynthetics are less toxic than colchicine and research is being carried out on effective, less toxic colchicine semisynthetic formulations with potential drug-delivery strategies directly targeting multiple solid cancers. This review focuses on the anticancer role of some of colchicine-based derivs. and their therapeutic importance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXislSqt7k%253D&md5=f1b663c193fa981e3025b66a9bb260d3
    76. 76
      Sun, L.; McPhail, A. T.; Hamel, E.; Lin, C. M.; Hastie, S. B.; Chang, J. J.; Lee, K. H. Antitumor Agents. 139. Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Thiocolchicine Analogs 5,6-Dihydro-6(S)-acyloxy)- and 5,6-Dihydro-6(S)-[(aroyloxy)methyl]-1,2,3-trimethoxy-9-(methylthio)-8H-cyclohepta[a]naphthalen-8-ones as Novel Cytotoxic and Antimitotic Agents. J. Med. Chem. 1993, 36, 544– 551,  DOI: 10.1021/jm00057a004
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      76
      Antitumor agents. 139. Synthesis and biological evaluation of thiocolchicine analogs 5,6-dihydro-6(S)-acyloxy)- and 5,6-dihydro-6(S)-[(aroyloxy)methyl]-1,2,3-trimethoxy-9-(methylthio)-8H-cyclohepta[a]naphthalen-8-ones as novel cytotoxic and antimitotic agents
      Sun, Li; McPhail, Andrew T.; Hamel, Ernest; Lin, Chii M.; Hastie, Susan B.; Chang, Jer Jang; Lee, Kuo Hsiung
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1993), 36 (5), 544-51CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
      A series of novel thiocolchicine analogs, 5,6-dihydro-6(S)-(acyloxy)- and 5,6-dihydro-6(S)-[(aroyloxy)-methyl]-1,2,3-trimethoxy-9-(methylthio)-8H-cyclohepata[a]naphthalen-8-one, possessing a six-membered ring B, were synthesized and evaluated for their cytotoxicity against various tumor cell lines, including solid tumor cell lines, and for their interaction with tubulin. The configuration of the parent alc. I (R = H) was established unequivocally as (aR,6S) by x-ray crystallog. anal. The side chain at the C(6) position is in a pseudoaxial orientation. The optical properties and 1H NMR data indicated that these compds. have the same conformations in soln. as in the solid state. Biol. results showed that compds. I (R = H, MeCO, PrCO, EtO2C, EtCO) and II bearing a small side chain at C(6) demonstrate high potency in inhibiting tubulin polymn. and binding of radiolabeled colchicine to tubulin. The most cytotoxic compds. were I (R = PrCO, EtO2C, EtCO) and II, with good activity against several solid tumor cell lines. To explain the strong antitubulin activity of compd. I (R= H) (with an aR configured biaryl system in contrast to the aS configuration previously described for colchicinoids, allocolchicinoids, and steganacin) a rapid atropisomerase equil. must exist for I (R= H) and its active derivs. This equil. would yield adequate amts. of aS-configured conformers that interact strongly with tubulin. Since the optically inactive II is also a potent inhibitor of tubulin, the configuration of the side chain of these six-membered ring B analogs cannot be essential for their binding to tubulin. The size of ring B and of its side chain play important roles in tubulin binding activity by affecting the rotation of the rings A and C along their linking C-C bond axis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXht1Crsbw%253D&md5=8a0f2660899cc179a5fd7ee06a41af37
    77. 77
      Lin, C. M.; Singh, S. B.; Chu, P. S.; Dempcy, R. O.; Schmidt, J. M.; Pettit, G. R.; Hamel, E. Interactions of Tubulin with Potent Natural and Synthetic Analogs of the Antimitotic Agent Combretastatin: A Structure-Activity Study. Mol. Pharmacol. 1988, 34, 200– 208
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      77
      Interactions of tubulin with potent natural and synthetic analogs of the antimitotic agent combretastatin: a structure-activity study
      Lin, Chii M.; Singh, Sheo B.; Chu, Ping S.; Dempcy, Robert O.; Schmidt, Jean M.; Pettit, George R.; Hamel, Ernest
      Molecular Pharmacology (1988), 34 (2), 200-8CODEN: MOPMA3; ISSN:0026-895X.
      Available analogs (17 natural products and 22 synthetic agents) of combretastatin, an antineoplastic drug isolated from the bark of Combretum caffrum, were examd. for antimitotic and cytotoxic activity and for effects on tubulin polymn. and colchicine binding. Nineteen compds. inhibited cell growth by 50% or more at concns. of 1 μM or less, and 14 inhibited tubulin polymn. by at least 50% at stoichiometric drug concns. The most potent cytotoxic agents strongly inhibited both tubulin polymn. and the binding of colchicine to tubulin. The most promising compd. is the (cis)-stilbene deriv. (cis)-1-(3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl)-2-(3'-hydroxy-4'-methoxyphenyl)ethene (I), which has been named combretastatin A-4. This compd. inhibited cell growth by 50% at 7 nM, inhibited tubulin polymn. by 50% at 2.5 μM (1/4 molar equivalent), and competitively inhibited colchicine binding with an apparent Ki of 0.14 μM. The structure-activity relationship of these compds. is discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXmvV2muw%253D%253D&md5=fa7b749542431a3bd0f593e93d11f028

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      78
      Tubulin binding of conformationally restricted bis-aryl compounds
      Huber, Scot K.; Werbovetz, Karl A.; Obaza-Nutaitis, Judy; Lehnert, Erich K.; Macdonald, Timothy L.
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (1991), 1 (5), 243-6CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X.
      A series of bis-aryl ring contg. analogs of podophyllotoxin and combretastatin were assayed for their abilities to inhibit tubulin polymn. as part of a program to define the relationship between the aryl ring systems and tubulin binding.

      Semisyntheses, x-ray crystal structures, and tubulin-binding properties of 7-oxodeacetamidocolchicine and 7-oxodeacetamidoisocolchicine
      Banwell, Martin G.; Peters, Steven C.; Greenwood, Richard J.; Mackay, Maureen F.; Hamel, Ernest; Lin, Chii M.
      Australian Journal of Chemistry (1992), 45 (10), 1577-88CODEN: AJCHAS; ISSN:0004-9425.
      Com. available (-)-colchicine (I) has been converted, via deacetylcolchiceine, into a mixt. of 7-oxodeacetamidocolchicine (II) and 7-oxodeacetamidoisocolchicine (III). The x-ray structures and tubulin-binding properties of these title ketones are described.

      Roesner, M.; Capraro, H.-G.; Jacobson, A. E.; Atwell, L.; Brossi, A.; Iorio, M. A.; Williams, T. H.; Sik, R. H.; Chignell, C. F. Biological Effects of Modified Colchicines.       80
      Biological effects of modified colchicines. Improved preparation of 2-demethylcolchicine, 3-demethylcolchicine, and (+)-colchicine and reassignment of the position of the double bond in dehydro-7-deacetamidocolchicines
      Roesner, Manfred; Capraro, Hans-Georg; Jacobson, Arthur E.; Atwell, Louise; Brossi, Arnold; Iorio, Maria A.; Williams, Thomas H.; Sik, Robert H.; Chignell, Colin F.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1981), 24 (3), 257-61CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
      A variety of colchicine, demecolcine, and isocolchicine derivs. were examd. for their potency in the lymphocytic leukemia P388 screen in mice, for their toxicity in mice, and for their binding to microtubule protein. A qual. direct correlation was found between in vivo potency and toxicity; potency appeared to be less well correlated with tubulin binding. The most potent compds. were N-acylated analogs of colchicine and demecolcine. Among the monophenols only 6-demethylcolchicine [7336-33-6] had an appreciable effect in vitro and in vivo and was less toxic than colchicine. Improved methods were found for the prepn. of 3- and 2-dimethylcolchicine [7336-36-9], which involved the use of 85% H3PO4 and concd. H2SO4, resp. Decoupling expts. with 1H NMR proved that the double bond of dehydro-7-deacetamidocolchiceine and its derived tropolonic Me ethers I [76265-61-7] and II [76265-62-8] was in the 5,6 position rather than the 6,7 position formerly tentatively assigned. Structure-activity relations are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3MXpsFOhtQ%253D%253D&md5=acbdf7bd8db06051ea1f5d1be490b93f
    81. 81
      Bagnato, J. D.; Eilers, A. L.; Horton, R. A.; Grissom, C. B. Synthesis and Characterization of a Cobalamin–Colchicine Conjugate as a Novel Tumor-Targeted Cytotoxin. J. Org. Chem. 2004, 69, 8987– 8996,  DOI: 10.1021/jo049953w
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      81
      Synthesis and Characterization of a Cobalamin-Colchicine Conjugate as a Novel Tumor-Targeted Cytotoxin
      Bagnato, Joshua D.; Eilers, Alanna L.; Horton, Robert A.; Grissom, Charles B.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2004), 69 (26), 8987-8996CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Colchicine was derivatized at C7 with p-alkoxyacetophenone and conjugated to cobalamin (vitamin B12) through an acid-labile hydrazone linker. The cobalamin moiety leads to preferential uptake of the cobalamin-colchicine prodrug by cancer cells, whereupon the hydrazone linker undergoes hydrolysis in the lysosome to unmask colchicine, which acts as a potent cytotoxin by stabilizing microtubules and causing cell death. The bioconjugate is stable in cell culture media and at neutral pH but undergoes hydrolysis with a half-life of 138 min at pH 4.5. The colchicine-cobalamin bioconjugate exhibits nanomolar LC50 values against breast, brain, and melanoma cancer cell lines in culture. Attachment of colchicine to cobalamin is expected to increase the therapeutic index of the drug by limiting the side effects caused by the current nonselective administration of tubulin-targeted chemotherapeutic drugs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXksVGqt74%253D&md5=5d369afc3e0b9901796f4f6bce92dc6c

      Stereochemical variations on the colchicine motif. 3. The first colchicine analog with an eight membered B-ring. Structure, optical resolution and inhibition of microtubule assembly
      Berg, Ulf; Bladh, Hakan; Svensson, Christer; Wallin, Margaretta
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (1997), 7 (21), 2771-2776CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      Synthesis, crystal structure, enantiomeric resoln., and CD spectroscopy of the first colchicine deriv. with an eight-membered B-ring lactam obtained via a Beckmann reaction, is described and only one of the stable atropisomeric enantiomers arrests microtubule assembly.

    84. 84
      Bergemann, S.; Brecht, R.; Büttner, F.; Guénard, D.; Gust, R.; Seitz, G.; Stubbs, M. T.; Thoret, S. Novel B-Ring Modified Allocolchicinoids of the NCME Series: Design, Synthesis, Antimicrotubule Activity and Cytotoxicity. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2003, 11, 1269– 1281,  DOI: 10.1016/S0968-0896(02)00639-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      84
      Novel B-ring modified allocolchicinoids of the NCME series: design, synthesis, antimicrotubule activity and cytotoxicity
      Bergemann, Silke; Brecht, Rene; Buttner, Frank; Guenard, Daniel; Gust, Ronald; Seitz, Gunther; Stubbs, Milton T.; Thoret, Sylviane
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2003), 11 (7), 1269-1281CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      Two new series of allocolchicinoids mimicking the structure of (-)-N-acetylcolchinol O-Me ether (2, NCME) were synthesized and evaluated for their abilities to inhibit tubulin assembly. Possible antitumor properties resulting thereof were evaluated in vitro on the human MCF-7 breast cancer cell line. The first series of NCME-derivs. was brought about by extending the seven membered B-ring to novel semisynthetic variations with a nitrogen contg. eight-membered B-ring similar, for example, to the artificial, potent steganacin aza-analog 3. In the second series the seven-membered B-ring of NCME (2) was modified by annulation with a heterocyclic ring system. The racemic ketone 7a serving as key precursor involved in the syntheses of all the target NCME variants 9-13 and 15, 16 was easily transformed into the eight-membered B-ring lactams 9 and 10 via a Beckmann rearrangement of the corresponding E-oxime 8. The tetrazole annulated congener 11 was prepd. via azidotrimethylsilane-mediated Schmidt rearrangement. Treatment of educt 7a with Bredereck's reagent led to the enamino ketone 14, which was easily converted into the pyrazole- or pyrimidine-annulated allocolchicinoids 15 and 16. Remarkably, all the allocolchicinoids 9-13 with an azocin-B-ring affected the tubulin/microtubule equil. only moderately. In contrast, the novel heterocycle annulated seven membered B-ring variants 15 and 16 proved to be highly potent tubulin-inhibitory, antimitotic agents. Interaction with tubulin occurred at concns. similar to those obsd. for colchicine (1) or the lead NCME (2). In all cases the antiproliferative effects correlated roughly with the inhibition of tubulin assembly.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXhvFGrsLw%253D&md5=ac27f307ab699607aa181120bda73190

      Rapoport, H.; Williams, A. R.; Cisney, M. E. The Synthesis of DL-Colchinol Methyl Ether. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1951, 73, 1414– 1421,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01148a005
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      The synthesis of dl-colchinol methyl ether
      Rapoport, Henry; Williams, Arthur R.; Cisney, Merle E.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1951), 73 (), 1414-21CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      cf. C.A. 44, 10722e. Methylation of 2,5-O2N(HO)C6H3CHO yielded 25% 5-MeO compd. (I), m. 82-3°. 3,4,5-(MeO)3C6H2CO2H and 2.5 mol SOCl2 in C6H6 yielded 91% acid chloride (II), b2.5 155-60°, m. 77-9° (from C6H6-MeEt). II and Pd-on-BaSO4 with S-quinoline poison yielded 81% of the aldehyde (III), via the bisulfite addn. compd. (IV). NaHSO3 (53.5 g.) in 194 cc. water added to 74.6 g. III yielded IV in 10 min.; water to form a thin paste and then 600 cc. Et2O were added, the mixt. cooled in an ice bath, 46.6 g. NaCN in 114 cc. water added, the mixt. stirred 30 min., 5.5 g. NaHSO3 added, the layers sepd., the aq. layer extd. with two 150-cc. portions of Et2O, and the Et2O evapd. from the combined exts., yielding 82 g. cyanohydrin (V), m. 99.6-100.8°. Hot AcOH and concd. HCl (108 cc. each) contg. 108 g. SnCl2 added to 74.0 g. V, the mixt. stirred 3 h. under N in a boiling water bath, filtered hot, concd. in vacuo to 0.25 vol., the conc. poured into 1 l. satd. NaCl, and the mixt. cooled overnight yielded 45 g. (plus 9 more from the mother liquor) 3,4,5-trimethoxyphenylacetic acid (VI), m. 117-18° (from water). VI (38.5 g.), 33.9 g. III, 52.3 g. Ac2O, and 17.2 g. Et3N heated 16 h. at 90-5°, 10 cc. water added at room temp., the mixt. poured after 1 h. into 1.1 l. water contg. 160 g. K2CO3 and heated on the steam bath, the soln. washed with C6H6, then Et2O, filtered through C, and acidified with concd. HCl yielded 55.6 g. 2-nitro-5-methoxy-α-(3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl)cinnamic acid (VII), m. 157-9°. VII (17.7 g.) in 1:1 warm water and concd. NH4OH (60 cc.) added to 315 cc. concd. NH4OH and 370 cc. water at 75° contg. 120 g. FeSO4.7H2O, the ppt. allowed to settle, filtered after 1 h., washed 4 times with dil. NH4OH, and the filtrate cooled and adjusted to pH 3.3 with concd. HCl yielded 14.1 g. amino acid (VIII), m. 189-91° (from EtOH). Concd. H2SO4 (7.7 cc.) added with stirring to 35.5 g. VIII in 700 cc. dioxane, the mixt. cooled to room temp., 16.3 g. iso-AmNO2 added, the mixt. stirred 1 h., the diazonium salt added during 30 min. to 200 cc. 6.8 M NaH2PO2 contg. 6 g. Gattermann Cu paste [Ber. 23, 1218(1890)] at 50-60°, the mixt. poured into 4 l. water contg. 80 cc. concd. NH4OH, filtered through C, and the filtrate acidified with concd. HCl yielded 21.1 g. 2,3,4,7-tetramethoxy-10-phenanthrenecarboxylic acid (IX), m. 201-2°; Me ester, m. 104-5°. IX (1.9 g.), 16 cc. quinoline, and 0.1 g. CuSO4 heated 3 h. at 200-10° yielded 1.45 g. 2,3,4,7-tetramethoxyphenanthrene (X), sublimate recrystd. from EtOH, m. 151-2°; picrate, deep red needles, m. 123-3.5°. IX (25 g.), 18.3 g. SOCl2, and 300 cc. C6H6 refluxed 1 h. yielded 25.4 g. acid chloride (XI), m. 162-4° (from C6H6). NaN3 (4.8 g.) in 18 cc. water added to XI in 2 l. Me2CO (ice bath), the soln. allowed to stand 15 min., 6 l. water added during 30 min., the azide filtered off and refluxed 1 h. in 300 cc. abs. EtOH, 300 cc. 4 N EtOH-KOH added, the mixt. refluxed 4 h., filtered, and the filtrate cooled yielded 19.2 g. 2,3,4,7-tetramethoxy-10-phenanthrylamine (XII), m. 153.5-54° (from abs. EtOH). One run with excessive water present yielded 6.5% 1,3-bis(2,3,4,7-tetramethoxy-10-phenanthryl)urea (XIII), m. 277.6-278°. XIII with KOH in (CH2OH)2 heated 18 h. at 150° yielded 64% XII. XII heated 5 min. on the steam bath with a 2-fold excess of Ac2O yielded the N-Ac deriv., m. 226-8°. IX (1.20 g.) yielded 19% of the phenanthrenequinone (XIV), m. 195-6°. Oxidn. of X yielded traces of XIV; XII yielded 24%. XII (20.0 g.), 200 cc. dioxane, and 200 cc. water satd. with SO2 at 0°, heated in sealed tubes 48 h. at 100-5° yielded 18.5 g. 2,3,4,7-tetramethoxy-10-phenanthrol (XV), m. 167-9° (from aq. EtOH). XV and Me2SO4 yielded 2,3,4,7,10-pentamethoxyphenanthrene, m. 111-12°. XV (19.7 g.) in 90 cc. N KOH and 5 g. NaNO2 in 40 cc. water mixed and cooled to 0°, 240 cc. N H2SO4 added during 1 h. (temp. at 3-5°), and the mixt. stirred 30 min. and filtered yielded 18.0 g. 2,3,4,7-tetramethoxyphenanthrenequinone 9-oxime (XVI), m. 154-5°, solidified and m. 173-5°. XVI (20 g.), 11.4 g. PhSO2Cl, and 160 cc. pyridine refluxed 1.5 h., cooled, added to 800 cc. 6 N HCl, cooled in an ice bath, filtered, 100 cc. 2 N K2CO3 added to the ppt. in 500 cc. MeOH, the soln. refluxed 1 h., 100 cc. water added, and the MeOH evapd. on the steam bath yielded 15.2 g. 2-(2-cyano-4-methoxyphenyl)-3,4,5-trimethoxybenzoic acid (XVII), m. 216.5-18° (from 10:1 C6H6-Pr2). XVII (0.3 g.) boiled 24 h. with 1 g. KOH in 50 cc. water yielded 0.24 g. 2'-carboxy acid, m. 240-1°. XVII (10.6 g.), 20 g. SOCl2, and 150 cc. C6H6 refluxed 1 h., the SOCl2 evapd. with C6H6, 2.2 g. Pd-on-BaSO4 and 0.2 cc. S-quinoline poison added to the acid chloride in 150 cc. xylene, the soln. filtered after 4 h., the filtrate concd. in vacuo, the residue in 300 cc. MeOH refluxed 1 h. with 100 g. 40% NaHSO3, and the addn. compd. decompd. with satd. Na2CO3 yielded 6.8 g. 2-(2-cyano-4-methoxyphenyl)-3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde (XVIII), m. 92-2.5°; semicarbazone m. 222-3° (from aq. EtOH). XVIII (12.9 g.), 8.2 g. CH2(CO2H)2, 40 cc. pyridine, and 0.8 cc. piperidine heated 30 min. at 80°, 2 h. at 100° refluxed 30 min., and the cooled soln. poured slowly into 200 cc. 6 N HCl (ice bath) yielded 13.5 g. of the cinnamic acid, (MeO)3[NC(MeO)C6H3]C6CH:CHCO2H (XIX), m. 224-5°. Hydrogenation of the Na salt of XIX with Pd-on-C yielded β-[2-(2-cyano-4-methoxyphenyl)-3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl]propionic acid (XX), m. 124.5-5.5° (from aq. EtOH); amide (from the acid chloride), m. 170-1° (from C6H6). The Na salt from 6 g. XIX hydrogenated 30 min. at room temp. and pressure with 1.2 g. 5% Pd-on-C yielded 5.3 g. β-[2-(2-carboxy-4-methoxyphenyl)-3,4,5-trimethoxyphenyl]propionic acid (XXI), m. 175-6.5° (from MeOH-water 1:2). XXI (4.5 g.), 35 cc. MeOH, and 1.5 cc. concd. H2SO4 refluxed 18 h. yielded 4.6 g. di-Me ester (XXII), m. 110-11° (from aq. MeOH). XXII (4.4 g.) in 75 cc. PhMe added during 2 h. to 1.24 g. K in 10 cc. refluxing PhMe contg. 5 drops MeOH, the mixt. refluxed 11 h., cooled, 5 cc. and then 50 cc., water added, the PhMe layer washed, dried, and the PhMe evapd. yielded crude 1,2,3,9-tetramethoxy-6-carbomethoxydibenzo[a,c] [1,3] cycloheptadiene-7-one (XXIII); 5 g. KOH in 10 cc. water added to XXIII in 90 cc. MeOH, the mixt. allowed to stand overnight at room temp., refluxed 1 h., 15 cc. concd. HCl added, the soln. refluxed overnight, 100 cc. water added, the MeOH evapd., the ketone extd. with CHCl3 and washed with water, NaOH, and water yielded 2.4 g. 1,2,3,9-tetramethoxydibenzo[a,c] [1,3]cycloheptadien-7-one (XXIV), m. 140.5-41° (from MeOH); semicarbazone, m. 246-6.5° (from CHCl3-EtOH); oxime, m. 194-6° (from MeOH). XXIV (0.5 g.), 0.35 g. KOH, 6.0 cc. (CH2OH)2, and 0.3 cc. 85% N2H4.H2O heated according to Huang-Minlon (C.A. 41, 1649a), the cooled mixt. dild. with 8 cc. water, acidified with concd. HCl, extd. with three 10-cc. portions of C6H6, the exts. washed, the C6H6 evapd., the residue shaken 2 h. at room temp. with 35 cc. 3 N NaOH and 5 cc. Me2SO4, the mixt. extd. with C6H6 (3 × 10 cc.) the C6H6 evapd., and the residue in 5 cc. MeOH filtered through C yielded 0.29 g. 1,2,3,9-tetramethoxydibenzo[a,c][1,3]cycloheptadiene (XXV), m. 96-8°. Hydrogenation of XXIV oxime yielded 0.43 g. 7-amino-1,2,3,9-tetramethoxydibenzo[a,c][1,3]cycloheptadiene (XXVI) (dl-colchinol Me ether); HCl salt, m. 258-9°; N-Ac deriv. (XXVII) m. 178-9° (from 1:1 aq. MeOH). Colchicine (XXVIII) was converted to colchiceine and thence to N-acetyliodocolchinol (XXIX) (Windaus, C.A. 9, 1481). XXVIII (5% in MeOH contg. 3 equivs. of NaOH) hydrogenated at room temp. and pressure yielded 90% N-acetylcolchinol, which with CH2N2 yielded N-acetylcolchinol Me ether (XXIX), m. 201-2°, [α]20D -86.6 (c 0.67, MeOH). XXIX (3 g.) in 30 cc. MeOH, and 30 cc. concd. HCl refluxed 24 h. yielded 2.5 g. colchinol Me ether (XXX) HCl salt, m. 258-9°, [α]20D -88.7° (c 0.76, EtOH). d-Tartaric acid (1.62 g.) in 5 cc. water added to 1.77 g. XXX in 5 cc. warm water yielded the d-acid tartrate, m. 182-4°, [α]20D -62.2° (c 1.2, water) (from water). XXX (1.0 g.) and 0.5 g. BzH in 5 cc. MeOH warmed 15 min. yielded N-benzylidenecolchinol Me ether (XXXI), m. 145-6°, [α]25D 23.3° (c 0.73, dioxane). XXIX by the method of Cook, et al. (C.A. 38, 5819.2), yielded desaminocolchinol Me ether, hydrogenated to the dihydro compd. XXXI (0.60 g.) refluxed 5 h. in 5 cc. of 35% MeOH-PhCH2Me3NOH yielded dl-XXX, m. 258-9°, 0° rotation; N-Ac deriv., m. 180-1°; alone or mixed with XXVII.

      Kang, G. J.; Getahun, Z.; Muzaffar, A.; Brossi, A.; Hamel, E. N-Acetylcolchinol O-Methyl Ether and Thiocolchicine, Potent Analogs of Colchicine Modified in the C Ring. J. Biol. Chem. 1990, 265, 10255– 10259
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      86
      N-Acetylcolchinol O-methyl ether and thiocolchicine, potent analogs of colchicine modified in the C ring. Evaluation of the mechanistic basis for their enhanced biological properties
      Kang, Gil Jong; Getahun, Zelleka; Muzaffar, Anjum; Brossi, Arnold; Hamel, Ernest
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (1990), 265 (18), 10255-9CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258.
      Two colchicine analogs with modifications only in the C ring are better inhibitors of cell growth and tubulin polymn than colchicine. Radiolabeled thiocolchicine (with a thiomethyl instead of a methoxy group at position C-10) and N-acetylcolchino O-Me ether (NCME) (with a methoxy-substituted benzenoid instead of the methoxy-substituted tropone C ring) were prepd. for comparison with colchicine. Scatchard anal. indicated a single binding site with KD values of 1.0-2.3 μM. Thiocolchicine was bound 2-4 times as rapidly as colchicine, but the activation energies of the reactions were nearly identical (18 kcal/mol for colchicine, 20 kcal/mol for thiocolchicine). NCME bound to tubulin in a biphasic reaction. The faster phase was 60 times as fast as colchicine binding at 37°, and a substantial reaction occurred at 0°. The rate of the faster phase of NCME binding changed relatively little as a function of temp., so the activation energy was only 7.0 kcal/mol. Dissocn. reactions were also evaluated, and at 37° the halflives of the tubulin-drug complexes were 11 min for NCME, 24 h for thiocolchicine, and 27 h for colchicine. Relative dissocn. rates as a function of temp. varied little among the drug complexes. Activation energies for the dissocn. reactions were 30 kcal/mol for thiocolchicine, 27 kcal/mol for NCME, and 24 kcal/mol for colchicine. Comparison of the activation energies of assocn. and dissocn. yielded free energies for the binding reactions of -20 kcal/mol for NCME, -10 kcal/mol for thiocolchicine, and -6 kcal/mol for colchicine. The greater effectiveness of NCME and thiocolchicine as compared with colchicine in biol. assays probably derives from their more rapid binding to tubulin and the lower free energies of their binding reactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXkvFWjt78%253D&md5=7e773d0ff7754bdb7c6fee08b0dcc8e1
    87. 87
      Brossi, A.; Boyé, O.; Muzaffar, A.; Yeh, H. J. C.; Toome, V.; Wegrzynski, B.; George, C. aS,7S-Absolute Configuration of Natural (−)-Colchicine and Allocongeners. FEBS Lett. 1990, 262, 5– 7,  DOI: 10.1016/0014-5793(90)80139-A
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      87
      aS,7S-absolute configuration of natural (-)-colchicine and allo-congeners
      Brossi, Arnold; Boye, Olivier; Muzaffar, Anjum; Yeh, Herman J. C.; Toome, Voldemar; Wegrzynski, Bogda; George, Clifford
      FEBS Letters (1990), 262 (1), 5-7CODEN: FEBLAL; ISSN:0014-5793.
      The aS,7S-abs. configuration of (-)-colchicine (I) and (-)-N-acetylcolchinol Me ether (II, R = Ac), suggested on the basis of 1H-NMR data and neg. Cotton effects at about 260 nm (EtOH), is firmly established by an x-ray anal. of II [R = (R)-CONHCHMePh]. Binding of these compds. to tubulin requires an aS-configuration of the biaryl system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXkvFOrtL4%253D&md5=23a5bda02c50c80b992347f82c126515
    88. 88
      Danieli, B.; Lesma, G.; Passarella, D.; Prosperi, D.; Sacchetti, A.; Silvani, A.; Destro, R.; May, E.; Bombardelli, E.       [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      88
      New tetracyclic colchicinoids from the reaction of N-deacetylthiocolchicine and N-deacetylcolchicine with nitrous acid and tert-butyl nitrite
      Danieli, Bruno; Lesma, Giordano; Passarella, Daniele; Prosperi, Davide; Sacchetti, Alessandro; Silvani, Alessandra; Destro, Riccardo; May, Emanuela; Bombardelli, Ezio
      Helvetica Chimica Acta (2003), 86 (6), 2082-2089CODEN: HCACAV; ISSN:0018-019X. (Verlag Helvetica Chimica Acta)
      Reaction of N-deacetylthiocolchicine and N-deacetylcolchicine with nitrous acid (HONO) furnished the new tetracyclic colchicinoids I (R = MeS, MeO), as well as the Demyanov-rearrangement products II (R = MeS, MeO). Starting from N-deacetylthiocolchicine, the pyrazole-contg. tetracycle III was obtained. The novel compds. were characterized spectroscopically, and an x-ray crystal-structure anal. of I (R = MeS) allowed the abs. configurations at the stereogenic centers to be established.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXlslGntLs%253D&md5=149593749cc42bba48469657516c0890
    89. 89
      Termath, A. O.; Ritter, S.; König, M.; Kranz, D. P.; Neudörfl, J.-M.; Prokop, A.; Schmalz, H.-G. Synthesis of Oxa-B-Ring Analogs of Colchicine through Rh-Catalyzed Intramolecular [5 + 2] Cycloaddition. Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2012, 2012, 4501– 4507,  DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201200677
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      89
      Synthesis of Oxa-B-Ring Analogs of Colchicine through Rh-Catalyzed Intramolecular [5+2] Cycloaddition
      Termath, Andreas Ole; Ritter, Stefanie; Koenig, Marcel; Kranz, Darius Paul; Neudoerfl, Joerg-Martin; Prokop, Aram; Schmalz, Hans-Guenther
      European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2012), 2012 (24), 4501-4507, S4501/1-S4501/37CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A synthetic approach towards (5R)-5-methyl-6-oxa-desacetamidocolchicine (I) as a conformationally defined non-natural colchicine analog with a modified B-ring was undertaken. The synthetic strategy was based on a Rh-catalyzed cascade reaction involving a [5+2] cycloaddn. of a carbonyl ylide intermediate as a key step, in which both seven-membered rings of the polycyclic framework are formed in a single operation. Starting from 2-iodo-3,4,5-trimethoxyacetophenone (II), an upper side-chain was constructed through enantioselective CBS redn. (up to 75% ee) and propargylation, while a lower succinoyl side-chain was attached either through iodine-magnesium-copper exchange and subsequent reaction with Me 4-chloro-4-oxobutanoate, or by Pd-catalyzed Stille cross-coupling with 2-tributylstannyl-5-methoxyfuran followed by hydrolytic furan-opening. Treatment of α-diazoketone intermediate III with Rh2(OAc)4 (3 mol-%)initiated the diastereoselective key cyclization cascade (≥97:3 dr). Treatment of the cycloadduct IV with Et2AlCl afforded an interesting 11,12-dihydrocolchicine analog V, which, however, could not be oxidized to the corresponding tropolone. Structural assignments were confirmed by X-ray crystallog. While compds. IV and V did not exhibit noteworthy cytotoxic activity by themselves, they were found to strongly enhance the cytostatic (apoptosis-inducing) activity of doxorubicin against resistant Nalm-6 cells (i.e., in a synergy effect).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XpvVSnurw%253D&md5=ab8af8d0b0232f5dc13d4bb96ebaccd0

      Bio-inspired synthesis and biological evaluation of a colchicine-related compound library
      Nicolaou, K. C.; Valiulin, Roman A.; Pokorski, Jonathan K.; Chang, Vicki; Chen, Jason S.
      Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2012), 22 (11), 3776-3780CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A bio-inspired investigation of the reactions of N-substituted 7-hydroxy-6-methoxy-1-(3,4,5-trimethoxyphenethyl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinolines with VOF3 and PIFA [PhI(OAc)2] led to a collection of colchicine-like compds. and related systems. Biol. evaluation revealed that some of the synthesized products had significant cytotoxic properties against the colon cancer cell line HT-29.

      91
      Colchicine Glycorandomization Influences Cytotoxicity and Mechanism of Action
      Ahmed, Aqeel; Peters, Noeel R.; Fitzgerald, Megan K.; Watson, James A., Jr.; Hoffmann, F. Michael; Thorson, Jon S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (44), 14224-14225CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The reaction of 70 unprotected, diversely functionalized free reducing sugars with methoxyamine-appended colchicine led to the prodn. of a 58-member glycorandomized library. High-throughput cytotoxicity assays revealed glycosylation to modulate specificity and potency. Library members were also identified which, unlike the parent natural product (a destabilizer), stabilized in vitro tubulin polymn. in a manner similar to taxol. This study highlights a simple extension of neoglycorandomization toward amine-bearing scaffolds and the potential benefit of glycosylating nonglycosylated natural products.

      92
      The interaction between lipid derivatives of colchicine and tubulin: Consequences of the interaction of the alkaloid with lipid membranes
      Mons, S.; Veretout, F.; Carlier, M.-F.; Erk, I.; Lepault, J.; Trudel, E.; Salesse, C.; Ducray, P.; Mioskowski, C.; Lebeau, L.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Biomembranes (2000), 1468 (1-2), 381-395CODEN: BBBMBS; ISSN:0005-2736. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Colchicine is a potent antimitotic poison which is well known to prevent microtubule assembly by binding tubulin very tightly. Colchicine also possesses anti-inflammatory properties which are not well understood yet. Here we show that colchicine tightly interacts with lipid layers. The phys. and biol. properties of three different lipid derivs. of colchicine are investigated parallel to those of membrane lipids in the presence of colchicine. Upon insertion in the fatty alkyl chains, colchicine rigidifies the lipid monolayers in a fluid phase and fluidifies rigid monolayers. Similarly X-ray diffraction data show that lecithin-water phases are destabilized by colchicine. In addn., an unexpectedly drastic enhancement of the photoisomerization rate of colchicine into lumicolchicine in the lipid environment is obsd. and further supports insertion of the alkaloid in membranes. Finally the interaction of colchicine with lipids makes the drug inaccessible to tubulin. The possible in vivo significance of these results is discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXmvFyqtr0%253D&md5=faa999a57faa6192e61eefe3bee41943

      Zheng, X.; Dong, F.; Yang, J.; Duan, X.; Niu, T.; Wu, W.; Wang, J. Synthesis and Preliminary Biodistribution Studies of [131I]SIB-PEG4-CHC in Tumor-Bearing Mice. J. Radioanal. Nucl. Chem. 2011, 287, 113– 117,  DOI: 10.1007/s10967-010-0659-5
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      93
      Synthesis and preliminary biodistribution studies of [131I]SIB-PEG4-CHC in tumor-bearing mice
      Zheng, Xiaobei; Dong, Feng; Yang, Jing; Duan, Xiaojiang; Niu, Tingting; Wu, Wangsuo; Wang, Jianjun
      Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry (2011), 287 (1), 113-117CODEN: JRNCDM; ISSN:0236-5731. (Springer)
      This work reports the synthesis and preliminary biodistribution results of [131I]SIB-PEG4-CHC in tumor-bearing mice. The tributylstannyl precursor ATE-PEG4-CHC was synthesized by conjugation of ATE to amino pegylated colchicine NH2-PEG4-CHC. [131I]SIB-PEG4-CHC was radiosynthesized by electrophilic destannylation of the precursor with a yield of ∼44%. The radiochem. purity (RCP) appeared to be >95% by a Sep-Pak cartridge purifn. [131I]SIB-PEG4-CHC was lipophilic and was stable at room temp. Biodistribution studies in tumor-bearing mice showed that [131I]SIB-PEG4-CHC cleared from background rapidly, and didn't deiodinate in vivo. However, the poor tumor localization excluded it from further investigations as a tumor-targeted radiopharmaceuticals.

      94
      Azides Derived from Colchicine and their Use in Library Synthesis: a Practical Entry to New Bioactive Derivatives of an Old Natural Drug
      Nicolaus, Norman; Zapke, Janet; Riesterer, Philipp; Neudoerfl, Joerg-Martin; Prokop, Aram; Oschkinat, Hartmut; Schmalz, Hans-Guenther
      ChemMedChem (2010), 5 (5), 661-665CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Triazole-substituted colchinoids such as I [R = Me(CH2)10COOCH2, HO(CH2)3] and triazole-substituted allocolchicinoids II [R = 2-AcOC6H4COOCH2, HO(CH2)3] are prepd. from nonracemic colchicinoid and allocolchicinoid azides and alkynes RC≡CH by regioselective copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddn. reactions and tested for their inhibition of tubulin polymn., effect on the morphol. and survival of human cancer cells, and induction of apoptosis in vitro. The nonracemic colchicinoid and allocolchicinoid azide precursors are prepd. in four and five steps from colchicine, resp. I [R = Me(CH2)10COOCH2] showed high antitumor activity in human cancer cells at concns. < 0.01 μM while showing only moderate activity in protein binding assays.

      New Colchicine-Derived Triazoles and Their Influence on Cytotoxicity and Microtubule Morphology
      Thomopoulou, Persefoni; Sachs, Julia; Teusch, Nicole; Mariappan, Aruljothi; Gopalakrishnan, Jay; Schmalz, Hans-Guenther
      ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2016), 7 (2), 188-191CODEN: AMCLCT; ISSN:1948-5875. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of new colchicinoids with a variable triazole unit at C-7 was synthesized through Cu(I)-catalyzed 1,3-dipolar cycloaddn. (click-chem.) of a colchicine-derived azide with various alkynes and the cytotoxicity against THP-1 and Jurkat cancer cell lines was used for structural optimization. Three particularly active compds. (IC50 ≤ 5 nM) were addnl. investigated with respect to their efficacy against relevant solid tumor cell lines (HeLa, A549, and SK MES 1). Besides distorting the microtubule morphol. by tubulin depolymn., one compd. I also exhibited a pronounced centrosome declustering effect in triple neg. breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-231) and nonsmall cell lung cancer cells (H1975).

      Colchicine metallocenyl bioconjugates showing high antiproliferative activities against cancer cell lines
      Kowalczyk, Karolina; Blauz, Andrzej; Ciszewski, Wojciech M.; Wieczorek, Anna; Rychlik, Blazej; Plazuk, Damian
      Dalton Transactions (2017), 46 (48), 17041-17052CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A series of ferrocenyl and ruthenocenyl conjugates with colchicine bearing a 1,2,3-triazole moiety were synthesized and their anticancer properties were evaluated. The authors found that the most potent metallocenyl derivs. Rc4 and Rc5 are 6-7 times more cytotoxic toward HepG2 cells, while Fc4 and Fc5 are two times more cytotoxic toward HCT116 cells as colchicine. The authors also found that compds. Fc4, Fc5, Rc1 and Rc3-Rc5 are able to induce apoptosis, while compd. Fc2 arrests mitosis.

      Arylureas derived from colchicine: Enhancement of colchicine oncogene downregulation activity
      Blasco, Victor; Cunat, Ana C.; Sanz-Cervera, Juan F.; Marco, J. Alberto; Falomir, Eva; Murga, Juan; Carda, Miguel
      European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 150 (), 817-828CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
      Our efforts to get therapeutically useful colchicine derivs. for the treatment of cancer have led us to synthesize and biol. evaluate twenty-seven N,N'-disubstituted ureas contg. a colchicine moiety and an aryl fragment. The cytotoxicity of the compds., their ability to inhibit the expression of oncogenes related to telomerase activation and to the VEGF/VEGFR-2 autocrine process, such as c-MYC, hTERT and VEGF and their capability to downregulate c-MYC and VEGFR-2 proteins and the secretion of VEGF have been measured. In these biol. evaluations, we have found that the change of the acetyl group in colchicines for an N-arylurea unit causes a great improvement in anticancer properties. The most promising derivs. were compds. 6 VI and XIV as they were able to downregulate all the tested targets at a concn. below their IC50 values. Thus, the arylurea unit enhances the potential of colchicine as an anticancer agent.

      Synthesis and biological evaluation of 4-chlorocolchicine derivatives as potent anticancer agents with broad effective dosage ranges
      Nishiyama, Hiroyuki; Ono, Masahiro; Sugimoto, Takuya; Sasai, Toshio; Asakawa, Naoyuki; Yaegashi, Takashi; Nagaoka, Masato; Matsuzaki, Takeshi; Kogure, Noriyuki; Kitajima, Mariko; Takayama, Hiromitsu
      MedChemComm (2012), 3 (12), 1500-1504CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      4-Chlorocolchicine derivs. were synthesized with a view of developing new anticancer agents. The derivs. were examd. for their potent activity and effective dosage range in mice, as well as favorable metabolic stability. As a result, several compds. bearing an α-hydroxyalkanoyl group on the C-7 amino function, were revealed to exhibit potent activities with broad effective dosage ranges. The title compds. thus formed included a colchicine amide deriv. (I) and related substances. The title compds. were evaluated against N-[(7S)-5,6,7,9-tetrahydro-1,2,3,10-tetramethoxy-9-oxobenzo[a]heptalen-7-yl]acetamide (colchicine). The synthesis of the target compds. was achieved using (7S)-7-amino-4-chloro-6,7-dihydro-1,2,3,10-tetramethoxybenzo[a]heptalen-9(5H)-one (4-chlorodeacetylcolchicine) as a starting material.

      4-Chlorocolchicine derivatives bearing a thiourea side chain at the C-7 position as potent anticancer agents
      Nishiyama, Hiroyuki; Ono, Masahiro; Sugimoto, Takuya; Sasai, Toshio; Asakawa, Naoyuki; Ueno, Satoshi; Tominaga, Yoshitaka; Yaegashi, Takashi; Nagaoka, Masato; Matsuzaki, Takeshi; Kogure, Noriyuki; Kitajima, Mariko; Takayama, Hiromitsu
      MedChemComm (2014), 5 (4), 452-458CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A series of 4-substituted colchicine derivs. were synthesized and evaluated with an eye toward developing new anticancer agents. As a result, 4-chlorocolchicine derivs. bearing a thioureide side chain at the C-7 position were found to exhibit significant cytotoxicities to three human cancer cell lines (A549, HT-29, and HCT116). In particular, compd. 26 having an ethylthioureide group at the C-7 had high antitumor activity in vivo and a broad effective dosage range. Furthermore, compd. 58, which has a (5-methylpyrazol-3-yl)thioureide group at the C-7 side chain, exhibited strong cytotoxicity and desirable metabolic stability in vitro.

      Lee, S.-J.; Namkoong, S.; Ha, K.-S.; Nam, W.-D.; Kwon, Y.; Lee, H.; Yoon, E.-Y.; Chang, D.-J.; Kim, S.-O.; Kim, Y.-M. Colchicine-Derived Compound CT20126 Promotes Skin Allograft Survival by Regulating the Balance of Th1 and Th2 Cytokine Production. Exp. Mol. Med. 2007, 39, 230– 238,  DOI: 10.1038/emm.2007.26
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      101
      Colchicine-derived compound CT20126 promotes skin allograft survival by regulating the balance of Th1 and Th2 cytokine production
      Lee, Seon-Jin; Namkoong, Seung; Ha, Kwon-Soo; Nam, Woo-Dong; Kwon, Young-Guen; Lee, Hansoo; Yoon, Eun-Young; Chang, Dong-Jo; Kim, Soon-Ok; Kim, Young-Myeong
      Experimental and Molecular Medicine (2007), 39 (2), 230-238CODEN: EMMEF3; ISSN:1226-3613. (Korean Society of Medical Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      Colchicine was shown to regulate the expression of inflammatory gene, but this compd. possesses much weaker anti-inflammatory activity. In this study, we synthesized a new colchicine deriv. CT20126 and examd. its immunomodulatory property. CT20126 was found to have immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting lymphocyte proliferation without cytotoxicity and effectively inhibit the transcriptional expression of the inflammatory genes, iNOS, TNF-α, and IL-1β, in macrophages stimulated by LPS. This effect was nearly comparable to that of cyclosporine A. This compd. also significantly suppressed the prodn. of nitric oxide and Th1-related pro-inflammatory cytokines, IL-1β, TNF-α, and IL-2, with minimal suppression of Th2-related anti-inflammatory cytokines IL-4 and IL-10 in the sponge matrix allograft model. Moreover, administration of CT20126 prolonged the survival of allograft skins from BALB/c mice (H-2d) to the dorsum of C57BL/6 (H-2b) mice. The in vivo immune suppressive effects of CT20126 were similar to that of cyclosporine A. These results indicate that this compd. may have potential therapeutic value for transplantation rejection and other inflammatory diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXltFarsLc%253D&md5=d6762576addeb280449f1d502c7de3f6
    102. 102
      Kim, S.-K.; Cho, S.-M.; Kim, H.; Seok, H.; Kim, S.-O.; Kwon, T. K.; Chang, J.-S. The Colchicine Derivative CT20126 Shows a Novel Microtubule-Modulating Activity with Apoptosis. Exp. Mol. Med. 2013, 45, e19  DOI: 10.1038/emm.2013.38
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      102
      The colchicine derivative CT20126 shows a novel microtubule-modulating activity with apoptosis
      Kim, Sung-Kuk; Cho, Sang-Min; Kim, Ho; Seok, Heon; Kim, Soon-Ok; Kwon, Taeg Kyu; Chang, Jong-Soo
      Experimental & Molecular Medicine (2013), 45 (April), e19, 7 pp.CODEN: EMMEF3; ISSN:2092-6413. (NPG Nature Asia-Pacific)
      New colchicine analogs have been synthesized with the aim of developing stronger potential anticancer activities. Among the analogs, CT20126 has been previously reported to show immunosuppressive activities. Here, we report that CT20126 also shows potential anticancer effects via an unusual mechanism: the modulation of microtubule integrity and cell cycle arrest at the G2/M phase before apoptosis. When we treated COS-7 cells with CT20126 (5 μM), the normal thread-like microtubules were disrupted into tubulin dimers within 10min and thereafter repolymd. into short, thick filaments. In contrast, cells treated with the same concn. of colchicine exhibited microtubule depolymn. after 20min and never underwent repolymn. Furthermore, optical d. (OD) anal. (350nm) with purified tubulin showed that CT20126 had a higher repolymg. activity than that of Taxol, a potent microtubule-polymg. agent. These results suggest that the effects of CT20126 on microtubule integrity differ from those of colchicine: the analog first destabilizes microtubules and then stabilizes the disrupted tubulins into short, thick polymers. Furthermore, CT20126 induced a greater level of apoptotic activity in Jurkat T cells than colchicine (assessed by G2/M arrest, caspase-3 activation and cell sorting). At 20nM, CT20126 induced 47% apoptosis among Jurkat T cells, whereas colchicine induced only 33% apoptosis. Our results suggest that the colchicine analog CT20126 can potently induce apoptosis by disrupting microtubule integrity in a manner that differs from that of colchicine or Taxol.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnsFWku7w%253D&md5=0de0f0fc3a699af6af2fd7a60af67226
    103. 103
      Choi, M.; Wee, Y.; Kim, Y.; Shin, S.; Yoo, S.; Han, D.-J. Novel Colchicine Derivatives Enhance Graft Survival after Transplantation via Suppression of T-cell Differentiation and Activity. J. Cell. Biochem. 2019, 120, 12436– 12449,  DOI: 10.1002/jcb.28510
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      103
      Novel colchicine derivatives enhance graft survival after transplantation via suppression of T-cell differentiation and activity
      Choi, Monica-Y.; Wee, Yu-Mee; Kim, Yang-Hee; Shin, Sung; Yoo, Sung-Eun; Han, Duck-Jong
      Journal of Cellular Biochemistry (2019), 120 (8), 12436-12449CODEN: JCEBD5; ISSN:0730-2312. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      Immunosuppressants are crucial in organ transplantation but their side effects are a trade-off for long-term use. Colchicine has been shown to be effective in various diseases, albeit with many side effects. To enhance the immunosuppressive effects of colchicine, in addn. to minimizing its side effects, we attempted to synthesize new colchicine derivs. (KR compds.). In rat cardiac and pancreatic islet allograft, long-term graft survival was identified in KR compd.-treated groups. The use of cyclosporine A (CsA) or colchicine inhibited the CD3+ and CD4+ T-cell proliferation, whereas KR compds. inhibited the CD8+ T cells as well as CD4+ T cells. KR compds. reduced the apoptosis, interleukin-2 receptor expression, and signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 phosphorylation more than CsA. These results indicate that KR compds. have a potential therapeutic value as novel agents for prevention of graft deterioration by allograft of rejection.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXktlKlsb0%253D&md5=3ff80a7189eebaa97b71d5b1f87cb096
    104. 104
      Shi, Q.; Verdier-Pinard, P.; Brossi, A.; Hamel, E.; McPhail, A. T.; Lee, K.-H. Antitumor Agents. 172. Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Novel Deacetamidothiocolchicin-7-ols and Ester Analogs as Antitubulin Agents. J. Med. Chem. 1997, 40, 961– 966,  DOI: 10.1021/jm960663k
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      104
      Antitumor Agents. 172. Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Novel Deacetamidothiocolchicin-7-ols and Ester Analogs as Antitubulin Agents
      Shi, Qian; Verdier-Pinard, Pascal; Brossi, Arnold; Hamel, Ernest; McPhail, Andrew T.; Lee, Kuo-Hsiung
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1997), 40 (6), 961-966CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of novel deacetamidothiocolchicine derivs. I (R = OCOMe, OCOCF3, OCOCH2CH2Me, OCOPh, 3-, 4-pyridinylcarbonyloxy, R1 = H; RR1 = O) were synthesized and evaluated for their inhibitory activity against tubulin polymn., the binding of [3H]-colchicine to tubulin, and the growth of human Burkitt lymphoma cells. Of these new derivs. thiocolchicone I (RR1 = O) was obtained from deacetylthiocolchicine by Schiff's base equilibration and acid hydrolysis. Redn. of thiocolchicone with sodium borohydride yielded the racemic alc. I (R = OH, R1 = H), the structure of which was verified by X-ray crystallog. anal. Optically pure alcs. I (R = α-OH, β-OH, R1 = H) were obtained by treatment of the racemic alc. with the optically pure reagent (1S)-(-)-camphanic chloride followed by chromatog. sepn. of the camphanate esters and hydrolysis of the diastereomers. X-ray crystallog. anal. established configuration of (S)-I (R = α-OH, R1 = H). The racemic and optically active esters were obtained by esterification of the corresponding alcs. with acyl chlorides, RCOCl. The compds. showing activity equiv. to or greater than (-)-thiocolchicine I (R = α-NHCOMe, R1 = β-H) in all the biol. assays were three optically pure enantiomers I (R = α-OH, α-OCOMe, α-4-pyridinylcarbonyloxy, R1 = β-H;). In addn., the ketone I (RR1 = O) and enantiomers I (R = α-OCOCH2CH2Me, α-3-pyridinylcarbonyloxy, R1 = β-H;) had high activity in the biochem. assays with tubulin but reduced antiproliferative activity. In all cases, optically pure isomers with the (-)-(7S) configuration exhibited greater biol. activity than racemic mixts. or (+)-(7R)-isomers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXhvVSrs7c%253D&md5=40ef2d28774717f701a96d06d0314543

      Shi, Q.; Chen, K.; Brossi, A.; Verdier-Pinard, P.; Hamel, E.; McPhail, A. T.; Lee, K.-H. Antitumor Agents. Part 184.       105
      Antitumor agents. Part 184. Syntheses and antitubulin activity of compounds derived from reaction of thiocolchicone with amines. Lactams, alcohols, and ester analogs of allothiocolchicinoids
      Shi, Qian; Chen, Ke; Brossi, Arnold; Verdier-Pinard, Pascal; Hamel, Ernest; McPhail, Andrew T.; Lee, Kuo-Hsiung
      Helvetica Chimica Acta (1998), 81 (6), 1023-1037CODEN: HCACAV; ISSN:0018-019X. (Verlag Helvetica Chimica Acta AG)
      7-O-substituted analogs of deaminodeoxycolchinol thiomethyl ether were synthesized and evaluated for their inhibitory effects on tubulin polymn. in vitro. Unexpectedly, introduction of O-aroyl substituents at C(7) of the new compds. resulted in different effects on the conformation of the biphenyl backbone and, therefore, on biol. activity. The biol. active O-acyl derivs. retained the (-)-(aS,7S)-configuration of colchicine, but, among the O-aroyl derivs., the (+)-(7R)-isomers had greater inhibitory effects on tubulin than the (-)-(7S)-derivs. Anal. of 1H-NMR spectra and optical rotatory data indicated that, in soln., both (7S)- and (7R)-compds. assumed 2 conformations, and that biol. activity is related to the proportion of the (aS)-conformation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXktVyisr8%253D&md5=a19b74683958b355a77074eac4d5452c

      Klejborowska, G.; Moshari, M.; Maj, E.; Majcher, U.; Preto, J.; Wietrzyk, J.; Tuszynski, J. A.; Huczyński, A. Synthesis, Antiproliferative Activity, and Molecular Docking Studies of 4-Chlorothiocolchicine Analogues. Chem. Biol. Drug Des. 2020, 95, 182– 191,  DOI: 10.1111/cbdd.13618

      Synthesis, antiproliferative activity, and molecular docking studies of 4-chlorothiocolchicine analogues
      Klejborowska, Greta; Moshari, Mahshad; Maj, Ewa; Majcher, Urszula; Preto, Jordane; Wietrzyk, Joanna; Tuszynski, Jack A.; Huczynski, Adam
      Chemical Biology & Drug Design (2020), 95 (1), 182-191CODEN: CBDDAL; ISSN:1747-0277. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      Colchicine is a therapeutic agent currently used in therapies of many diseases. It also shows antimitotic effects, and its high cytotoxic activity against different cancer cell lines has been demonstrated many times. To overcome the limitations of colchicine use in anticancer therapy, we synthesized a series of novel triple-modified 4-chloro-7-carbamatethiocolchicines. All the synthesized compds. have been tested in vitro to evaluate their cytotoxicity toward A549, MCF-7, LoVo, LoVo/DX, and BALB/3T3 cell lines. Addnl., their mode of binding to β-tubulin was evaluated in silico. The majority of triple-modified colchicine derivs. exhibited significantly higher cytotoxicity than colchicine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin against tested cancerous cell lines with much higher selectivity index values for four of them.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhvVWit7rJ&md5=c2dfc333f1a735ce2791731ad20f9017

      Klejborowska, G.; Urbaniak, A.; Maj, E.; Preto, J.; Moshari, M.; Wietrzyk, J.; Tuszynski, J. A.; Chambers, T. C.; Huczyński, A. Synthesis, Biological Evaluation and Molecular Docking Studies of New Amides of 4-Chlorothiocolchicine as Anticancer Agents. Bioorg. Chem. 2020, 97, 103664,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bioorg.2020.103664

      107
      Synthesis, biological evaluation and molecular docking studies of new amides of 4-chlorothiocolchicine as anticancer agents
      Klejborowska, Greta; Urbaniak, Alicja; Maj, Ewa; Preto, Jordane; Moshari, Mahshad; Wietrzyk, Joanna; Tuszynski, Jack A.; Chambers, Timothy C.; Huczynski, Adam
      Bioorganic Chemistry (2020), 97 (), 103664CODEN: BOCMBM; ISSN:0045-2068. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Colchicine belongs to a large group of microtubule polymn. inhibitors. Although the anti-cancer activity of colchicine and its derivs. has been established, none of them has found com. application in cancer treatment due to side effects. Therefore, we designed and synthesized a series of six triple-modified 4-chlorothiocolchicine analogs with amide moieties and one urea deriv., I [R = CH2OMe, (CH2)3Cl, Ph, Et, CHMe2, (CH2)8Me, NEt2]. These novel derivs. were tested against several different cancer cell lines (A549, MCF-7, LoVo, LoVo/DX) and primary acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) cells and they showed activity in the nanomolar range. The obtained IC50 values for novel derivs. were lower than those obtained for unmodified colchicine and common anticancer drugs such as doxorubicin and cisplatin. Further studies of colchicine and selected analogs were undertaken to indicate that they induced apoptotic cell death in ALL-5 cells. We also performed in silico studies to predict binding modes of the 4-chlorothiocolchicine derivs. to different β tubulin isotypes. The results indicate that select triple-modified 4-chlorothiocolchicine derivs. represent highly promising novel cancer chemotherapeutics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXjvVKhu7k%253D&md5=84aa7b0ddfadce8666ec7a97a4d5a9de

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Interaction of colchicine analogs with purified tubulin
      Choudhury, Goutam Ghosh; Banerjee, Ashok; Bhattacharyya, Bhabatarak; Biswas, Birendra B.
      FEBS Letters (1983), 161 (1), 55-9CODEN: FEBLAL; ISSN:0014-5793.
      The binding of 2 colchicine (I) analogs, deacetamidocolchicine (II) and 2-methoxy-5-(2',3',4'-trimethoxyphenyl)tropone (III), to purified tubulin was studied. Both I analogs bound to tubulin with a significant increase in fluorescence polarization of the drugs in solns. contg. tubulin. The Kd for the tubulin-drug complexes were 1.25 × 10-6 and 1.08 × 10-6 M for II and III, resp. Scatchard anal. of the fluorescence titrn. curve of drug-tubulin interactions also gave values for the stoichiometry and affinity const. These were 0.8 and 1.6 × 106 M-1 for II and 0.9 and 0.58 × 106 M-1 for III, resp.

      Hastie, S. B. Interactions of Colchicine with Tubulin. Pharmacol. Ther. 1991, 51, 377– 401,  DOI: 10.1016/0163-7258(91)90067-V
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      109
      Interactions of colchicine with tubulin
      Hastie, Susan Bane
      Pharmacology & Therapeutics (1991), 51 (3), 377-401CODEN: PHTHDT; ISSN:0163-7258.
      A review with ∼230 refs. Colchicine exerts its biol. effects through binding to the sol. tubulin heterodimer, the major component of the microtubule. The colchicine-binding abilities of tubulins from a variety of sources are summarized, and the mechanism of colchicine binding to brain tubulin is explored in depth. The relationship between colchicinoid structure and tubulin binding activity provides insight into the structural features of colchicine responsible for high affinity binding to tubulin and is reviewed for analogs in the colchicine series. The thermodn. and kinetic aspects of the assocn. are described and evaluated in terms of the binding mechanism. Colchicine binding to tubulin results in unusual alterations in the low energy electronic spectra of colchicine. The spectroscopic features of colchicine bound to tubulin are discussed in terms of the nature of the colchicine-tubulin complex. Attempts to locate the high affinity colchicine binding site on tubulin are presented.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xht1ShsLw%253D&md5=13a53c4b603f19fa2d1f1464782b11fc

      Nicholls, G. A.; Tarbell, D. S. Colchicine and Related Compounds. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1953, 75, 1104– 1107,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01101a028
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      110
      Colchicine and related compounds
      Nicholls, Gordon A.; Tarbell, D. Stanley
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1953), 75 (), 1104-7CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      Nitration of colchiceine (I) under mild conditions gave a cryst. nitro compd. which was catalytically reduced in good yield to the corresponding amine. The amine rearranged to a HO carboxylic acid on treatment with HNO2 in the presence of H3PO2. The hydrogenation of colchicine (II) in C6H6 over PtO2 gave 10-15% demethoxyhexahydrocolchicine (III), m. 174-5°, along with a very small amt. of a stereoisomer of III, m. 126-8°, and hexahydrocolchicine (IV), m. about 124°. U.S.P. grade II (50 g.) was chromatographed on grade I-II alkali-free Al2O3, eluted with 850 cc. Me2CO, and the gum (47.3 g.) seeded and twice recrystd. from EtOAc to give pure II, m. 155-7° (decompn.). II (16.0 g.) heated 1.75 hrs. with 160 cc. 0.1N HCl on a steam bath gave I, m. 177-9° (from EtOAc-hexane); the filtrate from the I neutralized with NaHCO3 gave a gelatinous ppt. of 680 mg. trimethylcolchicinic acid, m. 163° (from hot MeOH). To 6.0 g. I in 10 cc. AcOH and 3 cc. H2O was added dropwise 7 cc. of a soln. of 2 cc. HNO3 (d20 1.41), 5 cc. glacial AcOH, and 5 cc. H2O, the mixt. stirred 1 hr. at 0-5°, poured with stirring into 110 cc. ice cold H2O, and the yellow ppt. filtered off, washed twice by stirring 0.5 hr. with 15 cc. H2O each, and recrystd. several times from C6H6 or C6H6-EtOH to give nitrocolchiceine, C21H22N2O8.0.5C6H6 (V), yellow leaflets, m. indefinitely with foaming near 148-50°, darkened on drying in vacuo over P2O5 at 110°. V (1.32 g.) hydrogenated 45 min. in 70 cc. dioxane over 430 mg. PtO2 at 25° gave 78-80% aminocolchiceine, C21H24N2O6 (VI), yellow prisms, m. 269-70° (decompn.) (in vacuum tube), insol. in aq. NaHCO3, sol. in aq. Na2CO3, gave a green color with FeCl3. VI (250 mg.) in 2 g. 30% H3PO2 treated with stirring at 0-5° with 0.5 cc. aq. NaO2 (47 mg.) added dropwise from a capillary, the mixt. kept 1.5 hrs. in an ice bath (during which time the initial orange ppt. decompd. with effervescence to a pale cream ppt.), and the ppt. filtered, washed, dried (245 mg.) and recrystd. from cold. EtOAc-hexane gave a HO carboxylic acid, C21H23NO7 (VII), colorless plates, m. indefinitely with decompn. near 175°, readily sol. in aq. NaHCO3, gave a green color with FeCl3. VII (50 mg.) in 0.5 cc. Ac2O and 1 drop 60% HClO4 from a capillary let stand 15 min. at 25°, the mixt. stirred into 10 cc. H2O, let stand 4 hrs. with frequent scratching, and the cryst. ppt. (47 mg.) recrystd. from cold EtOAc-hexane gave the acetate of VII, C23H25NO8.H2O, colorless prisms, m. indefinitely with decompn. near 190°, readily sol. in aq. NaHCO3. II (4.0 g.) hydrogenated 20 hrs. in 80 cc. C6H6 over 500 mg. prereduced PtO2, the run repeated, the 2 mixts. combined and warmed to dissolve the crystals which had deposited during the hydrogenation, and the soln. filtered and satd. with H2O deposited 1.24 g. III, colorless plates, m. 174-5° [acetate, colorless needles, m. 212.5-13° (from EtOAc satd. with H2O)]; the H2O-satd. combined filtrates from III fractionally concd. over a period of several weeks, and the residues recrystd. from H2O-satd. EtOAc gave 2.64 g. microcryst. solid, m. 100-20°, which on repeated recrystn. from aq. MeOH and EtOAc gave 700 mg. IV, m. indefinitely but near 121-4°. The residue from the mother liquors from III fractionally crystd. from C6H6 and the low-melting fractions recrystd. from Me2CO and EtOAc satd. with H2O gave stereoisomeric III, m. 126-8° (dried at 110° in vacuo over P2O5); acetate, 60%, colorless prisms, m. 169-70° (from aq. MeOH). IV was converted in 58% yield to the acetate (VIII), colorless needles, m. 164.5-65° (from EtOAc-heptane). VIII let stand 1 day at room temp. with 5 cc. MeOH and 15 cc. 0.047N NaOH, the soln. concd. by a cold air stream, and the residue recrystd. from aq. MeOH and H2O-satd. EtOAc gave colorless needles, m. indefinitely but near 122-6°, which, dried 3 weeks at room temp. in a vacuum desiccator, yielded IV, m. 167-7.5° with shrinking at 120°; a sample dried a further 4 hrs. in vacuo over P2O5 167-7.5°. The infrared spectra of V, VI, and VII are recorded.

      Šantavý, F. Préparation de l’acide Colchicique à Partir de La Colchicine. Helv. Chim. Acta 1948, 31, 821– 826,  DOI: 10.1002/hlca.19480310322

      Preparation of colchicic acid from colchicine
      Santavy, Fr.
      Helvetica Chimica Acta (1948), 31 (), 821-6CODEN: HCACAV; ISSN:0018-019X.
      In an attempt to prep. N-methylcolchicine from colchicine (I), 1 g. I is heated in a sealed tube with 0.8 g. MeI and 5 cc. MeOH contg. 0.1 g. Na at 100°, the MeOH distd. off in vacuo at 30°, and the residue acidified with 2 N HCl, giving crude colchicic acid (II), m. 240-60°. I (100 mg.) is refluxed in 2 cc. MeOH, 5 cc. MeOH contg. 0.1 g. Na added, the mixt. heated slowly to boiling, kept there 0.5 hr., the MeOH distd. off in vacuo at 30°, and the residue taken up in 5 cc. H2O and slightly acidified with HCl, giving 70-80% crude or 50-60% pure II, m. 262-6°. When 100 mg. I in 2 cc. MeOH and 0.2 cc. H2O is heated with 5 cc. MeOH contg. 0.1 g. Na, 45% II is formed. I heated with a satd. MeOH-KOH soln. gives 25-35% II. Iso-colchicine heated with MeONa in MeOH also gives II. Colchiceine treated in the same way is recovered unchanged. II, fine needles from CHCl3, EtOAc, or Me2CO-ether, m. 262-6° and sublimes at 240°/0.001 mm. Methylation of 500 mg. II with an excess of CH2N2 in MeOH, evapn. of the MeOH, and extn. of the residue with MeOH or CHCl3 leaves a residue, m. 131-3°. From the ext. Me colchicate (III), prisms, m. 261-2°, [α]20D -141.72 ± 2° (c 1.4112, CHCl3), subliming 220°/0.001 mm., is isolated. III treated with Ac2O in C5H5N is recovered unchanged. Sapon. of III with MeOH-NaOH gives II, λmax. 280 mμ, λmin. 257 mμ (in 0.05 N NaOH). The polarographic curve of II is given.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaH1cXislCqug%253D%253D&md5=0e3d8013376c9075516dee0fbb3c0418

      Fernholz, H. Über Die Umlagerung Des Colchicins Mit Natriumalkoholat Und Die Struktur Des Ringes C. Justus Liebigs Ann. Chem. 1950, 568, 63– 72,  DOI: 10.1002/jlac.19505680106
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
