        Nicholls, G. A.; Tarbell, D. S. Colchicine and Related Compounds. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1953, 75, 1104– 1107,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01101a028
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        110
        Colchicine and related compounds
        Nicholls, Gordon A.; Tarbell, D. Stanley
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1953), 75 (), 1104-7CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        Nitration of colchiceine (I) under mild conditions gave a cryst. nitro compd. which was catalytically reduced in good yield to the corresponding amine. The amine rearranged to a HO carboxylic acid on treatment with HNO2 in the presence of H3PO2. The hydrogenation of colchicine (II) in C6H6 over PtO2 gave 10-15% demethoxyhexahydrocolchicine (III), m. 174-5°, along with a very small amt. of a stereoisomer of III, m. 126-8°, and hexahydrocolchicine (IV), m. about 124°. U.S.P. grade II (50 g.) was chromatographed on grade I-II alkali-free Al2O3, eluted with 850 cc. Me2CO, and the gum (47.3 g.) seeded and twice recrystd. from EtOAc to give pure II, m. 155-7° (decompn.). II (16.0 g.) heated 1.75 hrs. with 160 cc. 0.1N HCl on a steam bath gave I, m. 177-9° (from EtOAc-hexane); the filtrate from the I neutralized with NaHCO3 gave a gelatinous ppt. of 680 mg. trimethylcolchicinic acid, m. 163° (from hot MeOH). To 6.0 g. I in 10 cc. AcOH and 3 cc. H2O was added dropwise 7 cc. of a soln. of 2 cc. HNO3 (d20 1.41), 5 cc. glacial AcOH, and 5 cc. H2O, the mixt. stirred 1 hr. at 0-5°, poured with stirring into 110 cc. ice cold H2O, and the yellow ppt. filtered off, washed twice by stirring 0.5 hr. with 15 cc. H2O each, and recrystd. several times from C6H6 or C6H6-EtOH to give nitrocolchiceine, C21H22N2O8.0.5C6H6 (V), yellow leaflets, m. indefinitely with foaming near 148-50°, darkened on drying in vacuo over P2O5 at 110°. V (1.32 g.) hydrogenated 45 min. in 70 cc. dioxane over 430 mg. PtO2 at 25° gave 78-80% aminocolchiceine, C21H24N2O6 (VI), yellow prisms, m. 269-70° (decompn.) (in vacuum tube), insol. in aq. NaHCO3, sol. in aq. Na2CO3, gave a green color with FeCl3. VI (250 mg.) in 2 g. 30% H3PO2 treated with stirring at 0-5° with 0.5 cc. aq. NaO2 (47 mg.) added dropwise from a capillary, the mixt. kept 1.5 hrs. in an ice bath (during which time the initial orange ppt. decompd. with effervescence to a pale cream ppt.), and the ppt. filtered, washed, dried (245 mg.) and recrystd. from cold. EtOAc-hexane gave a HO carboxylic acid, C21H23NO7 (VII), colorless plates, m. indefinitely with decompn. near 175°, readily sol. in aq. NaHCO3, gave a green color with FeCl3. VII (50 mg.) in 0.5 cc. Ac2O and 1 drop 60% HClO4 from a capillary let stand 15 min. at 25°, the mixt. stirred into 10 cc. H2O, let stand 4 hrs. with frequent scratching, and the cryst. ppt. (47 mg.) recrystd. from cold EtOAc-hexane gave the acetate of VII, C23H25NO8.H2O, colorless prisms, m. indefinitely with decompn. near 190°, readily sol. in aq. NaHCO3. II (4.0 g.) hydrogenated 20 hrs. in 80 cc. C6H6 over 500 mg. prereduced PtO2, the run repeated, the 2 mixts. combined and warmed to dissolve the crystals which had deposited during the hydrogenation, and the soln. filtered and satd. with H2O deposited 1.24 g. III, colorless plates, m. 174-5° [acetate, colorless needles, m. 212.5-13° (from EtOAc satd. with H2O)]; the H2O-satd. combined filtrates from III fractionally concd. over a period of several weeks, and the residues recrystd. from H2O-satd. EtOAc gave 2.64 g. microcryst. solid, m. 100-20°, which on repeated recrystn. from aq. MeOH and EtOAc gave 700 mg. IV, m. indefinitely but near 121-4°. The residue from the mother liquors from III fractionally crystd. from C6H6 and the low-melting fractions recrystd. from Me2CO and EtOAc satd. with H2O gave stereoisomeric III, m. 126-8° (dried at 110° in vacuo over P2O5); acetate, 60%, colorless prisms, m. 169-70° (from aq. MeOH). IV was converted in 58% yield to the acetate (VIII), colorless needles, m. 164.5-65° (from EtOAc-heptane). VIII let stand 1 day at room temp. with 5 cc. MeOH and 15 cc. 0.047N NaOH, the soln. concd. by a cold air stream, and the residue recrystd. from aq. MeOH and H2O-satd. EtOAc gave colorless needles, m. indefinitely but near 122-6°, which, dried 3 weeks at room temp. in a vacuum desiccator, yielded IV, m. 167-7.5° with shrinking at 120°; a sample dried a further 4 hrs. in vacuo over P2O5 167-7.5°. The infrared spectra of V, VI, and VII are recorded.

        Šantavý, F. Préparation de l’acide Colchicique à Partir de La Colchicine. Helv. Chim. Acta 1948, 31, 821– 826,  DOI: 10.1002/hlca.19480310322

        Preparation of colchicic acid from colchicine
        Santavy, Fr.
        Helvetica Chimica Acta (1948), 31 (), 821-6CODEN: HCACAV; ISSN:0018-019X.
        In an attempt to prep. N-methylcolchicine from colchicine (I), 1 g. I is heated in a sealed tube with 0.8 g. MeI and 5 cc. MeOH contg. 0.1 g. Na at 100°, the MeOH distd. off in vacuo at 30°, and the residue acidified with 2 N HCl, giving crude colchicic acid (II), m. 240-60°. I (100 mg.) is refluxed in 2 cc. MeOH, 5 cc. MeOH contg. 0.1 g. Na added, the mixt. heated slowly to boiling, kept there 0.5 hr., the MeOH distd. off in vacuo at 30°, and the residue taken up in 5 cc. H2O and slightly acidified with HCl, giving 70-80% crude or 50-60% pure II, m. 262-6°. When 100 mg. I in 2 cc. MeOH and 0.2 cc. H2O is heated with 5 cc. MeOH contg. 0.1 g. Na, 45% II is formed. I heated with a satd. MeOH-KOH soln. gives 25-35% II. Iso-colchicine heated with MeONa in MeOH also gives II. Colchiceine treated in the same way is recovered unchanged. II, fine needles from CHCl3, EtOAc, or Me2CO-ether, m. 262-6° and sublimes at 240°/0.001 mm. Methylation of 500 mg. II with an excess of CH2N2 in MeOH, evapn. of the MeOH, and extn. of the residue with MeOH or CHCl3 leaves a residue, m. 131-3°. From the ext. Me colchicate (III), prisms, m. 261-2°, [α]20D -141.72 ± 2° (c 1.4112, CHCl3), subliming 220°/0.001 mm., is isolated. III treated with Ac2O in C5H5N is recovered unchanged. Sapon. of III with MeOH-NaOH gives II, λmax. 280 mμ, λmin. 257 mμ (in 0.05 N NaOH). The polarographic curve of II is given.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaH1cXislCqug%253D%253D&md5=0e3d8013376c9075516dee0fbb3c0418

        Fernholz, H. Über Die Umlagerung Des Colchicins Mit Natriumalkoholat Und Die Struktur Des Ringes C. Justus Liebigs Ann. Chem. 1950, 568, 63– 72,  DOI: 10.1002/jlac.19505680106
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        112
        Rearrangement of colchicine with sodium alcoholate and the structure of the C-ring
        Fernholz, Hans
        Justus Liebigs Annalen der Chemie (1950), 568 (), 63-72CODEN: JLACBF; ISSN:0075-4617.
        F. substantiated Santavy's results (C.A. 42, 5891a), obtaining similar conversion products from colchicine (I). However, to avoid confusion, F. proposes the term allocolchiceine (II) for S's "acid colchique" [which is not identical with Zeisel's "colchicinic acid," Monatsh. 9, 1(1888)] and the term allocolchicine (III) for the Me ester of II (which is isomeric with I). Heating 0.5 g. carefully purified I 0.5 hr. with 3 cc. dry MeOH and 0.05 g. Na with exclusion of H2O gave about 0.47 g. III, m. 248° (from MeOH or C6H6), also formed quantitatively by heating 5 g. 18 days with 0.01 g. Na and 30 cc. dry MeOH. Crude I, or the presence of traces of H2O, lowered the yields of III and in the latter case gave II as well as III. I (5 g.) refluxed 1 hr. with 40 cc. 10% NaOH in ordinary MeOH, dild. with H2O, and acidified, gave about 4.5 g. II, m. 254-5° (after crystn. from MeOH and sublimation in a high vacuum to remove solvents). From NaOEt and I in EtOH was formed the Et ester of II, m. 216° (also obtained by transesterification of III). The Pr ester of II, m. 192° (from C6H6-petr. ether), was formed from NaOPr and I, by the transesterification of III, or by the direct esterification of II. III (1.8 g.) was heated 2 hrs. with 20 cc. HBr soln. in glacial AcOH (d. 1.42), dild., concd. on the steam bath, treated with aq. NaOH, filtered, the brown filtrate acidified with aq. H2SO4, the resulting ppt. boiled 3 hrs. with 160 cc. H2O, 5 cc. 2 N NaOH, and 6 g. KMnO4, acidified with H2SO4, treated with SO2 to bleach the soln., satd. with Na2SO4, and extd. with Et2O; the dried, evapd. ext. gave trimellitic acid anhydride (IV), m. 163° (after crystn. from Et2O-C6H6, and vacuum sublimation); free acid, m. 217-220° (on the Cu block). IV was also formed by oxidizing III with 12% HNO3 in AcOH, followed by treatments similar to those outlined above. Possible structures for the C-ring, especially the 7-membered ring proposed by Dewar (C.A. 39, 2067.3) and supported by Arnstein, et al. (C.A. 43, 8376b), are fully discussed. To 1 g. II in 10 cc. concd. H2SO4 and 50 cc. CHCl3 at 40-45°, NaN3 was added very gradually, the mixt., poured into ice H2O, made alk., extd. exhaustively with CHCl3, and the ext. evapd. and treated with aq. H2SO4, giving the H2SO4 salt, m. 183-4°, of the corresponding free base, C20H24O4N2 (V), m. 255-6° (from very dil. MeOH); Bz deriv. of V, m. 287° (from aq. EtOH). Diazotization of V followed by heating gave Windaus' N-acetylcolchinol, m. 150° (from EtOH); Me ether, m. 199° (cf. Windaus, Sitzber. heidelberg. Akad. Wiss., Math.-naturw. Klasse, Abt. A, 16, Abh. (1919)). The C-ring in III therefore appears to have the structure IIIc and it is evident that the structure of the C-ring (VI) in I as suggested by Windaus is untenable.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG3cXjsFymug%253D%253D&md5=89cf145fdbdf746dfebf324063174a95
      113. 113
        Sitnikov, N. S.; Fedorov, A. Y. Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids: A 50 Year Journey. Russ. Chem. Rev. 2013, 82, 393– 411,  DOI: 10.1070/RC2013v082n05ABEH004361
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        113
        Synthesis of allocolchicinoids. A 50 year journey
        Sitnikov, N. S.; Fedorov, A. Yu.
        Russian Chemical Reviews (2013), 82 (5), 393-411, 19 pp.CODEN: RCRVAB; ISSN:0036-021X. (IOP Publishing Ltd.)
        A review. Published data on the stereo- and enantioselective synthesis of allocolchicinoids, which are off interest as antitumor agents, were summarized. The stereochem. of these compds. was described. Two key approaches to their prepn. are considered, namely, the synthesis from natural colchicine and total synthesis from com. available reagents. Various total syntheses of N-acetylcol-chicinol are performed using biaryl oxidative and reductive coupling, cyclopropanation - ring expansion and Nicholas reaction. The synthetic routes to allocolchicine are based on Diels-Alder cycloaddn., combination of metathesis and Diels-Alder reaction and direct catalytic CH-arylation. Analogs of the colchicine site ligands incorporating heteroarom. rings were briefly considered; their structural features and methods of synthesis were discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXht1SqtLbF&md5=ec627e55ce8a11aa223bea86b429b53c

        Thallium in organic synthesis. 59. Alkaloid synthesis via intramolecular nonphenolic oxidative coupling. Preparation of (±)-ocoteine, (±)-acetoxyocoxylonine, (±)-3-methoxy-n-acetylnornantenine, (±)-neolitsine, (±)-kreysigine, (±)-O-methylkreysigine, and (±)-multifloramine
        Taylor, Edward C.; Andrade, Juan G.; Rall, Gerhardus J. H.; McKillop, Alexander
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1980), 102 (21), 6513-19CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        Reaction of 1,2-bis(3,4-dimethoxyphenyl)ethane, 1,3-bis(3,4-dimethoxyphenyl)propane, diveratryl ether, N-methyl-N-veratrylveratramide, and N-methylbis(3,4-dimethoxybenzyl)amine with thallium(III) trifluoroacetate (TTFA) and BF3.Et2O in CH2Cl2/TFA resulted in intramol. nonphenolic coupling to give the resp. bridged biaryl systems, e.g. I. Extensions of this intramol. aryl coupling procedure to appropriately substituted 1-benzyl- and 1-phenethyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinolines have resulted in effective synthesis of the aporphine alkaloids, (±)-ocoteine (II), (±)-acetoxyocoxylonine, and (±)-neolistine, the noraporphine, (±)-3-methoxy-N-acetylnornantenine, and the homoaporphine alkaloids (±)-kreysigine, (±)-O-methylkreysigine, and (±)-multifloramine.

Both the synthetic sample and that obtained from the degrdn. of colchicine were found to exist in soln. as a 3:1 mixt. of conformational isomers at room temp.

        Seganish, W. M.; DeShong, P. Application of Aryl Siloxane Cross-Coupling to the Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids. Org. Lett. 2006, 8, 3951– 3954,  DOI: 10.1021/ol061413t
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        121
        Application of Aryl Siloxane Cross-Coupling to the Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids
        Seganish, W. Michael; DeShong, Philip
        Organic Letters (2006), 8 (18), 3951-3954CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
        Allocolchicinoids I (R = H, MeO) are prepd. using the palladium-catalyzed coupling of aryltrimethoxysilanes and aryl bromides and a two-step ring expansion of (methoxymethoxy)phenanthrenes as key steps. Coupling of aryltrimethoxysilanes 4-RC6H4Si(OMe)3 (R = H, MeO, Me, EtO2C) with 2-bromo-3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde in the presence of palladium acetate and triphenylphosphine and mediated by tetrabutylammonium fluoride yields biphenylcarboxaldehydes II (R = H, MeO, Me, EtO2C) in 87-94% yields. Methoxymethylenation of II (R = H), acid hydrolysis, oxidn. of the arylacetaldehyde to the arylacetic acid, Friedel-Crafts cyclocondensation, and methoxymethylation of the phenanthrenol provides (methoxymethoxy)phenanthrene intermediates III (R = H; MOM = MeOCH2); III (R = MeO) is prepd. by redn. of II (R = MeO) to the biphenylmethanol, conversion to the bromide, substitution of the bromide with potassium cyanide, hydrolysis of the nitrile, acid-catalyzed Friedel-Crafts acylation to a phenanthrenol, and protection of the phenanthrenol with methoxymethyl chloride. Treatment of III (R = H, MeO) with potassium hydroxide, triethylbenzylammonium chloride and chloroform provides dichloro(methoxymethyl)dibenzo[4.1.0]bicycloheptanes which undergo deprotection and ring expansion with aq. hydrochloric acid to provide the chlorodibenzotropolones IV (R = H, MeO). Palladium-catalyzed hydrogenation of IV (R = H, MeO), followed by reductive amination and acetylation by lit. procedures, provides I (R = H, MeO). Redns. or a Suzuki coupling reaction of unsubstituted chlorodibenzotropolone under various conditions yield a dibenzocycloheptanol, a dibenzotropolone, a dibenzocycloheptanone, dand a phenyldibenzotropolone.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XnvVKhur4%253D&md5=385607a5778e95159c55e54408392b16

        Djurdjevic, S.; Green, J. R. Allocolchicines via Intramolecular Nicholas Reactions: The Synthesis of NSC 51046. Org. Lett. 2007, 9, 5505– 5508,  DOI: 10.1021/ol7024422

        Biaryl propargyl acetate hexacarbonyldicobalt complexes I undergo Lewis acid mediated Nicholas reactions with a remote arene function to afford dibenzocycloheptyne complexes II. Reductive decomplexation based on a hydrosilylation-protodesilylation protocol is facile, and the 1,2,3,9-tetramethoxy case can be converted to NSC 51046 [(S)-N-acetylcolchicinol Me ether, (III)].

      123. 123
        Vorogushin, A. V.; Wulff, W. D.; Hansen, H.-J. Central-to-Axial Chirality Transfer in the Benzannulation Reaction of Optically Pure Fischer Carbene Complexes in the Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids. Tetrahedron 2008, 64, 949– 968,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2007.10.115
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        123
        Central-to-Axial Chirality Transfer in the Benzannulation Reaction of Optically Pure Fischer Carbene Complexes in the Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids
        Vorogushin Andrei V; Wulff William D; Hansen Hans-Jurgen
        Tetrahedron (2008), 64 (5), 949-968 ISSN:0040-4020.
        A method for the synthesis of allocolchicinoids is explored that involves the benzannulation reaction of Fischer chromium carbene complexes with alkynes. The benzannulation reaction is employed to install the aromatic C-ring via the reaction of an alpha,beta-unsaturated carbene complex in which the carbene complex is attached to a seven-membered ring that is to become the B-ring of the allocolchicinoids. Two different regioisomeric series can be accessed depending on which position the carbene complex is on the seven membered ring. A key issue that is addressed is the stereochemistry of the newly formed axis of chirality that results from a stereo-relay from an existing chiral center on the seven membered ring at the position destined to be C(7) in the allocolchicinoids. The level of stereochemistry is dependent on the position of the carbene complex on the seven membered ring. A mechanism is proposed to account for this stereochemical dependence and to account for the observed effects of temperature and solvent on the stereoselectivity. Finally, the benzannulation reactions of optically pure complexes are examined and quite surprisingly one, but not both, of the diastereomeric products is racemized. The racemization can be prevented with the proper choice of solvent and temperature. A mechanism is proposed to account for the racemization of only one of the diastereomers of the product that involves the intermediacy of an ortho-quinone methide chromium tricarbonyl complex.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2srlvVSktA%253D%253D&md5=d5132ce4e079f3c984634e376eabfa55
      124. 124
        Mehdi, M. A.; Djurdjevic, S.; Green, J. R. Lewis Acid Catalyzed Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids. Synlett 2015, 26, 2408– 2412,  DOI: 10.1055/s-0034-1378816
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        124
        Lewis Acid Catalyzed Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids
        Mehdi, Mariam A.; Djurdjevic, Sinisa; Green, James R.
        Synlett (2015), 26 (17), 2408-2412CODEN: SYNLES; ISSN:0936-5214. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
        The Lewis acid catalyzed intramol. conjugate addn. of 3',4',5'-trimethoxybiphenyl-2-propenones give the corresponding 8,9,10-trimethoxydibenzocycloheptanones in good yields. A case of a conjugate addn.-cation rearrangement of a 2',3',4'-trimethoxybiphenyl-2-propenone to give the same ring system is also reported. The dibenzocycloheptanones may be converted readily into the 8,9,10-trimethoxy-substituted allocolchicinoids in highly enantioenriched form.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1Glur7M&md5=caa70321c7c69b08f564d08d0a662901
      125. 125
        Vorogushin, A. V.; Predeus, A. V.; Wulff, W. D.; Hansen, H.-J. Diels–Alder Reaction–Aromatization Approach toward Functionalized Ring C Allocolchicinoids. Enantioselective Total Synthesis of (−)-7S-Allocolchicine. J. Org. Chem. 2003, 68, 5826– 5831,  DOI: 10.1021/jo034420t
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        125
        Diels-Alder Reaction-Aromatization Approach toward Functionalized Ring C Allocolchicinoids. Enantioselective Total Synthesis of (-)-7S-Allocolchicine
        Vorogushin, Andrei V.; Predeus, Alexander V.; Wulff, William D.; Hansen, Hans-Juergen
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2003), 68 (15), 5826-5831CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        Allocolchicinoids are analogs of the important antimitotic compd. (-)-colchicine. A strategy is reported for the synthesis of ring C functionalized allocolchicinoids, which is based on a Diels-Alder reaction-aromatization sequence. This route is complementary to the previously disclosed benzannulation approach involving Fischer carbene complexes and alkynes. Dienes I (R=H and Me) incorporate the natural substitution pattern on ring A and undergo Diels-Alder reactions with various dienophiles. Subsequent aromatization affords the set of differently functionalized ring C allocolchicinoids with high regioselectivity and in moderate to good yields. An intramol. Diels-Alder reaction-aromatization sequence allows for access to allocolchicinoids with reversed regiochem. introduction of ring C substituents. The equil. of the atropisomers of II (R1=COOMe, R2=H) and II (R1=H, R2=COOMe) were studied in three NMR solvents. Reactions of the dienes I (R=H and Me) with DMAD lead to the corresponding cycloadducts, but the subsequent aromatization is complicated. A regioselective Diels-Alder reaction-aromatization sequence is utilized as the key step in the first stereoselective total synthesis of (-)-allocolchicine (III). Asym. introduction of hydroxy group at C7 is achieved by the enantioselective redn. of ketone IV. The correct stereochem. is then established by Mitsunobu inversion reaction using Zn(N3)2-2Py.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXkvFWlsL8%253D&md5=48c0fa93ebbaf36c4b6d9cd644e01fb0

        Boyer, F.-D.; Hanna, I. Synthesis of New Allocolchicinoids with Seven- and Eight-Membered B-Rings by Enyne Ring-Closing Metathesis. Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2008, 2008, 4938– 4948,  DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.200800595
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      127. 127
        Leblanc, M.; Fagnou, K. Allocolchicinoid Synthesis via Direct Arylation. Org. Lett. 2005, 7, 2849– 2852,  DOI: 10.1021/ol0505959
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        127
        Allocolchicinoid Synthesis via Direct Arylation
        Leblanc, Melissa; Fagnou, Keith
        Organic Letters (2005), 7 (14), 2849-2852CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
        A formal enantioselective synthesis of allocolchicine and a synthesis of a C-ring analog was achieved by employing an intramol. direct arylation of an aryl chloride to form the biaryl carbon-carbon bond and the seven-membered ring.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXkvFSlsrg%253D&md5=98fcd19f56cc488b67978f0c5565241c
      128. 128
        Corrie, T. J. A.; Lloyd-Jones, G. C. Formal Synthesis of (±)-Allocolchicine Via Gold-Catalysed Direct Arylation: Implication of Aryl Iodine(III) Oxidant in Catalyst Deactivation Pathways. Top. Catal. 2017, 60, 570– 579,  DOI: 10.1007/s11244-017-0742-z
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        128
        Formal Synthesis of (±)-Allocolchicine Via Gold-Catalysed Direct Arylation: Implication of Aryl Iodine(III) Oxidant in Catalyst Deactivation Pathways
        Corrie, Tom J. A.; Lloyd-Jones, Guy C.
        Topics in Catalysis (2017), 60 (8), 570-579CODEN: TOCAFI; ISSN:1022-5528. (Springer)
        A concise formal synthesis of racemic allocolchicine has been developed, centered on three principal transformations: a retro-Brook alkylation reaction to generate an arylsilane, a gold-catalyzed arylative cyclization to generate the B-ring via biaryl linkage, and a palladium-catalyzed carbonylation of an aryl chloride to generate an ester. 1H NMR monitoring of the key gold-catalyzed cyclization step reveals that a powerful catalyst deactivation process progressively attenuates the rate of catalyst turnover. The origins of the catalyst deactivation have been investigated, with an uncatalyzed side-reaction, involving the substrate and the iodine(III) oxidant, identified as the source of a potent catalyst poison. The side reaction generates 1-4% of a diaryliodonium salt, and while this moiety is shown not to be an innate catalyst deactivator, when it is tethered to the arylsilane reactant, the inhibition becomes powerful. Kinetic modeling of processes run at two different catalyst concns. allows extn. of the partitioning of the gold catalyst between the substrate and its diaryliodonium salt, with a rate of diaryliodonium salt generation consistent with that independently detd. in the absence of catalyst. The high partition ratio between substrate and diaryliodonium salt (5/1) results in very efficient, and ultimately complete, diversion of the catalyst off-cycle.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXmtlWkt7s%253D&md5=51b7238f3d267d032920f271be8eaa35

        More, A. A.; Ramana, C. V. Alkyne [2 + 2 + 2]-Cyclotrimerization Approach for Synthesis of 6,7-Cyclopropylallocolchicinoids. J. Org. Chem. 2016, 81, 3400– 3406,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.joc.6b00020
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Alkyne [2 + 2 + 2]-Cyclotrimerization Approach for Synthesis of 6,7-Cyclopropylallocolchicinoids

        Employing a cobalt-catalyzed [2 + 2 + 2] alkyne cyclotrimerization as the final step, the short and efficient synthesis of cyclopropylallocolchicinoid and its analogs having functional group variations at C9 and/or C10 and C11 of ring C has been accomplished.

      130. 130
        Larocque, K.; Ovadje, P.; Djurdjevic, S.; Mehdi, M.; Green, J.; Pandey, S. Novel Analogue of Colchicine Induces Selective Pro-Death Autophagy and Necrosis in Human Cancer Cells. PLoS One 2014, 9, e87064  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0087064
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        130
        Novel analogue of colchicine induces selective pro-death autophagy and necrosis in human cancer cells
        Larocque, Kristen; Ovadje, Pamela; Djurdjevic, Sinisa; Mehdi, Mariam; Green, James; Pandey, Siyaram
        PLoS One (2014), 9 (1), e87064/1-e87064/10, 10 pp.CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
        Colchicine, a natural product of Colchicum autumnae currently used for gout treatment, is a tubulin targeting compd. which inhibits microtubule formation by targeting fast dividing cells. This tubulin-targeting property has lead researchers to investigate the potential of colchicine and analogs as possible cancer therapies. One major study conducted on an analog of allocolchicine, ZD 6126, was halted in phase 2 clin. trials due to severe cardio-toxicity assocd. with treatment. This study involves the development and testing of novel allocolchicine analogs that hold non-toxic anti-cancer properties. Currently we have synthesized and evaluated the anti-cancer activities of two analogs; N-acetyl-O-methylcolchinol (NSC 51046 or NCME), which is structurally similar to ZD 6126, and (S)-3,8,9,10-tetramethoxyallocolchicine (Green 1), which is a novel deriv. of allocolchicine that is isomeric in the A ring. NSC 51046 was found to be non-selective as it induced apoptosis in both BxPC-3 and PANC-1 pancreatic cancer cells and in normal human fibroblasts. Interestingly, we found that Green 1 was able to modestly induce pro-death autophagy in these pancreatic cancer cells and E6-1 leukemia cells but not in normal human fibroblasts. Unlike colchicine and NSC 51046, Green 1 does not appear to affect tubulin polymn. indicating that it has a different mol. target. Green 1 also caused increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) prodn. in mitochondria isolated from pancreatic cancer cells. Furthermore, in vivo studies revealed that Green 1 was well tolerated in mice. Our findings suggest that a small change in the structure of colchicine has apparently changed the mechanism of action and lead to improved selectivity. This may lead to better selective treatments in cancer therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXlsVCqur0%253D&md5=fe7f3f2d1b206fc77476824d326851e1
      131. 131
        Shah, P.; Westwell, A. D. The Role of Fluorine in Medicinal Chemistry. J. Enzyme Inhib. Med. Chem. 2007, 22, 527– 540,  DOI: 10.1080/14756360701425014
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        131
        The role of fluorine in medicinal chemistry
        Shah, Poonam; Westwell, Andrew D.
        Journal of Enzyme Inhibition and Medicinal Chemistry (2007), 22 (5), 527-540CODEN: JEIMAZ; ISSN:1475-6366. (Informa Healthcare)
        A review. The small and highly electroneg. fluorine atom can play a remarkable role in medicinal chem. Selective installation of fluorine into a therapeutic or diagnostic small mol. candidate can enhance a no. of pharmacokinetic and physicochem. properties such as improved metabolic stability and enhanced membrane permeation. Increased binding affinity of fluorinated drug candidates to target protein has also been documented in a no. of cases. A further emerging application of the fluorine atom is the use of 18F as a radiolabel tracer atom in the exquisitely sensitive technique of Positron Emission Tomog. (PET) imaging. This short review aims to bring together these various aspects of the use of fluorine in medicinal chem. applications, citing selected examples from across a variety of therapeutic and diagnostic settings. The increasingly routine incorporation of fluorine atom(s) into drug candidates suggests a bright future for fluorine in drug discovery and development. A major challenge moving forward will be how and where to install fluorine in a rational sense to best optimize mol. properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtFOjtr%252FI&md5=58bc1c42a7525b66772967543256a7d2
      132. 132
        Takubo, K.; Furutsu, K.; Ide, T.; Nemoto, H.; Ueda, Y.; Tsujikawa, K.; Ikawa, T.; Yoshimitsu, T.; Akai, S.         132
        Diversity Oriented Synthesis of Allocolchicinoids with Fluoro and/or Oxygen Substituent(s) on the C-Ring from a Single Common Intermediate
        Takubo, Keita; Furutsu, Kazunori; Ide, Takafumi; Nemoto, Hiroyuki; Ueda, Yuko; Tsujikawa, Kazutake; Ikawa, Takashi; Yoshimitsu, Takehiko; Akai, Shuji
        European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2016), 2016 (8), 1562-1576CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Allocolchicinoids, with a distinct polyoxygenated dibenzocycloheptane skeleton, attract much attention as potential candidate anticancer drugs. In this study, eight C-ring fluorinated analogs of allocolchicinoids, seven C-ring oxygen-substituted analogs, and known compds. N-acetylcolchinol and NSC 51046 were synthesized as racemates from a single common intermediate by using either the deoxyfluorination/migration domino reaction or acid-promoted migration as the key step. Among the products obtained, some of the fluorinated derivs. strongly inhibited the growth of prostate DU145 and pancreas Panc 1 cancer cell lines with efficacy comparable to or better than those of N-acetylcolchinol and NSC 51046. They were also less toxic against a non-cancerous cell line than the known compds. were.

        Yang, B.; Zhu, Z. C.; Goodson, H. V.; Miller, M. J. Syntheses and Biological Evaluation of Ring-C Modified Colchicine Analogs. Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2010, 20, 3831– 3833,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmcl.2010.03.056

        133
        Syntheses and biological evaluation of ring-C modified colchicine analogs
        Yang, Baiyuan; Zhu, Zhiqing C.; Goodson, Holly V.; Miller, Marvin J.
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2010), 20 (12), 3831-3833CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Ring-C modified alkaloids (e.g. I) were synthesized from colchicine using iminonitroso Diels-Alder reactions in a highly regio- and stereoselective fashion. Several analogs exhibited cytotoxic activity similar to that of colchicine itself against PC-3 and MCF-7 cancer cell lines, by serving as prodrugs of colchicine through retro Diels-Alder reactions under the assayed conditions. In vitro microtubule polymn. assays indicated that these modifications affected their interaction with tubulin.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXntVClsrw%253D&md5=94b333a3a31ce9383979e8b08f3c6796
      134. 134
        Joncour, A.; Décor, A.; Liu, J.-M.; Tran Huu Dau, M.-E.; Baudoin, O. Asymmetric Synthesis of Antimicrotubule Biaryl Hybrids of Allocolchicine and Steganacin. Chem. - Eur. J. 2007, 13, 5450– 5465,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200601764
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        134
        Asymmetric synthesis of antimicrotubule biaryl hybrids of allocolchicine and steganacin
        Joncour, Agnes; Decor, Anne; Liu, Jian-Miao; Dau, Marie-Elise Tran Huu; Baudoin, Olivier
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (19), 5450-5465, S5450/1-S5450/56CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The asym. synthesis of novel axially chiral biaryl compds. contg. a seven- or eight-membered heterocyclic medium ring is described. These mols. can be considered to be structural hybrids of allocolchicine- and steganacin-type natural products. The synthesis featured an atropo-diastereoselective biaryl Suzuki coupling in which a benzylic stereocenter efficiently transferred its stereochem. information to the biaryl axis. The coupling conditions were optimized, and two biphenylphosphane ligands (DavePhos and S-Phos) were found to give the highest yields and diastereoselectivities. A three-element stereochem. model was proposed to explain the obsd. diastereoselectivities. In a second key step, the medium ring of the target mols. was formed by a stereoselective SN1-type cyclodehydration that probably involved a configurationally stable carbocationic intermediate, as supported by calcns. Alternatively, SN2-type cyclizations were employed on the same Suzuki coupling products to give the target mols. in a stereodivergent or stereoconvergent manner. These cyclization methods furnished the target hybrid analogs with ee values above 94%. All analogs were evaluated as antimicrotubule agents and against a panel of cancer cell lines using colchicine and N-acetylcolchinol as refs. Promising activities were found for R,aR-configured compds. I (R = Me, Et) and II; in particular, Et analog I (R = Et) showed a twofold antimicrotubule activity relative to colchicine.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXns1Cqtrw%253D&md5=278d15add6dd1cc320d3ef4727ec8b8d

        Efficient Synthesis of Dibenzo[a,c]cyclohepten-5-ones via a Sequential Suzuki-Miyaura Coupling and Aldol Condensation Reaction
        Choi, Young Lok; Yu, Chan-Mo; Kim, Bum Tae; Heo, Jung-Nyoung
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74 (10), 3948-3951CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        A common strategy for the synthesis of a 7-membered-ring system with a Suzuki-Miyaura coupling followed by an acid/base-promoted intramol. aldol condensation reaction has been developed. The reaction of 2'-bromoacetophenones with 2-formylphenylboronic acids in the presence of Pd(OAc)2 and CataCXium PIntB efficiently provided biaryl compds., which were transformed to a wide array of dibenzo[a,c]cyclohepten-5-ones in excellent yields by a sequential treatment with p-TsOH, followed by 10% aq NaOH.

        Tubulin-binding dibenz[c,e]oxepines as colchinol analogues for targeting tumour vasculature
        Edwards, David J.; Hadfield, John A.; Wallace, Timothy W.; Ducki, Sylvie
        Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2011), 9 (1), 219-231CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Various methoxy- and hydroxy-substituted dibenz[c,e]oxepines were prepd. via the copper(I)-induced coupling of ether-tethered arylstannanes or the dehydrative cyclization of 1,1'-biphenyl-2,2'-dimethanols, assembled using the Ullmann cross-coupling of ortho-bromoaryl carbonyl compds. The dibenzoxepines were screened for their ability to inhibit tubulin polymn. and the in vitro growth of K562 human chronic myelogenous leukemia cells. The most active was 5,7-dihydro-3,9,10,11-tetramethoxydibenz[c,e]oxepin-4-ol, whose tubulin inhibitory and cytotoxicity (IC50) values were 1 μM and 40 nM, resp.

        138
        Synthesis of Diverse 6-Oxa-allocolchicinoids by a Suzuki-Miyaura Coupling, Acid-Catalyzed Intramolecular Transacetalization Strategy
        Yadav, Dharmendra B.; Taleli, Lebusetsa; van der Westhuyzen, Alet E.; Fernandes, Manuel A.; Dragoun, Maxim; Prokop, Aram; Schmalz, Hans-Guenther; de Koning, Charles B.; van Otterlo, Willem A. L.
        European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2015), 2015 (23), 5167-5182CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The synthesis of allocolchicine analogs is of importance as these compds. have been found to possess promising anticancer activity by affecting tubulin polymn. In this paper, the synthesis of 28 novel substituted 6-oxa-allocolchicinoids was reported. The key steps involved in the synthesis were a Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reaction, followed by an acid-catalyzed intramol. transacetalization to afford the desired 5-alkoxy-5,7-dihydrodibenz[c,e]oxepins, e.g., I. In addn., when thiophenol and phenol were used in the transacetalization step, the 5-(phenylsulfanyl)-5,7-dihydrodibenz[c,e]oxepin and 4-(5,7-dihydrodibenz[c,e]oxepin-5-yl)phenol, e.g., II, skeletons were obtained, resp. The cytotoxicity of the synthetic compds. was unfortunately not impressive; however, one of the compds. was shown to sensitize vincristine-resistant leukemia and lymphoma cells to vincristine, a result vindicating further synthetic studies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        A [2 + 2 + 2]-Cycloaddition Approach toward 6-Oxa-allocolchicinoids with Apoptosis-Inducing Activity

[2 + 2 + 2]-cycloaddn. (alkyne cyclotrimerization) as a key step. The approach opens a short and efficient access to a variety of novel compds., some of which were found to exhibit significant and selective apoptosis-inducing activities against BJAB tumor cells.

        Total Synthesis of Indole-Derived Allocolchicine Analogues Exhibiting Strong Apoptosis-Inducing Activity
        Sitnikov, Nikolay; Velder, Janna; Abodo, Liliane; Cuvelier, Nicole; Neudoerfl, Joerg; Prokop, Aram; Krause, Guenter; Fedorov, Aleksey Y.; Schmalz, Hans-Guenther
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (38), 12096-12102, S12096/1-S12096/54CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A series of novel pyrrolo-allocolchicine derivs. (contg. a 1-methyl-1H-indol-5-yl moiety replacing ring C), e.g., I, was synthesized. The tetracyclic ring system was constructed by Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling of a 1-methylindole-5-boronate with an ortho-iodo-dihydrocinnamic acid deriv. and subsequent intramol. Friedel-Crafts acylation. After redn. of the resulting ketone, the nitrogen functionality was introduced in a Mitsunobu-type reaction by using zinc azide followed by LiAlH4 redn. Structural assignments were supported by X-ray crystallog. The compds. synthesized were then tested against BJAB tumor cells and found to exhibit pronounced cytotoxic activity (proliferation inhibition and apoptosis induction). The ketone I was even active at sub-nanomolar concn. In addn., the antitumor potential of the compds. was confirmed by using B lymphoid cell lines.

        Synthesis of indole-derived allocolchicine congeners through Pd-catalyzed intramolecular C-H arylation reaction
        Sitnikov, Nikolay S.; Kokisheva, Antonina S.; Fukin, Georgy K.; Neudoerfl, Joerg-Martin; Sutorius, Hannah; Prokop, Aram; Fokin, Valery V.; Schmalz, Hans-Guenther; Fedorov, Alexey Yu.
        European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2014), 2014 (29), 6481-6492CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The synthesis of several new heterocyclic structural analogs of the natural antimitotic agent allocolchicine is reported. As a key step an intramol. Pd-catalyzed C-H arylation reaction was used to close the seven-membered ring fused with two electron-rich aryl fragments. The stereostructure of the target compds. was detd. by x-ray crystal anal. The primary biol. assessment of the synthesized compds. was carried out on human lymphoma cells. Several allocolchicinoids were detd. to possess antiproliferative and apoptosis-inducing activity in the micromolar concn. range.

        Synthesis of indole-derived allocolchicine congeners exhibiting pronounced anti-proliferative and apoptosis-inducing properties
        Sitnikov, Nikolay S.; Sinzov, Alexander V.; Allegro, Diane; Barbier, Pascale; Combes, Sebastien; Onambele, Liliane Abodo; Prokop, Aram; Schmalz, Hans-Gunther; Fedorov, Alexey Yu.

        Based on the natural antimitotic agent allocolchicine as a lead structure, a series of novel indole-based allocolchicine congeners was synthesized and assessed in vitro for their cytostatic properties. Several compds. exhibited potent anti-proliferative and apoptosis-inducing activity towards lymphoma cells along with low unspecific cytotoxicity. The obsd. activity is supposed to result from the inhibition of microtubule assembly, as indicated by the tubulin polymn. assay.

        Shchegravina, E. S.; Knyazev, D. I.; Beletskaya, I. P.; Svirshchevskaya, E. V.; Schmalz, H.-G.; Fedorov, A. Y. Synthesis of Nonracemic Pyrrolo-Allocolchicinoids Exhibiting Potent Cytotoxic Activity. Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2016, 2016, 5620– 5623,  DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201601069

        144
        Synthesis of Nonracemic Pyrrolo-allocolchicinoids Exhibiting Potent Cytotoxic Activity
        Shchegravina, Ekaterina S.; Knyazev, Dmitry I.; Beletskaya, Irina P.; Svirshchevskaya, Elena V.; Schmalz, Hans-Guenther; Fedorov, Alexey Yu.
        European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2016), 2016 (34), 5620-5623CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An efficient eight-step semisynthetic approach towards nonracemic pyrrolo-allocolchicinoids starting from natural colchicine was developed by exploiting Pd-catalyzed domino Sonogashira coupling/5-endo-dig cyclization of a 2-iodo-trifluoroacetanilide intermediate to build up the heterocyclic ring system (e.g., I + propargyl t-butyldimethylsilyl ether → II →→ III). The N-Me substitution of the pyrrole ring enhanced the antitumor activity of the prepd. mols. by 2-3 orders of magnitude. Among the active compds., the N-methylated colchicinoid III exhibited powerful cytotoxic and antiproliferative properties at concns. < 1 nM.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhsl2hsrjK&md5=3492564936e1844051654759631db2b9

        Shchegravina, E. S.; Maleev, A. A.; Ignatov, S. K.; Gracheva, I. A.; Stein, A.; Schmalz, H.-G.; Gavryushin, A. E.; Zubareva, A. A.; Svirshchevskaya, E. V.; Fedorov, A. Y.         145
        Synthesis and biological evaluation of novel non-racemic indole-containing allocolchicinoids
        Shchegravina, Ekaterina S.; Maleev, Alexander A.; Ignatov, Stanislav K.; Gracheva, Iuliia A.; Stein, Andreas; Schmalz, Hans-Gunther; Gavryushin, Andrey E.; Zubareva, Anastasiya A.; Svirshchevskaya, Elena V.; Fedorov, Alexey Yu.
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 141 (), 51-60CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        Two novel indole-contg. allocolchicinoids were prepd. from naturally occurring colchicine exploiting the Curtius rearrangement and tandem Sonogashira coupling/Pd-catalyzed cyclization as the key transformations. Their cytotoxic properties, apoptosis-inducing activity, tubulin assembly inhibition and short-time cytotoxic effects were investigated. Compd. I demonstrated the most pronounced anti-cancer activity: IC50 < 1 nM, cell cycle arrest in the G2/M phase, 25% apoptosis induction, as well as lower destructive short-time effects on HT-29 cell line in comparison with colchicine. Docking studies for prepd. indole-derived allocolchicine analogs were carried out.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhs1GmurvE&md5=607b1cc44e87c188e5bc723f228b28f9
      146. 146
        Shchegravina, E.; Svirshchevskaya, E.; Schmalz, H.-G.; Fedorov, A. A Facile Synthetic Approach to Nonracemic Substituted Pyrrolo-Allocolchicinoids Starting from Natural Colchicine. Synthesis 2019, 51, 1611– 1622,  DOI: 10.1055/s-0037-1610673
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        146
        A Facile Synthetic Approach to Nonracemic Substituted Pyrrolo-allocolchicinoids Starting from Natural Colchicine
        Shchegravina, Ekaterina S.; Svirshchevskaya, Elena V.; Schmalz, Hans-Gunther; Fedorov, Alexey Yu
        Synthesis (2019), 51 (7), 1611-1622CODEN: SYNTBF; ISSN:1437-210X. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
        A six-step semi-synthetic approach towards chiral nonracemic pyrrolo-allocolchicinoids, e.g., I, starting from naturally occurring colchicine was developed. The synthetic scheme includes an electrocyclic tropolone ring contraction to afford allocolchicinic acid followed by the Curtius reaction, giving the corresponding aniline. The Sandmeyer reaction and copper-mediated hydrazination gave hydrazine-substituted allocolchicine. This was introduced into the Fischer indole synthesis, affording libraries of regioisomeric indole-based allocolchicine congeners.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFWqsbfL&md5=2a40be835adf5821d177a5188bd3b5a9

        Voitovich, Y. V.; Shegravina, E. S.; Sitnikov, N. S.; Faerman, V. I.; Fokin, V. V.; Schmalz, H.-G.; Combes, S.; Allegro, D.; Barbier, P.; Beletskaya, I. P.; Svirshchevskaya, E.         147
        Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Furanoallocolchicinoids
        Voitovich, Yuliya V.; Shegravina, Ekaterina S.; Sitnikov, Nikolay S.; Faerman, Vladimir I.; Fokin, Valery V.; Schmalz, Hans-Gunther; Combes, Sebastien; Allegro, Diane; Barbier, Pascal; Beletskaya, Irina P.; Svirshchevskaya, Elena V.; Fedorov, Alexey Yu.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 58 (2), 692-704CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A series of conformationally flexible furan-derived allocolchicinoids was prepd. from com. available colchicine in good to excellent yields using a three-step reaction sequence. Cytotoxicity studies indicated the potent activity of two compds. against human epithelial and lymphoid cell lines (AsPC-1, HEK293, and Jurkat) as well as against Wnt-1 related murine epithelial cell line W1308. The results of in vitro expts. demonstrated that the major effect of these compds. was the induction of cell cycle arrest in the G2/M phase as a direct consequence of effective tubulin binding. In vivo testing of the most potent furanoallocolchicinoid I using C57BL/6 mice inoculated with Wnt-1 tumor cells indicated significant inhibition of the tumor growth.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXitVyhsr3J&md5=e82912b440db9dd48ed85a2345f14889

        Reaction of hydroxyl-contg. heterocyclic colchicinoids with S-nucleophiles led to the formation of furanoallocolchicinoid sulfides I [R = H, Me; R' = cyclopentyl, CH2CO2Me, R''] in a high yield.

        Gracheva, I. A.; Voitovich, I. V.; Faerman, V. I.; Sitnikov, N. S.; Myrsikova, E. V.; Schmalz, H.-G.; Svirshevskaya, E. V.; Fedorov, A. Y.         149
        Synthesis and cytostatic properties of polyfunctionalized furanoallocolchicinoids
        Gracheva, Iuliia A.; Voitovich, Iuliia V.; Faerman, Vladimir I.; Sitnikov, Nikolay S.; Myrsikova, Ekaterina V.; Schmalz, Hans-Gunther; Svirshevskaya, Elena V.; Fedorov, Alexey Yu
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 126 (), 432-443CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of furan-based allocolchicinoids was prepd. from com. available colchicine via a nine-step reaction sequence. Cytostatic activity, cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, tubulin and F-actin expression were studied in vitro in 2D and 3D cultures of normal and tumor epithelial keratinocytes, endothelial and mesenchymal cells. Among the prepd. furanoallocolchicine analogs, I (X = O) and I (X = OH) displayed the most pronounced anticancer activity. These compds. induced two types of effects: (a) cell cycle arrest in the G2/M phase as a direct consequence of effective tubulin binding (metaphase effect), and (b) pronounced cell stress (as evidenced by the overexpression of tubulin and F-actin), which was caused by the hyperpolarization of mitochondrial and lysosomal membranes (interphase effect).
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvFymtrfN&md5=7e1a59e0cd4cde42b699494d026a8571
      150. 150
        Gracheva, I. A.; Svirshchevskaya, E. V.; Zaburdaeva, E. A.; Fedorov, A. Y. Synthesis of Bifunctional Furano-Allocolchicinoids. Synthesis 2017, 49, 4335– 4340,  DOI: 10.1055/s-0036-1589060
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        150
        Synthesis of Bifunctional Furano-Allocolchicinoids
        Gracheva, Iuliia A.; Svirshchevskaya, Elena V.; Zaburdaeva, Elena A.; Fedorov, Alexey Yu.
        Synthesis (2017), 49 (18), 4335-4340CODEN: SYNTBF; ISSN:1437-210X. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
        An efficient seven-step semisynthetic approach towards non-racemic bifunctional furano-allocolchicinoids, starting from naturally occurring colchicine is presented. The Pd-catalyzed domino Sonogashira coupling/5-endo-dig cyclization was employed as the key step [e.g., I + propargyl alc. → II (81%)]. The prepd. compds. exhibited substantial cytotoxicity against T3M4, MiaPaCa-2, Colo-357, and PANC-1 cell lines. The presence of two functionalities with different reactivity (hydroxyl and amino groups) in the target mols. allows for an easy conjugation of furano-allocolchicinoids with drug delivery carriers, and opens promising opportunities for their further exploitation in the search of therapeutics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVKnsbjL&md5=a80b8a9f1f6c76987913a98570c5b59e

        Gracheva, I. A.; Svirshchevskaya, E. S.; Faerman, V. I.; Beletskaya, I. P.; Fedorov, A. Y. Synthesis and Antiproliferative Properties of Bifunctional Allocolchicine Derivatives. Synthesis 2018, 50, 2753– 2760,  DOI: 10.1055/s-0037-1610146

        151
        Synthesis and Antiproliferative Properties of Bifunctional Allocolchicine Derivatives
        Gracheva, Iuliia A.; Svirshchevskaya, Elena V.; Faerman, Vladimir I.; Beletskaya, Irina P.; Fedorov, Alexey Yu.
        Synthesis (2018), 50 (14), 2753-2760CODEN: SYNTBF; ISSN:1437-210X. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
        Based on the natural antimitotic agent colchifoline as a lead structure, a series of novel bifunctional allocolchicine congeners were synthesized from com. colchicine. The new derivs. maintain good cytotoxicity against T3M4, MiaPaCa-2, and PANC-1 cell lines. The presence of functional groups simplifies further modifications of the prepd. structures and the design of novel colchicine-derived antitumor compds. with desired pharmacol. properties.

        Shi, Q.; Verdier-Pinard, P.; Brossi, A.; Hamel, E.; Lee, K.-H. Antitumor Agents—CLXXV. Anti-Tubulin Action of (+)-Thiocolchicine Prepared by Partial Synthesis. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 1997, 5, 2277– 2282,  DOI: 10.1016/S0968-0896(97)00171-5
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        152
        Antitumor agents. CLXXV. Anti-tubulin action of (+)-thiocolchicine prepared by partial synthesis
        Shi, Qian; Verdier-Pinard, Pascal; Brossi, Arnold; Hamel, Ernest; Lee, Kuo-Hsiung
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (1997), 5 (12), 2277-2282CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        (+)-Thiocolchicine was prepd. from (±)-colchicine in a five-step reaction sequence that included chromatog. sepn. of appropriate camphanylated diastereomers. Acid hydrolysis of the (+)-diastereomer, followed by acetylation, yielded the desired product (+)-thiocolchicine. (+)-Thiocolchicine has 15-fold lower inhibitory activity against tubulin polymn. than (-)-thiocolchicine, and is 29-fold less potent for inhibiting growth of human Burkitt lymphoma cells. (-)-Thiocolchicine, prepd. from the (-)-camphanylated diastereomer, had potent activity in all assays comparable to that prepd. by other methods. These results support the hypothesis that the proper configuration of colchicine-related compds. is an important requirement for their anti-tubulin action.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXjsVSktw%253D%253D&md5=c3c0eefb611db8e6a3956f733d1af573

        Zweig, M. H.; Chignell, C. F. Interaction of Some Colchicine Analogs, Vinblastine and Podophyllotoxin with Rat Brain Microtubule Protein. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1973, 22, 2141– 2150,  DOI: 10.1016/0006-2952(73)90113-5

        153
        Interaction of colchicine analogs, vinblastine, and podophyllotoxin with rat brain microtubule protein
        Zweig, Mark H.; Chignell, Colin F.
        Biochemical Pharmacology (1973), 22 (17), 2141-50CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
        Tritiated colchicine (I) [64-86-8] was competitively displaced from rat brain microtubule protein by colchiceinamide [3123-89-5], N-deacetylthiocolchicine [2731-16-0], demecolcine [477-30-5], N-acetyliodocolchinol [38838-27-6], trimethylcolchicinic acid Me ether [36191-19-2], N-acetylcolchinol [38838-26-5], or trimethylcolchicinic acid Et ether [36191-20-5]. Ten other I analogs including isocolchicine and colchiceine did not inhibit the binding of I to rat brain microtubule protein. The ability of a given analog to displace I from the microtubule protein correlated well within its antimitotic and antigout properties. Podophyllotoxin [518-28-5] and vinblastine [865-21-4] inhibited 3H-labeled I binding by a competitive and a noncompetitive mechanism, resp.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE2cXit1Gnug%253D%253D&md5=bcdf49e245df8e32069114e45171a990
      154. 154
        Bartusik, D.; Tomanek, B.; Lattová, E.; Perreault, H.; Tuszynski, J.; Fallone, G. Derivatives of Thiocolchicine and Its Applications to CEM Cells Treatment Using 19F Magnetic Resonance Ex Vivo. Bioorg. Chem. 2010, 38, 1– 6,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bioorg.2009.10.002
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        154
        Derivatives of thiocolchicine and its applications to CEM cells treatment using 19F Magnetic Resonance ex vivo
        Bartusik, Dorota; Tomanek, Boguslaw; Lattova, Erika; Perreault, Helene; Tuszynski, Jack; Fallone, Gino
        Bioorganic Chemistry (2010), 38 (1), 1-6CODEN: BOCMBM; ISSN:0045-2068. (Elsevier Inc.)
        It was shown, that cultured ex vivo human T-Lymphoblastoid (CEM) cells respond to synthesized thiocolchicine and fluorine thiocolchicine derivs. The prepn. of derivs. with substitution at C-3 and C-7 is described. All compds. were used at concn. from 1 nM to 1000 nM. Inhibitory effects of these compds. were examd. in the three-dimensional (3-D) culture and cells morphol. during treatment was monitored using 9.4 T MRI system. We performed studies of these compds. in CEM cells ex vivo using 1H and 19F Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), 19F Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (MRS), High Performance Liq. Chromatog. coupled with Ultra Violet (HPLC-UV) and Electron Impact Mass Spectrometry (EIMS). The results of the multi-technique approach are consistent with the fact that the new derivs. are more efficient than colchicine and thiocolchicine ex vivo.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjtlyqsA%253D%253D&md5=70a24b1c019a8d7038b56e101ab9292e
      155. 155
        Hastie, S. B.; Williams, R. C.; Puett, D.; Macdonald, T. L. The Binding of Isocolchicine to Tubulin. Mechanisms of Ligand Association with Tubulin. J. Biol. Chem. 1989, 264, 6682– 6688
        [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        155
        The binding of isocolchicine to tubulin. Mechanisms of ligand association with tubulin
        Hastie, Susan Bane; Williams, Robley C., Jr.; Puett, David; Macdonald, Timothy L.
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (1989), 264 (12), 6682-8CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258.
        Isocolchicine (I) is a structurally related isomer of colchicine (II) altered in the methoxytropone C ring. In spite of virtual structural homol. of I and II, I is commonly believed to be inactive in binding to tubulin and in inhibiting microtubule assembly. Here, I was found to bind to the II site on tubulin, as demonstrated by its ability to competitively inhibit [3H]II binding to tubulin with a Ki of ∼400 μM. I inhibited tubulin assembly into microtubules with an I50 of ∼1 mM, but the affinity of I for the II receptor site (5.5 × 103 M-1 at 23°) was much less (∼500-fold) than that of II. Unlike II, I bound rapidly, and the absorption and fluorescence properties of the complex were only modestly altered compared to free ligand. It was proposed that the binding of I to tubulin be rationalized either in terms of conformational states of colchicinoids when liganded to tubulin or by the structural requirements for C-10 substituents for high affinity binding to the II receptor.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXitVyis78%253D&md5=aa9e3d028a51229a1fbc8f5d47e78f77

        Rapoport, H.; Lavigne, J. B. The Preparation of Colchicide (Demethoxycolchicine). J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1955, 77, 667– 670,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01608a038

        157
        The preparation of colchicide (demethoxycolchicine)
        Rapoport, Henry; Lavigne, Joe B.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1955), 77 (), 667-70CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The reaction of colchicine (I) with MeSH in the presence of ZnCl2 resulted in the replacement of the methoxy group by MeS to give methylthiocolchicide (II). Partial desulfurization with Ni afforded the tropone, colchicide (III), which formed a HCl salt and was hydrogenated to tetrahydrodemethoxycolchicine (IV). Purified I (6.0 g.) and 0.42 g. fused ZnCl2 heated in vacuo 0.5 hr. at 135°, the mixt. treated at 0° with 75 g. MeSH, heated in a sealed tube 5.5 hrs. on the steam bath, and evapd. in vacuo at room temp., the residue treated with 10 cc. H2O and extd. with CHCl3, the ext. washed, dried, and evapd. in vacuo, the residue dissolved in EtOAc, the soln. evapd., the residue heated 12 hrs. at 95° (5.53 g.), dissolved in 55 cc. C6H6, chromatographed on 90 g. Al2O3, and eluted with 500 cc. C6H6, 250 cc. 0.5% abs. EtOH-C6H6, and 1400 cc. 1% abs. EtOH-C6H6, the 1% abs. EtOH-C6H6 eluate evapd., and the residue crystd. from EtOAc and dried at 135° in vacuo yielded 4.48 g. II, m. 189-90°, [α]D28 -191° (c 0.94, CHCl3); all m.ps. are cor. The column eluted further with 120 cc. Me2CO gave 0.11 g. unchanged I, m. 152-4°. II (500 mg.) in 1.5 cc. 15% Me2NH in MeOH heated 24 hrs. in a sealed tube at 100°, the mixt. evapd., the residue dissolved in C6H6 and extd. with C6H6, the ext. dried, and evapd., and the residue recrystd. from EtOAc gave 230 mg. N,N-dimethylaminocolchicide, m. 174-6°. II (500 mg.) in 100 cc. 90% aq. EtOH refluxed 18 hrs. under N with stirring with 10 g. Raney Ni, the mixt. filtered, the filter residue digested with two 50-cc. portions of boiling C6H6, the combined filtrate and digests evapd., and the residue recrystd. from C6H6 gave 180 mg. hexahydrodemethoxycolchicine, m. 170-1°. Raney Ni (10 g.) washed with five 15-cc. portions Me2CO, heated in 50 cc. refluxing Me2CO 10.5 hrs. with stirring under N, treated with 500 mg. II in 50 cc. Me2CO, refluxed 17 hrs. with stirring and filtered, the filter residue washed with Me2CO, and the combined filtrate and washings evapd. in vacuo yielded 460 mg. pale yellow residue contg. 30% II. A similar run with 5.71 g. II gave 5.31 g. residue contg. 20% unreacted II. The combined residues (5.77 g., contg. approx. 21% II) dissolved in 65 cc. C6H6 and chromatographed on 1100 g. Al2O3 with a flow rate of 1 l./hr., the column developed with 2 l. C6H6 and eluted with 32 l. 0.5% EtOH in C6H6 and 4 l. 1% EtOH in C6H6, the eluate concd. in vacuo, and the yellow solid residue (1.66 g.) crystd. from EtOAc gave 0.88 g. II; the next fraction (8 l.) concd. in vacuo gave 3.03 g. III.H2O, light yellow glass, which gave dried at 60° and 0.03 mm. overnight anhyd. III, m. 105-20°, [α]D25 -87° (c 1.01, C6H6), [α]D27 -260° (c 0.42, EtOH), -196° (c 0.47, CHCl3). III in MeOH gave with aq. FeCl3 a red color which disappeared on diln. III (200 mg.) in 2 cc. C6H6 and 10 cc. Et2O treated dropwise with about 2 cc. ethereal HCl, the pptd. gum rubbed to solidify and centrifuged, the solid washed with C6H6 and dried, the product (246 mg.) dissolved in 40 cc. EtOAc at 75° during 3-4 min., and the soln. cooled overnight gave 146 mg. III.H2O.HCl, long, yellow needles, m. 119-21°. III.H2O.HCl in C6H6 heated 10 min. on the steam bath, chromatographed on Al2O3, and eluted successively with C6H6 and 0.5% abs. EtOH in C6H6 gave 100% III, [α]D23 -256° (c 0.6, EtOH). III.H2O (200 mg.) in 20 cc. EtOH hydrogenated 40 min. at atm. pressure and room temp. over 80 mg. 5% Pd-BaSO4, the mixt. filtered and evapd., the residue chromatographed with 0.5% abs. EtOH in C6H6 on Al2O3, and the crude product (154 mg.) recrystd. from EtOAc-Bu2O yielded 81 mg. IV, m. 142-3°. III acted as mitotic poison in the same manner as I on the isolated mitotic app. of the sea urchine egg and is markedly less toxic to mice than is I.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG28Xot1al&md5=adc5c3d1bc33816d7da564fd2c9274b6

        Brossi, A.; Sharma, P. N.; Atwell, L.; Jacobson, A. E.; Iorio, M. A.; Molinari, M.; Chignell, C. F. Biological Effects of Modified Colchicines. 2. Evaluation of Catecholic Colchicines, Colchifolines, Colchicide, and Novel N-Acyl- and N-Aroyldeacetylcolchicines. J. Med. Chem. 1983, 26, 1365– 1369,  DOI: 10.1021/jm00364a006
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        158
        Biological effects of modified colchicines. 2. Evaluation of catecholic colchicines, colchifolines, colchicide, and novel N-acyl- and N-aroyldeacetylcolchicines
        Brossi, Arnold; Sharma, Padam N.; Atwell, Louise; Jacobson, Arthur E.; Iorio, Maria A.; Molinari, Marisa; Chignell, Colin F.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1983), 26 (10), 1365-9CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
        The title compds. I (R1 = Me, R2 = H, Me, or phenyltetrazolyl; R3 = Me or phenyltetrazolyl; R4 = H, R5 = Ac, COCH2OH, COCH2OAc, Bz, etc.; R6 = H, OH, or MeO) and II (R = CH2Me, CH2CH2Me, OEt, 3,4,5-(MeO)3C6H2) were prepd. and most of them as well as several analogs previously prepd. tested for their potency in the lymphocytic leukemia P388 screen in mice, for their toxicity in mice, and for their binding to microtubule protein. N-(Carbetoxydeacetylcolchicine (I; R1 = R2 = R3 = R6 = MeO, R4 = H, R5 = CO2Et) [86436-42-2] showed good biol. properties and colchicide (I; R1 = R2 = R3 = Me, R4 = R6 = H, R5 = Ac) [518-15-0] was highly potent in vivo. Structure-activity relations are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Cosentino, L.; Redondo-Horcajo, M.; Zhao, Y.; Santos, A. R.; Chowdury, K. F.; Vinader, V.; Abdallah, Q. M. A.; Abdel-Rahman, H.; Fournier-Dit-Chabert, J.; Shnyder, S. D. Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Colchicine B-Ring Analogues Tethered with Halogenated Benzyl Moieties. J. Med. Chem. 2012, 55, 11062– 11066,  DOI: 10.1021/jm301151t

        159
        Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Colchicine B-Ring Analogues Tethered with Halogenated Benzyl Moieties
        Cosentino, Laura; Redondo-Horcajo, Mariano; Zhao, Ying; Santos, Ana Rita; Chowdury, Kaniz F.; Vinader, Victoria; Abdallah, Qasem M. A.; Abdel-Rahman, Hamdy; Fournier-Dit-Chabert, Jeremie; Shnyder, Steven D.; Loadman, Paul M.; Fang, Wei-shuo; Diaz, Jose Fernando; Barasoain, Isabel; Burns, Philip A.; Pors, Klaus
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 55 (24), 11062-11066CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        Deacetylcolchicine was reacted with substituted benzyl halides to provide a library of compds. for biol. anal. Compd. 7 (3,4-difluorobenzyl-N-aminocolchicine) was shown to possess cytotoxicity in cancer cell lines in the low nanomolar range. Significantly, it showed no loss of activity in the resistant A2780AD ovarian carcinoma cell line known to overexpress the ABCB1 drug transporter and was also unaffected by overexpression of class III β-tubulin in HeLa transfected cells.

        Synthesis, antiproliferative activity and molecular docking of colchicine derivatives
        Huczynski, Adam; Majcher, Urszula; Maj, Ewa; Wietrzyk, Joanna; Janczak, Jan; Moshari, Mahshad; Tuszynski, Jack A.; Bartl, Franz
        Bioorganic Chemistry (2016), 64 (), 103-112CODEN: BOCMBM; ISSN:0045-2068. (Elsevier B.V.)
        To create more potent anticancer agents, a series of five structurally different derivs. of Colchicine have been synthesized. These compds. were characterized spectroscopically and structurally and their antiproliferative activity against four human tumor cell lines (HL-60, HL-60/vinc, LoVo, LoVo/DX) was evaluated. Addnl. the activity of the studied compds. was calcd. using computational methods involving mol. docking of the Colchicine derivs. to β-tubulin. The exptl. and computational results are in very good agreement indicating that the antimitotic activity of Colchicine derivs. can be readily predicted using computational modeling methods.

        Singh, B.; Kumar, A.; Joshi, P.; Guru, S. K.; Kumar, S.; Wani, Z. A.; Mahajan, G.; Hussain, A.; Qazi, A. K.; Kumar, A.; Bharate, S. S.; Gupta, S. D.; Sharma, P. R.; Hamid, A.; Saxena, A. K.; Mondhe, D. M.; Bhushan, S.; Bharate, S. B.; Vishwakarma, R. A. Colchicine Derivatives with Potent Anticancer Activity and Reduced P-Glycoprotein Induction Liability. Org. Biomol.         161
        Colchicine derivatives with potent anticancer activity and reduced P-glycoprotein induction liability
        Singh, Baljinder; Kumar, Ashok; Joshi, Prashant; Guru, Santosh K.; Kumar, Suresh; Wani, Zahoor A.; Mahajan, Girish; Hussain, Aashiq; Qazi, Asif Khurshid; Kumar, Ajay; Bharate, Sonali S.; Gupta, Bishan D.; Sharma, Parduman R.; Hamid, Abid; Saxena, Ajit K.; Mondhe, Dilip M.; Bhushan, Shashi; Bharate, Sandip B.; Vishwakarma, Ram A.
        Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2015), 13 (20), 5674-5689CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Colchicine, a nature-derived microtubule polymn. inhibitor, develops multi-drug resistance in tumor cells due to its P-gp substrate and induction activity, which in turn leads to its rapid efflux from tumor cells. This auto-induction of the efflux of colchicine remains a major challenge to medicinal chemists. Based on structure-based mol. modeling, a series of new colchicine derivs. were designed and synthesized with a potential for reduced P-gp induction liability. Screening of the prepd. derivs. for P-gp induction activity revealed that a no. of derivs. possess remarkably lower P-gp-induction activity (>90% intracellular accumulation of rhodamine 123 in LS-180 cells) compared to the parent natural product colchicine (62% Rh123 accumulation in LS-180 cells). The reduced P-gp-induction activity of new derivs. may be due to their reduced ability to interact and change the conformation of P-gp. The synthesized derivs. were then screened for antiproliferative activity against two colon cancer cell lines including HCT-116 and Colo-205. The deriv. I showed potent cytotoxicity in HCT-116 cells with IC50 of 0.04 μM with significantly reduced P-gp induction liability. Compd. I also inhibited microtubule assembly and induced expression of pro-apoptotic protein p21. In an Ehrlich solid tumor mice model, compd. I showed 38% TGI with no mortality at 2 mg kg-1 dose (oral). Compd. I, with potent in vitro and in vivo anticancer activity, significantly reduced P-gp induction activity and its excellent physicochem. and pharmacokinetic properties open up new opportunities for the colchicine scaffold.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXmt1Wnur8%253D&md5=91c9bba8750971c00cfadfe15776f02f
      162. 162
        Kumar, A.; Singh, B.; Sharma, P. R.; Bharate, S. B.; Saxena, A. K.; Mondhe, D. M. A Novel Microtubule Depolymerizing Colchicine Analogue Triggers Apoptosis and Autophagy in HCT-116 Colon Cancer Cells. Cell Biochem. Funct. 2016, 34, 69– 81,  DOI: 10.1002/cbf.3166
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        162
        A novel microtubule depolymerizing colchicine analogue triggers apoptosis and autophagy in HCT-116 colon cancer cells
        Kumar, Ashok; Singh, Baljinder; Sharma, Parduman R.; Bharate, Sandip B.; Saxena, Ajit K.; Mondhe, D. M.
        Cell Biochemistry and Function (2016), 34 (2), 69-81CODEN: CBFUDH; ISSN:1099-0844. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        Colchicine is a tubulin-binding natural product isolated from Colchicum autumnale. Here we report the in vitro anticancer activity of C-ring modified semi-synthetic deriv. of colchicine; N-[(7S)-1,2,3-trimethoxy-9-oxo-10-(4-phenyl-piperidin-1-yl)-5,6,7,9 tetrahydrobenzo[a]heptalen-7-yl]acetamide (4h) on colon cancer HCT-116 cell line. The compd. 4h was screened for anti-proliferative activity against different human cancer cell lines and was found to exhibit higher cytotoxicity against colon cancer cell lines HCT-116 and Colo-205 with IC50 of 1 and 0.8 μM resp. Cytotoxicity of the compd. to the normal fR2 breast epithelial cells and normal HEK293 human embryonic kidney cells was evaluated in concn. and time-dependent manner to est. its selectivity for cancer cells which showed much better selectivity than that of colchicine. Compd. 4h induced cell death in HCT-116 cells by activating apoptosis and autophagy pathways. Autophagy inhibitor 3-MA blocked the prodn. of LC3-II and reduced the cytotoxicity in response to 4h, but did not affect apoptosis, suggesting thereby that these two were independent events. Reactive oxygen species scavenger ascorbic acid pretreatment not only decreased the reactive oxygen species level but also reversed 4h induced cytotoxicity. Treatment with compd. 4h depolymd. microtubules and the majority of cells arrested at the G2/M transition. Together, these data suggest that 4h has better selectivity and is a microtubule depolymerizer, which activates dual cell-death machineries, and thus, it could be a potential novel therapeutic agent in cancer therapy. Copyright © 2016 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xjt1Citbo%253D&md5=866c11bcb7caa6e07091ae8d58d526ae

        Huczyński, A.; Rutkowski, J.; Popiel, K.; Maj, E.; Wietrzyk, J.; Stefańska, J.; Majcher, U.; Bartl, F. Synthesis, Antiproliferative and Antibacterial Evaluation of C-Ring Modified Colchicine Analogues. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2015, 90, 296– 301,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2014.11.037

        Synthesis, antiproliferative and antibacterial evaluation of C-ring modified colchicine analogues
        Huczynski, Adam; Rutkowski, Jacek; Popiel, Katarzyna; Maj, Ewa; Wietrzyk, Joanna; Stefanska, Joanna; Majcher, Urszula; Bartl, Franz
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 90 (), 296-301CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        A series of 10 amine derivs. of colchicine were obtained with high yields by modification at C(10)-OCH3 position of C-ring and characterized by spectroscopic methods. In vitro cytotoxicity was evaluated against four human tumor cell lines (HL-60, HL-60/vinc, LoVo, LoVo/DX), and antibacterial activity against clin. isolates of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Staphylococcus epidermidis (MRSE). From among the compds. tested the most active is colchicine deriv. I with bis(2-methoxyethyl)amine substituent which is active in nanomolar to submicromolar concns. and is several times more cytotoxic than cisplatin and doxorubicin. This compd. is also effective against the methicillin-resistant Staphylococci strains.

      164. 164
        Kumar, A.; Singh, B.; Mahajan, G.; Sharma, P. R.; Bharate, S. B.; Mintoo, M. J.; Mondhe, D. M. A Novel Colchicine-Based Microtubule Inhibitor Exhibits Potent Antitumor Activity by Inducing Mitochondrial Mediated Apoptosis in MIA PaCa-2 Pancreatic Cancer Cells. Tumor Biol. 2016, 37, 13121– 13136,  DOI: 10.1007/s13277-016-5160-5
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        164
        A novel colchicine-based microtubule inhibitor exhibits potent antitumor activity by inducing mitochondrial mediated apoptosis in MIA PaCa-2 pancreatic cancer cells
        Kumar, Ashok; Singh, Baljinder; Mahajan, Girish; Sharma, Parduman R.; Bharate, Sandip B.; Mintoo, Mubashir J.; Mondhe, Dilip M.
        Tumor Biology (2016), 37 (10), 13121-13136CODEN: TUMBEA; ISSN:1010-4283. (Springer)
        Colchicine, an antimitotic alkaloid isolated from Colchicum autumnale, is a classical drug for treatment of gout and familial Mediterranean fever. It causes antiproliferative effects through the inhibition of microtubule formation, which leads to mitotic arrest and cell death by apoptosis. Here, we report that a novel colchicine analog, 4o (N-[(7S)-1,2,3-trimethoxy-9-oxo-10-[3-(trifluoromethyl)-4-chlorophenylamino]-5,6,7,9-tetrahydrobenzo[a]heptalen-7-yl]acetamide), which exhibited potent anticancer activities both in vitro and in vivo. In this study, 4o with excellent pharmacokinetic profile and no P-gp induction liability displayed strong inhibition of proliferation against various human cancer cell lines. However, pancreatic cancer cell line MIA PaCa-2 was found to be more sensitive towards 4o and showed strong inhibition in concn. and time-dependent manner. By increasing intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels, 4o induced endoplasmic reticular stress and mitochondrial dysfunction in MIA PaCa-2 cells. Blockage of ROS prodn. reversed 4o-induced endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, calcium release, and cell death. More importantly, it revealed that increased ROS generation might be an effective strategy in treating human pancreatic cancer. Further 4o treatment induced mitotic arrest, altered the expression of cell cycle-assocd. proteins, and disrupted the microtubules in MIA PaCa-2 cells. 4o treatment caused loss of mitochondrial membrane potential, cytochrome c release, upregulation of Bax, downregulation of Bcl-2, and cleavage of caspase-3, thereby showing activation of mitochondrial mediated apoptosis. The in vivo anticancer activity of the compd. was studied using sarcoma-180 (ascitic) and leukemia (P388 lymphocytic and L1210 lymphoid) models in mice and showed promising antitumor activity with the least toxicity unlike colchicine. Such studies have hitherto not been reported. Taken together, these findings highlighted that 4o, a potent deriv. of colchicine, causes tumor regression with reduced toxicity and provides a novel anticancer candidate for the therapeutic use.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtlWgtbnM&md5=4061b3cedb1eb7ede5ea22fe93beabe3

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        165
        Synthesis of colchicine C-10-amino-acid derivatives
        Garazd, Ya. L.; Garazd, M. M.; Kartsev, V. G.
        Chemistry of Natural Compounds (2015), 51 (6), 1138-1141CODEN: CHNCA8; ISSN:0009-3130. (Springer)
        Modification of colchicine by addn. of natural and synthetic amino acids is reported. Condensation of colchicine and sodium salts of amino acids in EtOH-H2O mixts. with heating with heating, followed by acidolysis of the resulting salts produced in 62-76 % yields colchicine amino-acid derivs. with a free carboxylic acid that contained glycine, L-alanine, L-valine, L-leucine, L-isoleucine, L-methionine, L-phenylglycine, DL-norvaline, DL-norleucine, DL-2-aminobutanoic, 4-aminobutanoic, 6-aminohexanoic, and 1-(aminomethyl)cyclohexaneacetic (gabapentin, Neurontin) acids. The obtained colchicine C-10-amino-acid derivs. are interesting as multi-purpose org. synthons because they contain an active carboxylic functional group, which are opened new possibilities for their further modifications.

        N-alkyl colchiceineamides: their inhibition of GTP or taxol-induced assembly of tubulin
        Ringel, Israel; Bakshi, Orly; Mellado, Wilfredo; Ramu, Avner; Gibson, Dan; Katzhendler, Jehoshua
        Biochemical Pharmacology (1988), 37 (12), 2487-9CODEN: BCPCA6; ISSN:0006-2952.
        Colchicine and ten 10-N-alkyl colchiceinamides [I; R = Me, Et, Pr, iso-Pr, Bu, iso-Bu, CMe3, (CH2)3NMe2, (CH2)6NH2, and NMe2] were prepd. by reaction of colchicine with alkyl amines in MeCN. In these compds., the C-10 position is protected against hydrolysis. I inhibited the GTP- or taxol-induced polymn. of calf brain tubulin in vitro, their potencies correlated inversely with the size of the amine side chain. I were cytotoxic to various cell lines, and this effect correlated with the inhibition of tubulin assembly.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        168
        Fluorinated colchicinoids: antitubulin and cytotoxic properties
        Ringel, Israel; Jaffe, Dena; Alerhand, Sara; Boye, Oliver; Muzaffar, Anjum; Brossi, Arnold
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1991), 34 (11), 3334-8CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623.
        The synthesis of B-ring and C-ring trifluoroacetamide-substituted colchicinoids and fluoro-substituted colchicineethylamides is presented. The B-ring trifluoroacetamido-substituted analogs exhibit moderate enhancement of potency compared to the nonfluorinated analogs for tubulin assembly inhibition and cytotoxicity toward two wild type cell lines. The C-ring substituted fluoroethylamides have reduced relative potencies in the same systems due to the strong electron-withdrawing effect of the fluoro derivs. The fluorocolchicinoids are much more cytotoxic toward drug-resistant cell lines than to the wild type cell lines. Their enhanced potency is probably due to an effect of the fluoro moiety on functions specific to resistant cells and/or their higher hydrophobicity that may result in higher intracellular drug content. This finding may suggest the application of designed fluorinated anticancer drugs to overcome acquired resistance which may develop after several regimens of treatment with a nonfluorinated chemotherapeutic agent.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xjtl2itg%253D%253D&md5=156ebd20d524296abc4ee6ff268590a0
